In any case, I would say this is a pretty good show. I would give it a try if you like romance. There are so much feels. :D

-Summary-
Story: 7
Art: 9
Sound: 8
Character: 10
Enjoyment: 8
Overall: 8
This show is a good and realistic romcom/drama with an amazing and enjoyable cast of characters.  The realism is contradicted by the ghost haunting the main character and the contrived memory problems the main character deals with.  These factors however do not ruin the show but do perhaps prevent it from being something great and classic.  The art and character designs are beautiful and the sound gets the job done.  
-Details-
Story: 7
Genres: Comedy, Drama, Romance
Themes: College Life, Memory Loss, Personal Identity, Coming of Age
This show has a continuous narrative, and the story is mostly aboutinterpersonal relationships and romances.  This is a show where the story goes beyond the point where the main guy asks the girl out; the story mostly explores the challenges that come along with dating and opening up to someone else and letting them learn everything about you: the good, bad, and ugly.  \n
One thing that sets this show apart from other romcoms/dramas is its attempt at realism.  While there is some reliance on typical anime romcom/drama tropes, the uniqueness and personality of the setting and characters is actually pretty refreshing.  This anime takes place in college, not high school, and this difference actually shows, is significant, and does indeed give a different feel to the show than if it was a high school anime.  The wildness and relative freedom of college life is captured well, whether that be in the adventures/dates of the main cast, or whenever they get pulled into the shenanigans of the crazy tea party club.  This show is mostly about the romantic relationships between the main characters, and this seems to me to be much more realistic than other romance anime.  Realism isn't necessarily a virtue in itself since many people, including myself, enjoy the wackiness and unrealistic feel of anime quite a bit.  However, the upside of a realistic romance is that it isn't done as much since it's hard to write.  In that respect this anime can be refreshing, especially for people who do actually value realism and want to see it more in anime.\n
I think the realism of this show comes across most in the character interactions and in the dialogue.  What I love most about this series is that the love that develops between characters in this show makes sense and does not happen for no reason.  The hero is legitimately attracted to the beauty and playful personality of the heroine, but he also does not mindlessly pursue her and is willing to give up the relationship if she is not willing to see him as more than just a friend she can be real with.  He doesn't let himself get used and thus is a strong and pretty respectable male character.  The heroine starts out with some emotional-dependency issues and is a little immature, but she grows in a realistic way.  She goes through difficult times and sufferings, learning that people are not simply who she wants them to be.  She learns to love people for who they are and learns how to get along with other people who have their own freedom and desires and learns that she can't just control people based on her plans.  She gains a lot of self-confidence and matures into someone who can truly support and love another person.  In this show we get to see this process of maturing and the suffering that can go along with it, which I think really adds to the realism.  The dialogue between characters in these kind of situations makes sense and is not just rehearsed anime dialogue.  I felt like these people were real and were having real life dialogue when they were trying to work through their problems and disagreements.  What they said made sense; they were people and they tried to stick up for themselves and tried to communicate their own real thoughts to another real person.  This was probably the strongest part of the show and its story.\n
The reason the story gets a 7 from me is because this attempt at realism is completely contradicted by the main plot device: the main character's amnesia.  Amnesia and memory loss in itself is not unrealistic of course, but the way it's handled in this show is pretty unrealistic (it seemed to me at least; I don't know how regaining memory works so if this show actually does it right then feel free to contact me about this).  I'm going to avoid end-of-show-spoilers so I unfortunately won't be able to get into the details of why I believe this to be true.  I will say that the thrust of the plot later on in the show is whether or not the main male character will be able to live a stable life and have a stable romance despite the memory problems he has.  There is this bizarre narrative choice taken in the show where the main character seems to be one person, and the person he was before losing his memory seems to be another person who has come back as a ghost to haunt the new person.  At first I thought this was just a narrative choice and so I was fine with it, but then the ghost actually started to interact with the real world and curse the main character, like making it rain when they try to go to the beach.  Furthermore, the main character seems to switch between these two personalities every now and then, and when he does so it seems to come at arbitrary times.  I don't know if this is how memory works or not, but when he reverts to his pre-memory loss self, he loses all the memories he has made since then.  This seemed pretty weird to me.  \n
I can't give away the ending, but what I will say is that it did not make all of this memory stuff seem any more realistic than what I have just described, and is in fact probably even more fantastical.  The main character's relationships with the supporting cast are also not very satisfying by the end.  \n
In summary, there is a great amount of realism in this series in the characters, their interactions, and in the romance, but this is contradicted by the memory loss plot and the whole thing with the ghost haunting the main character.  The realistic parts are very enjoyable and refreshing and make me want to give this show a higher score, but this incongruity with the memory and ghost stuff really hurts, and thus I think a 7 is appropriate for the story.\n\n
Art: 9\n
Studio: J. C. Staff\n\n
The art in this show is very good and consistent throughout.  I never noticed any drop in quality and I don't remember there being in shift in art styles.  The art is an attractive, modern anime style.  The character designs are all quite appealing, especially the main female's design.  The characters are fashionable and attractive.  Backgrounds look pretty good; there is some CGI, but I think this is mostly used for cars and stuff like that.  There was nothing jarring and frankly I think CGI for stuff like cars actually works pretty well.  Overall I think the art worked well with the story; I give this category a 9 simply because nothing really blew me away or stood out as simply amazing.  I don't think a more realistic art style (like in shows like Monster or Space Brothers) would have aided the realism since these are still college students.  I find that realistic art styles makes the most sense in shows with a primarily adult cast.  So again the art in this show is attractive and appropriate, but not groundbreaking.\n\n
Sound: 8\n\n
The sound/music in this show gets the job done but is nothing to write home about.  The opening themes are quite good and appealing; the second opening theme is actually very unique and I like it a lot (it's not a typical j-pop song; frankly I don't know how I'd classify it, but it is good).  I don't have any lingering memory of the OST apart from the opening and ending themes, so it doesn't contain anything that you'll like remember and listen to a bunch.  The voice acting is very good though.  Yui Horie as the female protagonist is probably the standout role; she does her very well and makes for an attractive tsundere voice.  I had no problems with any other voices but I don't remember them too well either.  So as far as sound goes in this show, there are a few memorable qualities; overall it gets the job done well but isn't too memorable either.\n\n
Character: 10\n\n
This is where the show really shines.  All of the characters are very good, well-developed, and for the most part realistic and in that sense refreshing.  The main character isn't just some average, shy, romantically-unaware bimbo.  He has a pretty distinct personality and is quite aware of what is going on around him.  He is level-headed enough to be able to help to main heroine grow and mature as a woman.  He knows when she is just using him to make herself feel better and doesn't let her get away with it.  He is patient and forgiving with her sometimes overbearing personality which makes him a pretty respectable guy.  I've already talked about his memory issues in the story section; this is perhaps the most unrealistic and bizarre part of his character, but I would say this is more a problem with the writing than the character design.  Honestly I think the inner struggles we get to see with him trying to figure out who he is now and who he used to be are pretty interesting.  The ghost that haunts him--his "former" self--can come across as a whiny little brat that gets in the way of the current protagonists' life, but I consider him to be another character entirely.  He is probably the weakest character in the show (and as a mentioned in the story section, I don't even understand why he is there at all).\n
The main heroine is an amazing character and practically makes this entire show.  She starts off as a extremely overly attached girlfriend and is pretty immature as far as her relationships and plans for life are concerned.  Early on she realizes this and starts to change as she is dumped by her old boyfriend and starts dating the protagonist.  She learns how to be less emotionally dependent on her boyfriend and becomes her own person.  She becomes a devoted partner--one who is not too overly attached.  She is able to make decisions which are healthy for her and she is able to look out for herself.  As much as she loves the hero, she is able to take a step back from the relationship when she is unsure whether or not his memories will settle; this is the healthy decision and shows how much she matures over the series.  \n
The supporting cast is not nearly as vibrant as the main characters but they are still pretty unique and get some development.  The hero's childhood friend gets plenty of screen-time and is quite well-developed, and she is very likable and responsible.  The rest of the cast includes the other law students (including the main character's best friend and his love interest, who both get a good amount of screen time), various club members, and other students and teachers.  There are enough characters in this show to really make the setting feel like a vibrant and busy college campus-town.\n\n
Enjoyment/Overall: 8\n\n
This is always a pretty subjective category.  I think if you enjoy romantic comedies and dramas, this should suit you nicely.  The ride is certainly enjoyable--I think the biggest hit-or-miss factor is the ending.  Honestly I would have given this show a 9 had the ending been better, even with the strange stuff with the ghost haunting the main character.  The ending is simply confusing and contrived.  However, I would say that the ending does not utterly ruin this show.  I still see my experience of watching this show as a positive one and I'm glad I did so.  The ride is plenty enjoyable and the characters a still amazing despite the occasionally poor writing (mostly the ending and the ghost thing--otherwise the writing is actually very good).\n
This show is decently accessible given its realism; I think it's possible for a non-anime fan to enjoy this show and not find it weird.  There is the occasional fan-service, but there is actually not much.  The most I remember there being in the show is during the beach episode, but even that is not in your face with crazy camera angles.  Overall I think there is about as much fanservice in show show as there is in average real life (if that makes sense). \n
I think the characters alone give this show some good re-watch value; however, if I were to re-watch it, the ending is not something I would look forward to.  Despite that I would still very much enjoy the ride and the characters along the way.

Spoiler alert don't read unless already watched 
If you want to have your heart broken throughout the story and enjoy it watch this show. 
Okay let's talk about how pissed off I got at this show, but first a characteristic of myself is that I'm a hardcore shipper and i don't stop shipping no matter what. If you have this same characteristic, than do not watch this show unless you want to cry at least 7 times.
Overall I enjoyed the art and sound to anime, it was very well done and I saw no errors and the show itself flowed smoothly.
now on to the plotand how I literally hated this show's plot.

Ever since the introduction of Koko I had hated her with a passion, and throughout the show my feelings remained the same. She was self-centered and in my opinion was not an appealing character to me. The writers then introduced the fact that the old Tada had feelings for Linda through the use of flashbacks/memories. In which I thought was what drove me to continue watching. But apon realizing that the writers chose to make the MC and Koko get to together and not Linda and Tada completely ruined this show for me. Thus causing me to rate it so low in story and enjoyment. Linda and Tada just seemed to jell way and I mean way better than Koko and Tada. Plus the fact of Linda being there in his past and them being through so much to have it all thrown away,  and then having their original relationship never repaired to which it formally was in the end. Plus the writers shipped Linda with Yana which pissed me off even more which lead to me literally making me shed tears. And trust me i don't cry often when watching anime.  

Overall the story just killed me with ships. leading to a 3/10 because of the quality of anime and sound with some character development but trust me I wouldn't recommend this anyone not even people I despise.

Golden Time. 
This anime made me feel happy and sad, made me laugh and embarrassed and made me fall in love with the characters. Isn't that what a great anime is suppose to do? 
With the premise of self conflict and aspiration for romance this anime gave me everything I needed. A compelling story and relate-able characters these are two aspects which are the foundation of a good anime. Character development is the fruit of a good romance anime and it is outstanding and you definitively see how much each character has grown since the first to last episode.
If you are looking for a roller-coasterride of emotion accompanied by heartfelt romance and comedy then this is the anime for you!

This is my first time writing a review but actually I just want to record my opinion of this anime. If ever you find this helpful, then I'm glad.
I have seen many anime, and I mean "a lot" and those that gave me great entertainment whatever its genre are those anime that captivates me from beginning to end. And this anime is one of them.
There are anime that I liked to watch but its not really enchanting yet this work has pulled me in emotionally; just as DN (Death Note) pulled me in thrillingly, Golden Time captured my interest and focus from episode 1 upto the end.


The plot is great, it begins interestingly, develops intensely further up to episode 7 but it gets a little bit dragging in the middle (only because the ending needs that foundation I think) and gets intense again up to the end.


I almost cried, I was drawn into their world, and their feelings became my feelings it was though as if I can really relate to them; it was as if  I also experienced what they've experienced. The opening song has added a lining to its atmosphere, the comedy was really funny and the romances are natural.


Last time I felt this excitement was when I watch Attack on Titan, I was like (even late night already) "1 moooorrree..." It's so fascinating. 


Overall i give this 9/10 

I love the ending, but I feel like it won't need another sequel. Its great in its ending. And also, I had a crush on Kaga Koko! hihihi


p.s. I only give 10/10 when I want another season ^____^

Welcome to a straightforward review for those who are looking for short descriptions to help decide whether this anime is something you want to watch:
A pretty straightforward love drama/comedy with no plot twists.
If you're asking(why so?)the anime lays out the events for you as if you were watching the characters develop real time.If you ask me,this helped emphasize the drama.
If you hate female protagonists who are clingy and obsessive over their lover,you're going to have a 50/50 with the lead(加賀公子/Kaga Koko).
it never goes over the top as she herself understands this trait and tries to control it.
HOWEVER the big 50/50 here is the male protagonisthimself.(多田万里/Tada Banri)\n
Half of the time he is the perfect lead role:Noble,friendly,firm with his decisions.\n
THE OTHER HALFHe turns to everything I hate about an anime MC.:whiny,weak,fixated.THE START OF THE ANIME BASICALLY REVEALS HIS DEFEAT on his first love conquest and his persona doesnt even try to accept it.\n
#Now like I said,he cannot control this,you will know why as you watch the anime,but it gets frustrating to watch#\n
I had to mention this trait,because it is PRETTY MUCH 80% OF THE PLOT.TRUST ME.\n
if he wasnt like this the anime would end in 10-12 eps.\n\n
support characters are archetypes.\n
dont even try to argue with it,it is what it is.\n
handsome guy,nerdy guy,strong willed childhood friend.their backstories arent too deep.\n
the plot revolves around 3 characters(a love triangle)so if thats your thing then this is the anime for you.\n
If you hate a love triangle anime with no strong supporting characters and a deeper plot to give a backbone then maybe you should skip this.

When I first heard of golden time I thought it was an answered prayer, a drama/romance with a setting in college that had the potential to more serious and realistic than its high school counterparts. I loved the plot idea of the main character losing his memories and saw a lot of potential for later plot twists.
Story - 7/10 As mentioned earlier I loved this setting and premise of this series. A college setting with 24 episodes to build a good drama, and hopefully have some major character development in the process. The plot itself was also pretty well laid out, as expected from thecreator of Toradora, with a good balance of drama and comedy. However, something just felt missing throughout the story. My biggest complaint, without giving any spoilers, is the fact that some of the major characters weren't likable enough. You feel like the story is pulling you towards a heart wrenching and joyous ending, but it really turned out to pretty mediocre and full of plot holes.


Art/Sound 6/10 The art and sound of this series were pretty average especially considering some of the other series premiering at the same time. It wasn't bad by any means, but at times it felt hazy and the color contrast looked very dull. As for the music, I thought the 2nd op was absolutely annoying, and the other tracks in the series were okay at best.


Characters- 9/10 Aside from the great setting the true jewel of this series is the characters. They are all very unique and even the supporting roles show a great deal of character development. The only draw back in this section is the limbo of the main character's thoughts and motives. Their indecisiveness throughout the story doesn't create more drama, it just makes the plot drag a lot for two episodes while they make up their mind. 


Enjoyment/Overall- 7/10 Honestly I was pretty disappointed in "GoldenTime" especially after the first half of the series was so good. I feel like the writers were afraid of pushing the envelope and finished out the second half of the story in a very generic way. Sorry to say it but this is nothing but Toradora's awkward sibling and is an insult to be compared to Clannad AS. If you're considering this, I might suggest you just check out "Nagi-Asu" from this showing season instead.

Ok, I'll start this review short. This anime might have been the greatest representation of having a girlfriend and college life ever. The story of this anime was somewhat a bit under average and not greatly supported well. However the art was great and the characters is something relatable. Right now, I'm going though college with my gf and some of those events did occur to me. While watching this anime,I physically cringed on how real they were. Shout out to the crazy tea club and the glow stick scene.
Overall my enjoyment was pretty high. This anime should be something to watch with your girlfriendif you want to give her the quick emotions and comfort move. This review might just be totally bias for my experiences. However, if you want a realistic type of anime, this one would be the one I'll recommend

Just finished the anime a few seconds ago. That was one hell of a ride. The best love comedy I've ever watched. Don't let the shit MAL ratings bother you. This anime is an absolute beauty, I guarantee.
Story - 9/10
-
The story is great. It is set in University. So, I can relate this anime to me better. The story is realistic. It's really really moving. Although the ending was a bolt from the blue, it was good.
Character - 10/10
-
All the characters were great. I think this is the strongest part of this anime. All the characters were developed with care. There relationships were amazing. Allof them had so much to contribute to the story.\n\n
Art - 10/10\n
-\n
The art was really good. Normally you don't see the people in the background animated with so much care. The anime was lively whole time. Specially the surroundings.\n\n
Sound - 8/10\n
-\n
Great sound.\n\n
Enjoyment - 9/10\n\n
Overall - 9/10\n
-\n
This anime is one of the best animes out there. This anime has given me much more confidence. Now I am damn sure that I won't back away from an anime just because the ratings are low. At the end of the day, MAL ratings are shit, reviews are shit. If you want to enjoy yourself, don't let others to decide it for you.

Story = 8/10
Engaging, somewhat unpredictable twists and a solid grasp on the situation. The reason this score isn't higher is because of it's not groundbreaking and the fact that some questions regarding the side characters are left open for the viewer to assume what happens to them. Overall, quite good.
Art = 6/10
The art, in my opinion, is this show's weakest point. It's not bad, but it does falter numerous times. I found myself feeling like the production crew had to do budget cuts and they decided it to be in the art department. Even so, I believe they should be commended for choosing the besttimes to do this, as most of the scenes I was dissatisfied with were not crucial and do not distract the viewer from what the show is trying to portray.


Sound = 7/10


The OST was at times sub-par, but it did go well with the show's tone and they obviously made the effort of having a variety of themes for every occasion. It even surprised me in it's synchronisation with the feeling in the last few episodes. Overall, it could be better, but I was still, quite satisfied with it.

The voice actors did a superb job as well, every breath and stutter was done excellently. The laughter though, a little disappointing. 


I should also note that, the first ending was really to my liking, and the second opening was quite bad. This is my own personal opinion though, and as much as I try to be objective about it, I still prefer to let it sit in a different paragraph to make it stand out.


Characters = 8/10


Very good, I'd even go as far to say it's the best I've seen in quite some time. Characters are shown in great detail, and given the exact amount of attention for their importance in the story. Another important note is that they do develop throughout the show, in a way that is unlike most other shows - Their personality. While most other shows present a character and only change their decisions throughout the show, Golden Time shows us how people change, visibly, not only by their actions, but their behaviour and even their body language.


Personal note: I don't know why I can't give it a 10/10 on this part, but it feels like there is something they could have done to make it even better. Regardless, really good characters, and their development throughout the show.


Overall = 9/10


Great, thoroughly enjoyed it. The amount of realism and emotion it shows, coupled with the voice actors' excellent work, makes this show one of the best dramas I've seen so far. It's good traits heavily outweigh the bad and you'll hardly notice them, making you sit back and enjoy the emotional ride from start to finish.


To be honest, it's a 9.5/10 for me, but I just couldn't round it upwards because it felt just a little bit slow for me, 20-22 episodes would have been perfect, and a little more effort in the art department, and this might have been the best show I've seen, but alas, nothing is perfect.


I highly recommend it.

Golden Time is a kind of anime which gets a lot of things right and just as many things wrong. It does manage to capitalise on many brief moments to give the viewer a pretty rewarding experience. Unfortunately, certain shortcomings really drag down an anime which could have otherwise become much more memorable.
*Possible spoilers from here onwards; read at your own risk*
Story:7 
The story isn't really the most original or special one you'll see: our MC Banri Tada suffers from retrograde amnesia, following an accident in which he had fallen off a bridge. He gains admission to a university in Tokyo, and there he meetsKouko Kaga (the heroine), and falls in love with her. I won't give away too much of the plot, but it's basically about their relationship and how it is affected by the altercation between Banri's past and present selves.\n
Art:7\n
Nothing to write home about, but I do like the way the characters, specially Kouko and Banri, are drawn. The animation is a bit shoddy in parts though, but overall it isn't too noticeable.\n
Sound:8\n
One of my favourite things about the show. The music stays with you, and the both the ending themes are really good. The BGM is above average, and the Japanese voice acting is commendable. I particularly liked Yui Horie as Kouko.\n
Characters:7\n
Volumes can be said about this, because the plot is mainly character-driven; and in this respect Golden Time shows us some true masterstrokes as well as some pretty bad mistakes.\n
My biggest problem with most anime is the way the male MC's are characterized: they are displayed either as absolute oblivious dimwits, or as shy/spineless guys, or as too-many-layered tragic heroes (to the point where they become confusing). The great thing about Banri Tada is that he doesn't fall in the first two categories; the bad thing, that the writer tries a bit to make him like the third. Sometimes he will make you cheer for him (most noticeably when he refuses Kouko's friendship after she refuses his love) but more often his amnesiac melodrama will make you cringe, and though the "ghost" of his past self is symbolically appropriate, the writer might have done better to take a less cliched plotline.\n
The secondary characters, specially Linda, are great in parts, and here again Golden Time has a flaw:it simply does not give them enough screen time. Mitsuo and Linda's romance is only hinted at in the end, and we get to know even less about Oka Chinami and Nijigen-kun's lives.\n
However, nearly all of these flaws of characterization are made up for by one character: Kouko Kaga. Granted, she falls for Banri a little too fast, but her evolution throughout the show is remarkable; and seeing her, once in a while I had that thought which is so rare to have while watching an anime rom-com: 'Yes, this really happens in real life'. Kouko Kaga is one of an endangered species:a non-stereotyped anime rom-com heroine, who seems frivolous, but always wants to do the right thing and can own up to her feelings. Yes, she is a bit over-the-top at times, but then again, it is a romantic comedy. Her romance with Banri has some really great moments, and while they do not make the show exceptional, they certainly do their bit.\n
Enjoyment:8\n
I won't lie, I really enjoyed this show. There is much more to Golden Time than would appear going by the storyline; make no mistake, this isn't your standard fare. You'll have to keep your mind open and look for the nuances, and trust me, you wont be disappointed, unless you are expecting another Toradora! (which by the way, was written by the same author). There is an element of maturity in the handling of relationships; in particular, the "college" setting is a welcome break from ordinary high school romance. The best thing about Golden Time is its closeness to reality: the characters act quite sensibly most of the time, and are certainly refreshing considering the abundance of all kinds of "deres" in anime.\n
Overall:8\n
My review in short--\n
What I liked:\n
1. The refreshing maturity of the show.\n
2. The attention to little details and nuances to lend both liveliness and substance to the plot.\n
3. The feel-good nature of the show and at certain points, the characters' sensibility.\n
What I disliked:\n
1. The uneven pacing and a sloppy, almost forced ending which only answers half our questions.\n
2. Certain over-dramatic moments.\n
3. Banri's exaggerated amnesia which, though symbolic, deviates too far from reality and (let's face it) is far too often used.\n\n
I personally feel that if you want a soft, romantic anime which can make you think a little and reward you for it by making you smile, you can certainly give Golden Time a try. A word of warning though: if you are critical, skeptical, or cynical by nature, this anime is absolutely NOT for you.\n\n
This is my first review. Maybe a bit overlong, but certainly hope it helped!!

From beginning to middle to End , Golden Time's storyline was very solid. All though there were some episodes that were boring the romantic side of the story delivered at a 100% ! Graphics were very nice, each supporting characters played a crucial role into this and im glad they were not just shadows for the main character. The only that I have a problem with is that this did not have a second season. I wanted to see what played out after and i think it would of boosted this anime even more if there was one. I recommend this anime to any romanticlovers our there as for any relationships that are complicated and not going well this anime can help you a lot and relate as it did for me !

Ok, in any serialization, they childhood friend was often left either in the shadows or being rejected by the main character, I mean that for the most part was often the fate of the childhood friend. Here, we see the childhood friend, being placed in a whole prospective, this is the part where we see what happens next to the childhood friend after being dumped by the guy, and viola she finds someone for her. Ok, there there might have been a lot of ships, that has transpired in this anime over the course of its airing, however I cannot deny that this anime tobe 24 episode long was simply too much since it was all about the relationship between Banri and Kouko and the challenges that their relationship has to go through. About the characters, well at first I do find Kouko very annoying as she represent every girl despite of how gorgeous and affluent she is that every guy wants to dump, because of the way she clings to the guy like glue, on the other hand Banri was this guy better suited for a kind of girl like Kouko, since he somewhat is a glutton for punishment, but I really can't fathom that he has another personality that who was often referred to as "Ghost Banri" who seems to have a liking for his former high school classmate Linda, frankly I find it hard to accept that a person who is still alive would be haunted by his own ghost, co'z usually a person who ha suffered amnesia would still be able to retain his current memory along with his past, but as they say' leave it to them Japs to come out with something unusual and make it usual. As for the other character's like Linda, Mitsuo and Chinami, well in any serialization them Japs always include a harem element, so in the case of these three the harem element was transferred to them, thought I would have preferred that Mitsuo would have gone for Chinami and Linda went for 2D. The support character's here tbh where the usual support group that would keep the protagonist on its toes, well that was expected, so at this point I have nothing more to say, how I rated each part of this anime, I'd say that I gave all of it a straight 7.


Story, Art, Sound, Character, Enjoyment and Overall: all a Good 7.


Adios.

*THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS*
When I first heard about Golden Time, I was really excited. Being a huge fan of Romance, I had high expectations. I thought I finally found a great Romance Anime in a long time. But unfortunately, that didn't happen. What I got was totally different.
Story(1/10): Story starts with our male protagonist Tada Banri entering a law school and having a chance meeting with the female lead, Kaga Koko. It's not a love at first sight sorta thing, since Kaga's in love with Mitsuo, her childhood friend. But one thing leads to another and he doesn't accept her feelings and in turn, Banrihas feelings for Koko. The story's main plot device is Banri's amnesia, which makes for horrible horrible time for viewers. There's also a love triangle which left a bad taste in my mouth. The other love interest is Linda, the girl Banri loved before he had amnesia. The Anime has every single Romance cliche in the book and abuses them till it feels like you're probably gonna pass out from the stupidity of it all.It has random moments of melodrama that are there just for the sake of being there.                                                     They make no sense whatsoever and just move the already wafer-thin plot along. It's sad, since the starting few episodes were actually good. But then the story pretty much went to hell along with my enjoyment. I was seriously half asleep for most of the Anime since I really didn't find anything enjoyable in it.The story had infinite cringe worthy moments that I really didn't know what to make of. But honestly, the worst part was definitely the romance. In a ROMANCE Anime, having ruined the main element, it's obvious that it's gonna be a huge pile of garbage. Finally, the ending. Oh god, the ending. I would've forgiven the Anime if it had atleast ended in a logical way. But NO! The Anime pretty much says ''Screw you!'' and gives one of the worst endings I've ever seen in an Anime. It's stupid, it makes no sense, it pissed me off so much. The story made me facepalm so many times, that I lost count.



Art(4/10): The animation's the only place where I can atleast say something positive about this Anime. The characters look good. The surroundings are coloured with a varied palette and look nice. Still, the animation isn't something to write home about.



Sound(3/10): Nothing much to say. Generic romance soundtracks from start to finish. Voice acting was decent, they felt believable. Opening and Endings are what you expect, and I got tired of them very soon. Overall, pretty bland and tasteless.



Characters(1/10): Now, this is the part of the Anime which I hated the most. I'll start off with Banri. He has two personalities. One before he had Amnesia and one after. Both of them are boring as hell and felt lifeless, especially his past self. The fact that his past self was a ghost(yes, I know, it's ridiculous) that even said he'd ''take over'' the current Banri was SO bad, I couldn't help but laugh and feel sad at the same time. Now we get on to Kaga Koko. In my honest opinion, she is the worst female character I've seen in an Anime by a long shot. In the first few episodes, they seemed nice and I thought I'd like her. But oh boy, I was so wrong. I honestly don't have anything positive to say about her. Everything from her absolutely horrible personality to her quick jump to conclusions without even using her brain, they all pissed me off so much. Her meaningless relationship with Banri infuriated me to no end. I mean, seriously, how can someone be SUCH a huge piece of shit? She's a stalker, she's repulsive, she never listens to anyone and has frequent mood swings, much to the dismay of people around her. She doesn't really even care what happens to people other than herself. The couple of Tada and Koko is there just for show. Their interactions are mundane and feel plastic. There isn't any hint of a real relationship between two adults. 


Now, to the ''supporting'' cast. They get hardly any back story, nor character development. 

Hardly any of them has any memorable scenes, especially Mitsuo who I thought would play a big role in the Anime. Then there's the girl who Mitsuo liked but she barely had any development so I don't really have much to say. And then there's the guy who's eternally called 2D-kun and stays out for most of the duration of the Anime, except in the last episode or two. The ONLY reason I'm giving a single score to character is all cause of Linda. She's the diamond among the pile of coal, so to say. She's actually likable! And she has a real personality too! I really wanted her and Banri to end up together, but yeah, that didn't happen. Also, the relationship between her and Banri was hollow. On multiple occasions, it was to be assumed that she had feelings for Banri. When he asked her if she did like him or not(before he had amnesia), she took way to long to give a reply. And even in the end, I wasn't really sure if she actually confessed her feelings to him or not, which really annoyed me. Overall, the characters are horrible and not memorable one bit. They're probably the worst cast of characters I've seen. 


Overall(3/10): This Anime is an insult to Romance fans everywhere. Watching it took all I had and it tested my patience to the limit. I still can't believe the story's by the same person who wrote Toradora. This Anime is an example of a Romance Anime done entirely wrong. I've never been this disappointed in an Anime before. It really fails everywhere. I really wish I could get the time which I wasted on Golden Time back. So, I recommend that people stay far away from this monstrosity.

Golden Time, a story focusing on just the main couple. In comparison to other's JC Staff's works, Golden Time explores another aspect which we have not yet been exposed to. 
Real life couples. 
The reason why i said that was that, throughout the series, we can actually see the progress of their relationship. I would like to separate the series itself to three parts. The first part of the series showed how they met and the circumstances of each character. Mainly Banri and Kouko. The second part would be the honeymoon period of the relationship where most of the person who had been into arelationship would know. The clinginess and the 'forever want to text you' feeling. Yes, that actually happens in real life. And the third part would be the trust. 


They always say that honeymoon period is round three months and in the anime, the transition from the honeymoon to comfortable and trust was around that time too. Which makes it even more realistic.


People always compared GT with other works by JC, but that just wrong, because GT is unlike others. It's a work by its own. People might want a closure in the sub-plots of the side character, but the way i feel the story, it didn't even matter because GT is about Banri and Kouko. 


And i do think that the writer of GT had done a very good job with the transitions and plotting of the story. There were a few solid scenes. While some might not like it, i think it's very interesting. When you're in a relationship, sometimes, even just a dream will make you feel insecure about your parter. It does happen.


As far as the story, it's a solid 8/10


For characters. Kaga Kouko. A person who thought she knows what is love but in fact knows nothing. She thought by being there with the person she loves is the key for 'love' itself. it was shown by her clinginess and endless text, but after a certain episode, where she knew about Linda, and accept it, she began to trust Banri. By far, Kouko's character development was brilliant. Magnificent. She trusts Banri to remember him till the end.


Tada Banri. A guy who after a particular accident, forgets everything before the accident. Forgetting even his old personality. Because of that, because of fear he tried to run away from his past self and history and creating a new personality all together. This later created a dual personality. his past personality and present personality. When the past tried to take over, he forget the present. and vice versa. The character itself from the start had developed, but throughout the series, we can see the depth of his character.  He loves Kouko, but he doesn't want to forget her. the dilemma drove him into a corner. He was afraid. 


Linda is another main character which played a big part alongside Banri. She was very close with Banri. And was in love with the past Banri. Throughout the series, we can see how she finally confronts her true feelings towards him. She knew that she doesn't love the current Banri. But she still cares for Banri. Not as lovers, as bestfriends. Her development as a character was pretty good.


Mitsuo, Kouko's 'first' love. Was just a bro. his character developed well around with 2D and Chinami. These three characters all showed real life action to each situation. how they cope and solved it. 


So, characters, 8/10


Art 8/10 and Sound 10/10

OMG, the art style had JC written all over it. Kouko looked a lot like Taiga, but don't be fooled, she's not. I love the art style. Everything was smooth and the character movements was not that awkward either. The expressions given by characters was spot on. Both the OP and the ED were very good indeed. I was hooked with the songs. It was so good. And might i say that the second OP was pretty vague at first, both the lyrics and the scenes, but after the last episode, i kinda get what they meant. and yeah, it was beautiful. very beautiful.


So, If you love Rom-Com, you should try Golden Time because it will open your mind to another aspect. The real deal. And if you're an avid reader of a Young Adult genre novels, Golden Time is the anime for you. Because as a reader myself, watching Golden Time was just like reading a novel. The feeling of enjoyment. The satisfaction. It just made you want to say, "That's Golden Time and that's enough."

if you are looking for a good romantic anime and haven't seen Golden time look no further this is the anime for you.Golden time redefines the romantic genre.for about some time now the trend in the romantic genre is that the series will end with start of romance,that is usually the series will end after the protagonists start dating.this is where Golden time differs.it shows the actual romance,what both the main characters has to go through during their relationship.the story is done very good and is relatable for most people even though there is some supernatural elements here.it has its fair share of funny momentsalong with some serious and tensed situations.the way these are mixed together is what makes it enjoyable.this is one of the more realistic romantic anime out there or maybe the most realistic.the characters are also grown ups in college.its so refreshing to see a romantic anime taking place outside of high school.this is an anime everyone can enjoy and is one of the best of the romantic genre along with toradora!.so check it out you wont be disappointed.

The real review will be on the next paragraph so I'll start first with my initial thoughts and expectations from this series. The reason why this title has been sitting in my watch list unwatched for almost 2 years now is because I didn't really have time to watch 24 episode series back then, but now fortunately I was given a chance to check this one out. This series took my interest because well... Honestly speaking, I am attracted to beautifully drawn characters however I lost a bit of hope when I found out that this was not tagged ecchi since I am an enthusiastof that genre. Sorry if I may offend people with that. But well... it's the way I am so what can I do about it? Anyways... let's start with the real review. 


RomCom, is that what they call it? Yeah I'm kinda not used to plain old RomCom without the Ecchi-Harem combo because that's what I have been binging mostly on as you can see in my list. However though, after I have seen this series, I didn't expect it to be this good without all the scenes and shenanigans that I'm used to. In my opinion, this is a good example of what RomCom is supposed to be. Regarding the story, I think the plot goes well with the situations and the scenes were executed pretty well. I was surprised at one of the tags of this show namely "Drama". I was thinking that this might be a bit different compared to the rest of the series that I have seen but probably most RomComs contain drama so I didn't really thought about it much. As the show progressed, I was expecting the drama scenes and I was not disappointed with how well they went. Unexpectedly, I found a hidden genre that this show didn't highlight and I think it is the tag "Psychological". With the synopsis of the main character having amnesia, I think that the genre fits well considering that he has conflicts with himself. You may try and expect cliche from this series but I tell you that you may seem that you're expecting it, but it will catch you off guard anyway and that is one the things I enjoy about it. The comedy... man... if you want your comedy properly complimented by the plot, I assure you that this is a true gem if you like comedy along with your forms of entertainment. I can't count how many times I laughed my arse off from those comic relief moments. They're right on time and they don't stray too far away from the plot. With the comic relief scenes, there are drama scenes too if you're not forgetting about one of the main tags of this show. There were scenes that were rather heartwrenching and indeed painful for others but don't worry, as long as you finish the show, you'll be feeling better in no time. Regarding the art, J.C. Staff did a great job making the art of the anime. Though not as colourful and bedazzling compared to their other masterpieces, this one I rate as decent and on point. The characters were well drawn and that's one of the things that makes this anime nice. The voices fit the characters very well. 

The soundtrack is well played and it shows the shift of emotions in the plot. It sets the mood right for the situations and scenes. The characters are... well... they're kind of strange and unusual. It's my first time watching something that focuses on college campus and not the usual high school background but is it just me or I see no difference at all. Especially that the characters seem to be not acting their age at all and they're just the same as  what high school students would be. But other than that, the personality development is well played for immature people. Well.. I just think that they are but I don't need you to agree with me. Now for the conclusion, I think that this series ended really well with one season and no sequels needed. I never read the manga because I don't really read much but I think the story went pretty well in the anime so all's well ends well. If you are someone who likes RomComs, then I recommend this very much and I also recommend this as a first anime for people who haven't started yet on their anime journey. So that's it for the review and I might be putting more thought into the rating I gave for this series. Thank you for reading my review and if you have any further questions feel free to message me.

Leaving the past behind and start over with your life completely can be a hard thing. I'm pretty sure everybody have found themselves in the need to leave hobbies, things and even close people behind. But we might as well rejoice as we remember them old times.
But, what happens when we are forced to it?? What happens when we can't remember any of these? It's as if we were not alive before getting at a certain point. There's just nothing.
Golden time is a drama that deals with the internal conflicts of mental illness, specifically the Amnesia.
The story follows a dude who gets Amnesia out ofan accident right after finishing high school, and he pretty much forgets everything and everyone that has happened until that accident. After his rehab, he starts going to University, what could be better than a fresh start!


The story is mainly character driven, advancing its plot by inmersing into their relationships, building a close bond with each other and overcoming personal insecurities together.


Kouko's character is the strongest point of this anime, being one of the most relatable and realistic ones. She goes through a lot, and you really get to care for her.


Watch this if you want to watch a non-high school drama and realistic character development.

Tada Banri..? TADA BANRI???? TADA BANRIII!!!???
Well that's definitely a name I will never forget after watching this anime. Golden Time is truly an enjoyable anime that really takes the whole "amnesia" element to a whole new level.
This anime is dramatic, hilarious, nerve-wrecking, heartbreaking, nostalgic, and, most importantly, satisfying. It was truly an emotional roller coaster for me, especially since this anime is directed alot of its attention towards the whole "Who am I?" element.
Story/Characters : 
For story, I give it a 9/10. Unlike most romantic comedies, this anime does not focus on the development of characters into a relationship, but rather a development of therelationship of the characters. Typical romantic comedies like to end the story with the main character and the girl getting into a relationship, but this anime focuses more on how Tada Banri develops his relationship with his girlfriend throughout the rest of the anime. What makes it truly climatic is how the "old Tada Banri" gets in the way of the "new Tada Banri" as if they are two totally different people. To me, this was where the nervewrecking aspect comes in because, knowing that this anime will eventually choose which Tada Banri would win, another Tada Banri would also lose. 


The characters in Golden Time are who truly and successfully add on to the enjoyment and drama, which is why I give them a 10/10. Tada Banri's relationship with all the characters in the university he had worked so hard to get into all have some sort of connection with either the old or new Tada Banri. Golden Time is one of the few animes where I put more pressure on the side characters than the main character himself. Knowing how delicate and fragile the main character with amnesia is, entrusting the side characters to accomplish the viewer's mission and make this story end well for everyone was the only resort, which makes the story 20 times more dramatic, especially for the girlfriend. (the reason why I'm calling her "the girlfriend" is because even though it's obvious, I don't want to spoil it since they don't happen right away... so bear with me on this). I guess you could say that Golden Time is like a dog race to me because instead of cheering for the dog (main character) specifically, I put more emphasis in how fast the artificial hare (side characters) was moving because I knew eventually the dog would follow. 


Delving more into Tada Banri as a character now (God I can't stop saying Tada Banri.... it just has that ring to it), Tada Banri (I did it again..) still has some control over the story, after all he is still the main protagonist. It is the fact that he goes through this identity crisis that makes it much more difficult to see him as someone who is "in control". Tada Banri takes the viewers on a ride because like all stories about memory-loss, amnesia is only temporary. Oftentimes, there are scenes when the Old Tada Banri's high school temptations will take control and then steer back to the new Tada Banri, the university student. The fickleness of when he changes is what makes it scary because whether you want the new or old Tada Banri to take over the story, you know that sometime and somewhere, he will change and throw the whole plot off again. In short, Tada Banri's enemy IS Tada Banri. DUN DUN DUN...


Now for the rest of this review:


Art (7/10) - The art is nothing real special, the characters all look the same and there's no real change. What is beneficial of the art to this anime is how they make it obvious when Tada Banri is referring to a flashback or not because the old Tada Banri is a crybaby and given the weak, scrawny posture, whereas the new Tada Banri is mature and given a more manlier look. This goes for the other character (I won't mention who). 


Sound (8/10) - The music is absolutely amazing. Most of the time, I didn't really paid attention to in the heat of the moment, but by taking the time to actually listen, I realize how well it fits with the whole dramatic and romantic feel to it. (On a side note, the slap sound effects are really like "BAM"... as if we were getting slapped too..). I found it painful how the first intro was something really lovey and dovey and the ending songs that followed was something feelzy and nostalgic. It like makes you reflect on the episode you just finished. A beautiful starting point to a b'awww and feelzy finish each episode was just too cruel of a stopping point and made me watch more just to get that relief I had in the beginning. 


The voice actors were outstanding. From the arguing to the lovey-dovey stuff, the Japanese voice actors did a really good job in conveying and expressing the characters. You just have to watch it to understand what I mean by this.


Enjoyment - Overall, I give this a 10/10 in terms of enjoyment. I could never end an episode without wondering what would happen next. If you are a fan of super dramatic scenes that would tear your heart and then sew it back up CONSTANTLY...then this is definitely something for you. Now I mentioned before that this anime was satisfying and it's because by the end of this anime, you have nothing much more to ask. The story arc is closed to a clean finish and there are almost no critical holes that you felt needed to be filled. 


What I really liked about this anime was the fact that it's taking place in a university in Tokyo this whole time. Finally.. an anime that does not include high school for once... The characters are so mature that even when there is ecchi, the concept of sex is seen as an aspect of love rather than just being a dirty pervert like most animes would do. ("The Night in Paris" ;P ). There's a lot more things that I would love to babble on and on about, but this review is getting way too long, so I'll end it here.


I hope this review was helpful to those that don't really understand what Golden Time is all about and how much of an impact it had on some of its viewers, especially me. 


If it didn't then sorry about that. I hope I at least helped you realize it's not your style ^^. As long as I helped why not.

My 1st Short Review: (Long ones are such a drag)
Golden Time is a jolly good ol' Romcom if you ask me. While I won't call it my favorite Romance story, it was very enjoyable to say the least. The story is not exactly what I consider unique, maybe pseudo-unique, just read the details on the tab above(Details) if you are interested.  However, it does a very good job of creating a believable relationship(More or less). 
Story: Do you want a typical romcom where the main characters take the entire series to admit they love each other? To date? Well, this ain't one of them.Actually it is solely about an ongoing relationship, with the all the struggles and bs you deal with in a normal one. With the exception of things being blown hella out of proportion. Or in other words, young people romance. 

The story still is pretty basic ish and it follows a simple plot which can be read in the detail tab. I enjoyed it for the simple plot and the relationship problems, granted it may not impress some. I mean it didn't impress me greatly, but it was entertaining. For me, entertaining in enough. 


Art: Basically, it was basic. Nicely done and attractive looking basic. Still a basic slice of life look to it, nothing non-basic or different. It had above-basic colors and lighting though. 


Sound- I don't really remember anything particularly great. The opening and closing songs were good though. 


Characters- Honestly, Banri was a pretty typical non-talented and normal teenage boy. Koko was actually interesting, mostly due to the fact she was a little bit  obsessive and nuts. Oka Chinami developed somewhat quickly for my tastes. The supporting character Nana was pretty boss. 2-D was really funny.


Enjoyment- I did enjoy it anyways. Regardless of the flaws that you will likely see as you progress through the anime. It is entertaining and at least worth one watch through.


Overall- Personally I would have gave it a 7. The thing is I like happy endings, so I gave another point. I'm pretty lenient when it comes to that.  So it is an 8.

After finishing the marvelously written Toradora, I found a void in my heart that could only be filled with other romance-genre anime. I had heard of Golden Time as being another romance written by the same author as Toradora, which immediately had me intrigued. From the first 10 minutes or so, I could tell that this show would be - pardon the pun - a golden time.
There are a few pieces of this show that really stood out. The first is probably the most often mentioned when discussing this show: a rejection of the typical "romance" format (waiting until the last episode for a relationshipto happen) and instead having the relationship happen early-ish in the series, with the remainder being used to examine that relationship and how the circumstances this show creates changes the relationships in this show. 


The other most striking thing about this show is how original the plot is. There are unique circumstances for the main character(s) which makes this far more than just about a relationship. It forces the viewer to ask questions about their own identity and its influence from how others perceive them, as well as many more that I can't quite go into without actually giving spoilers. This gave the show a drive and context in a direction that kept me interested fairly early on, and kept me guessing until the end.


As a side note, the comedy in this show is most definitely better than average. The show was outright brilliant at times with it's comedy and made me laugh out loud on my own at least twice, which is a rare occurrence for me. The voice acting was marvelous


Of course, the show was not without its flaws. The characters (mostly just the main character) sometimes reacted to a situation in a way not consistent with their age (them being college students). Understandably this adds some characterization, and not everyone can react maturely all of the time, but I still found myself frustrated at times. Moreover, parts of the ending are confusing at first until you realize what's symbolism and what isn't. These are all small imperfections in an otherwise marvelous show.


This show surprised me from the first episode. It kept me engaged throughout the series, and made sure that I felt the emotional anguish the other characters felt when things got dramatic. Much like Toradora is commentary on the difference between love and infatuation, Golden Time is commentary on how powerful love can be, and the struggle of facing our problems for someone we love. I can certainly assure you that this is a message that I will not soon forget.

Not sure why people disagree so strongly with this review. But I really did enjoy this series \o/
There aren't many series that can handle the amnesia plot as brilliantly as Golden Time has. From the plot, characters, and even constant revelation of the mysterious past, Golden Time will take you for a ride on a bumpy feels train.
I didn't go into this with high expectations, but as I was watching, I realized how well-developed each character had become. There's a focus and back story for all the MCs, and the entire focus on memories makes all the experiences feel that much more meaningful and unforgettable.I surprised myself when I didn't feel the urge to look for a second season. Golden Time stands perfectly by itself, and you can't ask for a more satisfactory end between Koko and Banri (main couple).\n\n
Most importantly, Koko and Banri aren't frustrating and unrealistic like many amnesia plot MCs. They support each other and give each other time to find themselves. The more I think about it, the more I realize how much each character has developed. It may seem strange to say this, but after watching this series, I feel extremely connected to each character, as if I was a part of the adventure. This experience is something I'll never forget, and it was a real pleasure watching this series. Thanks Golden Time!

What's your own recipe for a good romance anime?
To me it's lovable characters, some comedies, more relationship development with lovey-dovey scenes and less pre-confession stories, and of course sprinkle it with a dash of drama. And to me Golden Time has just sort of nailed them all. This is a short review of the elements which made this anime IMO one of the best romance story ever.
Story (10/10)
First of all, almost 90% of romance animes i already watched were set up in high school and i have no complain or whatsoever that high school setting has a lot of potential for romantic stories that couldbe developed to an after story (i.e after graduation). Golden Time was some kind of novelty to me, because at last I found a romance anime that isn’t started and set up at high school. The story felt fresh like nothing I’ve seen before, no fragile school kids, no uniforms, no boring school festivals, no rubbish shoujo-ish kind of story, just one guy fell in love with a girl, confessed, lovey-dovey relationship, drama, solved, happily ever after, as simple as that.


Character (9,5/10)

This anime has one of the best written characters I’ve ever seen in the anime world. There’s only one character who’s annoying as hell, the “Ghost Banri". Other than him they’re all likeable characters.

Kaga Kouko – Yes, she’s the kind of “ojou-sama” here, a bit yandere-ish, obsessive, clingy, and insecure. But behind all that characters she’s a very loyal girl, dedicated to the person she loves, cheerful, straightforward, and down to earth as well. IRL I’d definitely choose a girl like her over a passive or tsundere-ish one.

Tada Banri – Yes, the MC who suffered from amnesia looked like a fragile guy, but no, he’s a very brave, very loyal, tolerant, and caring guy indeed. The relationship between him and Kouko is sometimes cheesy, but yet just a lot of fun and satisfying. This proved that the 2 of them are really a good match. If it wasn’t because of his amnesia and the “Ghost Banri” he would’ve been my absolute favorite romance MC ever. 

The side characters are also great, especially 2D-kun who’s without a doubt the real MVP of this anime, Nana-senpai the best senpai and neighbor I’ve ever seen, and the 2nd main girl Linda, which I don’t hate despite being the “threat”, because it turns out she isn’t even trying to steal the MC from Kouko, instead she’s being supportive of them despite the fact she still has feelings for him.


Overall (9,8/10)

I wouldn’t say this anime is perfect because it still has a bit of downsides, but as a romance anime this felt really enjoyable and refreshing, definitely the best one I’ve ever watched. There are so many emotions you can get, heartwarming, cuteness, laugh, sadness, friendship, happiness, cheesiness, all of them are there. Everytime I’m bored with animes with same kind of plots and settings I always rewatch Golden Time because it is one of a kind, and everytime i did rewatch it, i always got hit by all the feels this anime delivers from the beginning until the end. If you’re a romance fan who’s looking for something different in a romance anime, look no further.


Oh, and the only complaint I have for this anime :


WHY TF DO PEOPLE IN THIS ANIME LIKE TO TALK IN A PITCH-DARK ROOM?!

Wine.  If one considers the average rom com in this context, you'd be talking about a syrah or malbec.  Golden Time, by contrast, is a Brunello di Montalcino.  Mature.  
GT's expansiveness, much like the delicate and reserved flavor imparted by the Sangiovese grapes used in making Brunello di Montalcino, is derived from its discussion of deeper aspects of the human condition relative to other series in its genre.  Particularly, its handling of mental illness, and how these conditions can affect not only one person, but those we love and care for.  
It attempts to and succeeds at redefining 'loss.'It teaches us that sometimes in life, the more we try to hold close and treasure the things that matter most, the more those things slip through our fingers.  Most of all, it teaches us that we define ourselves by the reflections we see in the eyes of others.\n\n
Speaking of eyes, you'll probably cry at the end.\n

Golden Time serves as a reminder that, sometimes we can't explain our love of a show simply by quantifying it in the usual manner. Nevertheless, let's break it down:
Story (7) - A lot of big pros here but also a couple huge cons. After an exceptionally good introductory phase, the story hiccups in it's early-middle stage, when the introduction of the supernatural aspect to this show feels rather out of left field and forced. It's ok because ultimately we end up with a story that does what we need: give these exceptionally beloved characters high stakes to fight against. And that's why I still considerGT's story to be strong despite its issues. At the end of the day, the story is big enough to get you to bawl your eyes out for Koko and Banri.  


Art (8) -  A controversial aspect of the show. I won't deny there are flaws. Things ocassionally look awkward in GT. But it's unorthodox approach also leads to some uniquely satisfying sequences, be they for humor or drama. Besides, at the end of the day, Koko looks beautiful and Banri's pretty well done too... It's an unconventional and imperfect approach they use but in many ways that makes it a nice breath of fresh air compared to most slice of life anime. The OPs and EDs in particular are beautiful to watch.



Sound (8) - Golden Time's first set of opening and closing are dazzlingly whimsical, and immediately set the right tone for the show. Its second set is a bit more melodramatic, but that works as well for what is happening by then. Additionally, the voice acting and effects are both very solid. My only complaint is that its OST seems to be a bit lacking in variation. In particular, there is a track involving an acoustic guitar that is in my opinion very overused, to the point where it often becomes an annoying distraction. 


Characters (10) - The characters are what push this series into "must see" territory. In particular, Koko Kaga is incredibly well crafted. From her grand entrance, it's clear she's capable of stealing any scene she's in. A lot of romantic female leads (particularly in anime) are created with the approach of having a split personality (see: tsundere). These characters will do something like act aggressive to cover up their kindness or vice versa. Koko and Golden Time cleverly defy this, and instead introduce a girl who's in love and (the vast majority of the time) entirely honest about it. And they tell her story flaws and all. Rather than relying on contradictory actions, Koko does a lot of things that simply fall in gray areas.  Is she a stalker or just really sweet? Is she using people or is she just too shy to open up to them? Is it pathetic that she can't think of much more than love or is that what makes her a beautiful person? We intend to find out. Aside her, Banri makes for a strong male lead. He doesn't quite have her charisma, but he's very honestly told and more layered than a lot of the simplistic white knights that tend to pop up in the genre. The supporting characters are also exceptionally strong here. Mitsuo, Banri's first college friend and Koko's longtime crush, is a wonderful addition, as are Chinami, 2d-kun, and Linda. 


Enjoyment (10) - So this is the subjective aspect I suppose. For me, this show tapped into a lot of personal feelings. I sympathized a great deal with how Koko felt throughout. Many have said that this show makes more sense to people who have been in a relationship. I respectfully disagree. The entire way Koko acts will hit home for anyone who's truly loved another person romantically, regardless of how that turned out for him or her. As someone who's had their feelings for another unrequited, I was charmed by this series. It earns its perfect 10, along with an extra gold star for being the show I to this day (as I update this review in 2018) love the most. The satisfaction of GT's ending left me overjoyed in a way that no show has ever been able to match.


Overall (10) -. I think the art/animation will annoy people who care a lot about that aspect, and the story is not without its problems. But for me that simply does not change the fact that this anime is a 10/10. I found it connected with me in a way no other story ever has in any medium.. In particular, if you want a show that you will hit your feelings hard, this is a good choice. You're likely to cry tears of joy, tears of sadness, and tears that you aren't really sure how to classify. Much like its female lead, you'll find that Golden Time's strengths are more than enough to overcome its flaws.

This anime from start to finish was exactly what I was looking for in an anime. There was wholesome and comedic romance, and at the same time, the drama gave me the FEELS.
The story is about a couple, where the guy suffers from amnesia. As his memories come back there are many problems occur. His past feelings come back and present feelings are lost. It is a very interesting story that really keeps your attention and would make you binge it. It is a very classic and cliche story, but done very well.
The art and music are not bad. Sure, there are way more otheranimes with way better art and music, but I think the art really fits in with what's going on. The music is either very happy and cheerful, or sad and moody, fitting very well with what happens in the story.\n\n
Overall, I really enjoyed it and this anime still remains as one of my favorite animes of all time.

Story: This show is about a college dude named Tada Banri. He is new to Tokyo and studies in college as a 1st year student. He met a guy named Yana Mitsuo when heading to college. He met this girl named Kaga Koko who is Yana Mitsuo's childhood friend, and fell in love with her at first sight. The stories develop as they both are strangers at first, and becomes lovey-dovey when the story progresses, but that is not all, there is hardships between their romance and their circle of friends. 
Art: Perfect. Nothing much to say on this cause' its pretty damn good.
Sound: Themusic will sometimes trigger your emotions depending on the scene. Sometimes if it hits a little close to home, your heart might feel that its going to be ripped apart (I'm just exaggerating) but yeah, you might actually cry towards the end if you are a sucker for romantic comedy.


Character: Very well rounded characters. Tada Banri is a simple guy with simple needs. While Yana Mitsuo is a guy that is sick and tired of his childhood friend. 2D-kun is an Otaku HAHAHA 😂👌. Oka Chinami is a bit of a complicated character because she is not honest with her feelings, but is a good friend as a whole. Linda is someone that likes to keep secrets to herself, but is a good friend to Banri, and the others. Last, but not least Kaga Koko, she is a clingy girl that is romantic, and is loyal to her boyfriend, but can be quite overly attached as a girlfriend.


Enjoyment: I loved almost every single bit of it except for Banri's whole amnesia thing because I found it a bit ridiculous, and the characters can be a bit over dramatic, but people can get really over dramatic in real life too, so its to be expected that the characters would be that way in here also, so once you get over those 2 things because i have, then hopefully you find yourself loving this anime as much as i did.


Overall: I give it 9/10. And yes I really like this show as a whole. It is one hell of a ride, it has ups and downs, and drama with a pinch of feels. ♥♥♥

I'm a psychology and neurobiology major who is a huge otaku. While I really wasn't looking for a dramatic anime like Golden Time, I decided "What the heck, why not?" The story-line is nice, it has good comedy and doesn't try too hard to make it work. The drama was pretty intense as well. However I really have serious qualms with the individuals' psyches, mainly that of the female characters. Firstly Linda: the anime hints WAY too many times that she intended to say "yes" to Banri's confession but never actually does a development which follows suit. In the end it literally shows thatshe did indeed say yes to the confession (this is assuming that the former Banri was not actually imagining this outcome in order to be put at rest). In contrast to this, according to Linda's own thoughts, she regrets that she did not come earlier to respond to his confession but DOES NOT actually ever explain her own answer. If she had, it is likely that if she said "yes" it merely is because of that regret, not actual love. \n
SECOND, Oka Chinami: Her character is literally EVERYWHERE! All paradoxes with no clear personality type. Honestly the reason the anime had her was to fill in the unexplained gaps and use her as a happy-go-lucky (and foolish) martyr while not even paying attention to what her personality should actually be.\n
Lastly Kaga Koko: WHAT THE HELL??? While the last 7 or so episodes showed her as a FUNCTIONING human being, everything before that showed her as a severely hypomaniacal, narcissistic, borderline personality, OCD, spoiled rich girl with a huge case of Dependent Personality Disorder. Honestly how can someone go 18 years and not be a candidate for psychotherapy and hospitalization??? Jeez.\n
Sorry for ranting so much but I couldn't just sit here quietly and accept that this anime had severe issues.
