For any beginner anime enthusiast who has a soft spot for romance but has no idea what to watch, look no further! Golden Time is the perfect romance anime for any anime viewer. Going into this anime, I was expecting your average romance and predictable story. Thank the gods that wasn't the case. Golden Time features one of the more unique plot foundations in romance anime, giving the anime a very good twist and route to follow. The story is an 8 for me, only due to the fact that the ending left some to be desired. I honestly think it could've gone better andeven if done right, a second season could've been born. The art and sound are a 7. I mean, it's good. Nothing flashy and nothing horrendous looking.  The characters are a huge 10/10, as well as my enjoyment. An unforgettable cast of characters come right at you in episode 1. There's many emotional moments, more than you'd expect from a romance anime. I think that's why it's so good. More episodes than not leave on a cliffhanger, which makes you say "Ah 1 more episode" at 10pm and then it's 2am all of a sudden.\n
It's a 9/10 from me. I believe it would be a 10/10 from me if they solidified the ending more, buuuutttt that's just me.

Many shows suffer from poor execution of interesting concepts. When I started this show (throughout the first half or so) I never would have imagined that I would ever say that about this show. I thought that at best, it would get better with time, at worst I would drop it within 10 episodes. However, while the concept got more and more interesting, the execution fell apart episode by episode. I'm going to have a paragraph at the end with spoilers as I cant properly explain the execution problem with this show without spoiling a major plot element. Lets get started.
Story: 4
The story is apretty generic school setting romancy show, exactly what you probably came here to see. The issue is that the execution of Banri's amnesia was absolutely horrible. There were no outside influences on the relationship between Koko and Banri and the only issues were misunderstandings and the "amnesia" plot device. What made this story interesting for me, and the only reason I finished the show, was this amnesia plot device (If you don't mind spoilers I will talk about this more at the end). It was a truly fascinating concept and I was curious where the show would take it. I was dissapointed. 


Characters: 3

This show had some of the best side characters I have ever seen. Oka and 2d  are brilliant supporting characters, with distinctive personalities and traits that honestly would have been better suited to a better show. The reason I rated this show so low is the main characters and their interactions among each other. Koko is entirely unrelatable, except for a few parts near the very end of the show, and honestly I couldnt care less about their relationship. As a show that is solely about the relationship between Koka and Banri, it failed miserably in getting me emotionally involved in the relationship. Banri is in himself a pretty decent character, with relatable problems and goals, but unfortunately we lose all that by having him involved with Koko. Characters like Yana and Linda, whom I would call main supporting characters, are pleasantly decent. They don't steal the spotlight (Which is a bad thing in this show) but they also had a ton of character development and were very interesting to watch. The show was dragged down mostly by Koko and the way that the relationship between Koko and Banri was carried out.


Art: 10

The art is beautiful. I think this category is pretty subjective but watching the show felt great for me. I absolutely love the bright colors and happy atmosphere set by the art.


Sound: 9

Again, a fairly subjective category. I thought the music was well selected and set the mood it was supposed to. If anything, the music is what kept me from skipping entire conversations between Koko and Banri. 


So overall I rated this show a 5 because it is at a word mediocre. Its not a bad show by any means, but it isn't worth watching either unless you really love this genre and have gone through everything good (Toradora). In hindsight, I actually do regret finishing this show. The ending was a major letdown. I had hoped that it would make up for the 23 episodes that I watched to get to it. It did not. 


This is the spoiler part about the amnesia thing. If you don't want spoilers than that's my final opinion on the show. I hope this helped.


So the part of this show that I really liked was the concept of 2 Tada Banris. One who lost his memories and was now living in Tokyo, and the ghost, who was no longer living. The main "conflict" was when the ghost began to take over the body of the amnesiac Banri. This could have gone in any number of interesting directions, resulting in a triangle between Linda and Koko, or even Oka and Koko. Instead, this ghost spends like 5 episodes "cursing" Banri in ways that would imply some kind of magic powers. I can accept this duality ghost thing in a romance anime, but magic powers really took me out of the show. Then Banri began to "dissapear" which was also a great take imo. However this great development lasted 2 whole episodes and was fixed by... ... hell idk. I dont know how they fixed it. Its just gone now. Boom. I don't want to spoil what actually happened in the finale cause then this show really wouldnt be worth watching but take what you want from this review. Thanks for reading and I hope it helped.

*SPOILER FREE REVIEW*
J.C. Studios is a familiar name in the world of anime. I had high expectations of Golden Time after the recommendations of my friends. Needless to say, I was not disappointed.
Story 7/10
On the surface, the plot is rather simple. However, it can be likened to the layers of an onion. As the series went on, many underlying themes were brought out, sometimes in a subtle manner, which I admire. The story progressed at a mostly consistent fast pace, albeit dropping off towards the end. There were a few palpable plot twists, but it served well to give the story life. If I hadto nitpick, the numerous arcs were resolved too quickly, and felt rushed at times.


Art 8/10

The art was high quality and very smooth.


Sound 4/10

Not only were the OP and EDs nondescript, they felt too lively and spoiled the mood at the end of a sombre episode. However, the pieces used during dramatic or emotional moments were well-timed.


Character 8/10

As much as this anime is a romance, it is equally as much of Tada Banri's journey of self rediscovery. How he fought with his own demons and his highly strung behaviour places together pieces that reminded me how delicate human nature could be. His relationship with Kaga Kouko tugged at the heartstrings, and was an accurate portrayal of love. The main characters progressed neatly, and we see them develop complex personalities, which felt gratifying. Per contra, a few of the supporting characters appeared generic.


Enjoyment 8/10

I wholly enjoyed Golden Time as the fast pace engaged me. I relished the deepening story, and liked how the characters were progressing throughout the story.


Overall 8/10

Overlooking the music, Golden Time was a very good anime and I would recommend it.

[spoilers regarding the story antagonist]
I'm about to rip into this show's antagonist pretty hard. Aside from that, I enjoyed the storyline and main characters enough to watch the show twice, so I feel the following criticism is more than fair. The show has a great and surprisingly mature romance story. In fact, writing this review makes me want to watch it a third time. Although I normally dislike stories that feature amnesia, Golden Time doesn't seem to insult my intelligence about it. I'm aware that amnesia stories are a huge turnoff for people, but I feel like this story isn't hurt by it (except forthe antagonist).


While I give this a rating of "fair", Golden Time has a glaring narrative problem that tries at every turn to ruin the excellent romance story contained within: the antagonist.


The antagonist is basically a ghost for lack of better terms. The ghost exists because it is the pre-accident identity of the protagonist, Banri. At first Banri refers to his lost identity as a ghost, and I thought it was a touching philosophical take on his amnesia how it affects his relationships. But then, in one of the most painful eye-rolling moves in all of anime, the show reveals the ghost is real! And he doesn't want Banri to be with Koko. 


This is where our first problem occurs: the motivation of the antagonist makes no sense. He clearly identifies himself as a separate person from the real (or current) Banri. He doesn't want that Banri to hook up with Koko because he wants her to be with Linda. But wait - he goes on about how he loves Linda... so if he identifies as a different being, and he loves Linda, why does he want to get the protagonist to hook up with the woman he is in love with? Isn't that counter-intuitive and self-defeating? One may argue "he knows he's a ghost so the closest he can get to Linda is to get the real Banri with her," but I don't buy that. The show does not portray an effective ghost antagonist here, and his overall angst and antagonism is convoluted and poorly written. 


Speaking of poorly written, here's our second problem. The antagonist suffers a fate far worse than being a bad character: he is a completely unnecessary character for the show. The show has great (living) characters and a compelling conflict regarding Banri's struggle to form and hold onto relationships after his life-changing injury. Everything is so great about this show, and so complete about the main narrative, that you could literally edit out all the scenes featuring the ghost *and still have a complete story*. You have written an awful antagonist if you can delete all his or her scenes in the show then the show still makes 100% complete sense. Even the scene where ghost-Banri decides to affect the living world with bad weather and other vague uninteresting threats would still make sense as just real-life things that unfortunately happens. The show didn't need a ghost to cause their trip to be rained out, nor did it need the ghost for anything really. 


If you want a story with a better love triangle involving a ghost, watch Natsayuki Rendezvous. Or if you can accept that the antagonist in Golden Time is the product of unforgivably awful writing, you can forgive it and focus on the great and mature drama that Golden Time provides.

I recently watched Golden Time, I honestly didn't know much about it before hand but I fell in love with every thing. It starts with a boy named Banri being late for a college entrance ceremony because he was new to Tokyo. He follows two girls to the college and follows then into a convenient store and bought ice cream to avoids suspicion but they realize he was following and runs off. So he eats his ice cream outside the store but then he realizes a guy next to him also eating ice cream. They both followed those girls and bought ice cream and instantlybecame best friends. Banri has to handle a relationship and friendship while fighting over control of his body with his past self before he fell off a bridge and was hospitalized with amnesia for year forgetting his family and friends. I fell in love with all the main characters and the adventures they did. Overall just watching Golden Time made me smile, laugh, worry about the characters and their relationships way more than usual. Plus this Is the first anime I watched the whole thing subbed. If you need a nice feel good anime with a little drama, nothing is more golden than Golden Time.

I really don't know what to say. I'm freshly after the last episode and I have to say that I didn't expect myself to say what I'm about to say... First of, I always decide what score I would give for the anime whilstbeing in the middle of it. So for example I decided to watch Kill la Kill and I decided to give it a 9/10 while being on episode 12 IF I like the ending. The same thing happened here. I was in the middle of the anime and everything was going pretty well, I liked the story and the romance was pretty.. So I decided that I'll give this anime 9/10 IF the ending will be good/suit me. But something happened. The last... 5? 4? episodes, shook me and I thought I would have to drop the rating to 7-8/10 'cause I didn't like how it was going to end.. But Yuyuko Takemiya (Author of Golden Time) Shook me again in the 2 last episodes, especially the last one and the last seconds of the last one. When the end screen appeared I was left there looking at the screen with a little piece of my heart torn away.. Or at least that's how I feel when I finish a bumpy-ride series, like Clannad or TTGL, those are the anime that, when ended, left m with a little hole in my heart, 'cause I knew it was over, that there won't be anything new out of this world, that I could no longer live inside that world while watching it... And I got the same feeling at the end of Golden Time.. And there it struck me.. The WHOLE reason and meaning of Golden Time (IDK if the things I'm about to say are spoilers or not, so I'll just leave them untagged). I realized that the time that we were given will never rewind, that the past will never return and there it stung me more, 'cause I knew that such a a great anime just ended and now it's in the past just to die with memories... THAT is the meaning of Golden Time.. and because of that I'm going to give it a 10/10, even though many may say that it doesn't deserve that high of a rating, I know what I'm doing and I know how I feel. Too bad that this roller-coster ended...

This anime made me really sad because of two reasons. The way it was executed and the ending. 
The main problem with the execution was the very inconsistent amnesia of Tada Banri which dragged the plot along. The ending to me was expected however not the one I wanted (can't go any further without spoiling). The story is very good and not expected after reading the synopsis. The plot did not have any legitimate plot. It was the dragging of character developments of both Tada Banri and Kaga Koko with little to no emphasis on other characters. The character development was what let this animedown as I quite enjoyed the art and sound (OSTS and OP/ED). \n
The ending was also too expected and left little to no sense of satisfaction for myself. \n
For me, this anime was not as great as expected.

Golden Time is the most fulfilling Slice of Life romance I have ever scene. (Makes me the most happiest).
Let me start this review off with I am pretty bias because I just recently finished watching White Album 2 and for anyone who has seen the show it finished on a very sour note, because of this my review might be off. One thing to note is that Golden Time is a romance that has the couple get together in the beginning of the series rather than the very last episode, so if you are tired of romances that never become a thing (Pet girl atsakura, White Album 2, Nagi no Asukara etc. Golded Time is the show for you. Also Although it isn't listed as a drama by MAL Golden Time has plenty of drama more than shows like pet girl at sakura. Anyways lets start.


The story: 9

Golden Time is a successor of Toradora, because of this both of them have a similar plot and character design. The story starts off with the main heroine moving to a college in Tokyo to chase a childhood friend. However during her time in Tokyo and after a certain event she finds her true love (Tada Banri). However Banri has a secret, the day after his graduation he got into an accident and lost all his memories that he had previously. The story follows Banri and Koko's love life.

Art: 10

I must say the art is really refreshing characters are well drawn and the characters actually look like college students.


Sound: 7 

The sound was alright the Op/Ed's weren't very memorable nor worth listening to and there wasn't any significant soundtrack/osts in the show.


Character: 8

Rather then having a cast of characters with sad back stories like clannad it has a group of normal college kids other then banri, because of this the viewer never gets a look into the others past because its not necessary. This makes the characters realistic but bland depending on your tastes/opinions. 


Enjoyment: 10

This is were i am bias because of the previous show i had seen before watching white album 2. Like i stated earlier White Album 2 ended on a sour note which made me love Golden Time even more because of how satisfying the ending was. However Golden Time romance is nothing to sell short it was a refreshing show to watch and the art was amazing. It also has some very memorable comedy scenes 


Overall I recommend Golden Time to anyone who enjoys the genre. It has a very satisfying ending and is a very pleasant ride.

A complete and marvellous love journey between two very interesting and compelling characters is a rare gem. However, Golden Time easily accomplishes and even more this anime emits a very romantic and honest story. Golden Time has completely changed my perspective in the romance/drama anime genre because this anime has a typical love story but enhances it by making every moment worthwhile. This journey begins with the main character, Tada Banri, entering college which was a very fresh setting as almost every romance anime takes place in high school. But what made my jaw drop and my heart flutter was seeing the main heroine, KagaKouko, in the very first episode. Her beauty, vigour, and simply radiating personality from the moment she entered the story was a sight every anime viewer must experience. Contrary to most typical love stories this one between Banri and Kouko seems very realistic and genuine, as the relationship is not built out of happiness and innocent love, but it is founded from sadness, jealously, commitment, and trust in addition to the positive aspects of love.  I was constantly drawn into understanding what creates a strong and everlasting relationship, and I learned that true love can only be acquired from trust in your partner, but more importantly trust in yourself. Understanding your own goals and desires is the foundation of a strong relationship because it removes uncertainty and allows both individuals to become free from many burdens. 


Kaga Kouko is one of my favourite characters, not solely because of her enchanting appearance, but due to the fact that she portrays a genuine female in a new relationship. The audience simply cannot hold back their sympathy towards her struggle in finding a partner who truly loves her despite her very envious and insecure nature. Throughout the anime we come to understand that her friendly and cheerful attitude is only a façade and that she is far more unstable that she seems to be; however this flaw did not undermine  her character, instead it made her a more lovable and relatable character. Aside from the main heroine, the other characters have also been well developed. The most prevalent supporting character would be Linda, who is Banri’s childhood friend and Kouko’s rival in winning over Banri. Linda is a supportive and caring individual and many of her traits contrast to Kouko’s which adds to both of their development. The competition between Linda and Kouko was very mature throughout the anime and despite being rivals they were able to build their friendship. What surprised me was that I honestly did have difficulty in deciding who I wanted to root for because both Kouko and Linda managed to sway my emotions greatly and for different reasons. 


The animation and music was nothing that stood out as the main focus was character development, however both of these aspects were able to effectively compliment the story and really elevate the tone and mood for many emotion scenes. The animation was definitely smooth and flowing and the soundtracks were limited but were able to make me grow attached to them. 


I gave Golden Time a rating of 8, however this is my rating as an anime critic since this anime was far from being perfect. But this anime was something special as I was able to become attached to the characters and story very easily. Therefore, my enjoyment rating would undoubtedly be a high 9 as I have never before been more enthralled  by a romance anime as I were with Golden Time. 


This anime is something that I will always cherish because it showed me that love is much more difficult in reality, but through perseverance and commitment a strong and lasting bond can be formed.

I started this anime series today and finished it all in one go! I enjoyed it, it was a great emotional roller coaster with both laughter and tears. There are flaws but overall it was a fine show.
Story: While using amnesia as the basis of a story is not new and has potential, the main flaw is the pacing. A lot of things happened way too quickly, and the show as a whole would benefit with more episodes. Due to the pacing, some parts of the story did not make too much sense. Other than that, the story is fantastic. It is certainly cliched, butI did enjoy watching the drama and the interactions between the characters. Like I said in the introduction, it was a great emotional roller coaster. The story drags you in and makes you anticipate for the results. However, the characters are a big part of why the story was really interesting.


Characters: We are presented the great struggle between Tada Banri and his past. Everything started at that point, which resulted in him meeting new friends, Koko, Mitsuo, 2D-kun, Oka, and an important old friend, Linda. Banri struggled against his past, Koko struggled to mature, Linda struggled against guilt, all the problems the characters faced strongly show their development. The characters are easily one of the strongest point of this anime. It is really obvious to see they have major flaws within their characters, but none of the humans are perfect. We strive to improve ourselves, and that is what exactly the characters have tried to do, which is also what makes the story really interesting to watch.


Art/Sound: They were both good enough to compliment the anime. Nothing memorable, but they do not affect anything negatively, which is good enough for me.


Overall: I am glad that I finished the anime. I watched the first episode at my friend's place a few weeks ago, and was somewhat intrigued. While there are definitely flaws with this anime, it was good enough for me to waste an entire evening to finish the anime. There are also morals you can take away from it as well. 8/10

Are you tired and bored of the usual highschool, harem, tsundere female lead, romance anime cliches that always have a similar plot? If so, i would highly recommend Golden Time.  Its a refreshing take on the romance genre thats gone too stale for my taste. Especially since it caters to a more mature crowd with its characters and storytelling. Heres my Breakerdown 
Art: Artwork is amazing, characters design, background, colors are of all top notch production. Everything is very detailed and the art direction is just amazing especially with the romance genre where quality can often vary. I didn't see a dip in qualityand the artwork is consistent throughout the whole run.

10/10


Characters: I always thought the cast was great. This was probably the first time I actually liked the whole cast, sure they had minor annoying moments but nothing to point where i started to question and loathe characters unlike in every romance anime.  Although the mc is "technically" in a love triange, its played out in a way thats interesting and impacts the story in a deeper meaning. The relationships are believable and a joy to watch and nothing really felt forced to further the plot. I  was super estatic that in the main cast, golden time avoided another super annoying cliche with useless annoying characters strictly put in to add idiotic comic relief or even worse further plotlines. Also avoided the dreaded tsundere main love interest, seen in every other romance anime. Sure the female love interest is a yandere which isn't uncommon either but I liked how her relationship played out with the mc and ended up being very moving by its conclusion.  

9/10


Story: What started off as a feeling of deja vu and feeling "crappy where have i seen this before" the story unfolds and differentiates itself quickly .Like mentioned before, Golden Time story caters to more mature viewers with its mature theme and how the story plays out and its a great respite from all the recycled cheese out lately. The story mainly revolves around the mc's romance with kouko, his friendship with the cast, dealing his past and his mental issues( I'll word it this way to avoid spoilers) that begin to unfold in the second half of the story. The story is more on a serious tone for the most part with some light comedic relief here and real heartfelt moments that will test your ability to hold back tears .Golden Time also avoids the all too famous multiple implausible obstacles that come out of nowhere and unrealistic solutions. Ive heard people had issues with the pacing, saying it felt rushed at times. I thought pacing was fine, I honestly believe it woulda just felt bloated the if they implemented anymore into the story.  

9/10


Conlusion: 

Golden time ended up being of favorites in the genre and with all the other factors put into place I have to give a 10/10 overall. Sure there some minor flaws, as you can nitpick in any anime, but I felt they didn't away from the whole experience at all for me. 

So again I highly recommend you give Golden Time at least a try, especially since its rare to have mainly romance show with a more mature story. Especially if your looking for something different and bored of the same old bland romance animes. Give it at least a try to episode 4-5 if possible!!!

Shows like this don't come so often.
It's very common for romcom shows to have a plain story with a main thread that does not evolve the characters in any way. 
It's not the case here. You see very character change in personality, adapting to the new situations as the plot develops.
This show has some problems with pacing and sometimes it gets like mainstream shows when every character second guesses themselves when it comes to their feelings. Fortunately, it seldom happens.
Keeping this short I've enjoyed the relatable characters, a story line that has real impact on them, a plot that even not being new in anyway (because memory loss seems to be a common theme in romcom type) it's very enjoyable to watch and a finale that does not disappoint.

Done with my re-watch of Golden Time and what can I tell you, it did not disappoint.
******The following review may contain heavy spoilers******
~Story 9/10
The story had a great concept in my opinion. Not your traditional highschool boy falls in love with high school girl and some forced drama thrown around. It showed me a real view of how love is from the beginning. Not gonna go too deep into the starting and just gonna address my few concerns with the story. In my opinion, I did not see how it was possible for Linda to hug the ghost Banri towards the end. Moreover, it didn'tmake sense at all for the ghost Banri to pick up the ring. However all flaws aside, the story was an emotional rollercoaster and not gonna lie, made me cry and grin like an idiot towards the end.


~Characters 9/10

The show had a great cast. The protagonist Tada Banri showed me what mental illnesses are all about and how fucked up they can make a person. Moreover he gave a realistic view on those struggles on mental illness. The main love interest Kaga Kouko is definitely one of my favorite characters. She gives such a realistic view on what love is all about. It's not just blushing at the slightest touch, it's pain, happiness, stalking(had to include that lmao) and being there for your partner through thick and thin. Unlike shoujo manga love interests, her love seemed far more real. I didn't particularly dislike any of the supporting characters, however I really liked 2D kun and Nana-senpai. Best wingman and best neighbor titles go to them, no competition.


~Soundtrack 10/10

Loved it. Absolutely amazing, especially both the OPs. The EDs were also spectacular along with the BGM matching every scene perfectly


~Enjoyment 10/10

Ok so I'm not saying that the story is perfect if you look at it critically, however Golden Time is one of the realest romance anime I have seen. It portrays the struggles and happiness of love way too perfectly. Moreover, the romance is cute af and wants to make you squeal(not ashamed). Also the pain and suffering a mentally ill patient has to go through is described, and honestly it made me realize how serious amnesia is. Overall loved the anime and definitely worth bumping it's rating from 8 to 10.

This is like Toradora to me:
Toradora opened the world of romcom anime, Golden Time changed the world of romcom.
Tis was amazing finished it in two days and then fealed sad inside. Bigger part of the anime is cheery and fun, but last few episodes were heart braking. I felt deppresed from episode 21 to 24 end, then i felt better....
This was awesome, i dont know why i didnt check this earlier, it was on my plan to watch for months.
And im not sad that theres no season 2 couse it ended with a true ending, so dont need more, ill rather rewatch this, then seehow one of my favorite anime become bad.\n
Overall score: 10/10\n
(Sorry if my grammar is bad)

I honestly liked this anime up to the first 12 or so episodes, it was really intriguing but it seemed like it was taking forever to get to the point of the whole amnesia, it eventually picks up but stretches it for numerous episodes, I enjoyed this anime at the beginning and the end, the middle almost made me give up on this series. The characters were often over dramatic but realizing that I've seen these kinds of reactions from real life experiences it was insanely accurate, however, I do feel the Yana and Linda relationship was a little forced but thats just my opinion.The story was pretty on point, and pretty well thought out, I'd say this is definitely up there with one of the better romances I've seen but it's just missing something, Koko's love towards Tada seems kinda fake, I don't know what it is but for some reason it just doesn't seem as genuine as Lindas. I did root for Koko and Tada however and was happy there was resolve between Linda and Tada but not happy how rushed it was, she sees a ghost of Tada and confesses her love to him and the college Tada just kinda watches, ignores and goes to Koko. I felt it would have been better if there was more time in between each "confession." Overall I rate this an 8/10, not a 10/10 because I was unhappy with Koko and Tada's relationship progress, (lol) and I also didn't like how Chinami and Yana's relationship was never resolved, it was just sort of ignored. Another thing I didn't like was how Tada was such a little b*tch lmao. I did think this was a great romance however, honestly up there on the best ones. I'd definitely recommend it.

Golden Time is very unknown to the mass of anime viewers. Despite being under the surface of all these mainstream and fantastic anime, Golden Time offers its own, beautiful but yet, heartbreaking story. One that will leave you satisfied with how they executed it and if you're like me pleased to see some closure regarding relationships.
Storyline; 9
Golden Time's storyline is unique compared to the large number of anime I've watched thus far. It features a painful love story that will definitely make you feel a time or two. You'll find yourself frustrated with character decisions, sitting at the edge of your seat during the heatof drama, heartbroken during sad moments and fist pumping whenever something turns out okay! Maybe that last part is only me but, there are many elements intertwined within Golden Time and you won't feel cheated if you think this show only features a lovey-dovey story. Ultimately it will have a more relatable (excluding the main characters conflict) feeling to it.


Art/Animation Style; 8 


Golden Time is not you're 2015 Fate Stay Night animation but for its time, I found it quite appealing. You'll find this is easy to follow and in my opinion the artists behind this fantastic work did a job well done.


Sound; 8


If you're more with the feel-type music than Golden Time will do a fine job of satisfying that for you. Not only are the two openings well done in both animation and music but the OST Soundtrack has a nice few songs that you can sit down to and enjoy. I personally recommend listening to a few if that's you're taste. Overall the sound work done within the show was well done and fit key scene's when it needed too. 


Character; 9


Although none of the characters from Golden Time are in my top ten, I definitely had to consider putting Koko, the main female protagonist, into my top ten. You'll find each of the characters develop at their own rates and reach some kind of conclusion that will leave you at least fine with the fact they had some sort of epiphany.

Banri is the most dynamic character within Golden Time and you'll find following his story quite a rough one, with a lot of ups and downs, eventually you'll reach that critical breaking point and just pity him. His life is a harsh one but that's what will make following his journey a great one.

Koko is probably the second most changing character and the most annoying starting out. Her personality throughout the show may leave a bad taste in your mouth initially but seeing her change was one of my favorite aspects of this show. The pain and happiness she goes through, it's easy to follow and connectable. You may even cry at a point or two.

Banri and Koko are the two most main characters but there are a few "main" supporting characters that you'll be introduced to and each of them have their role/meaning to furthering the story along and you'll be pleased to see there are little to no fillers within this show. 


Enjoyment; 10


All in all, I loved Golden Time and I definitely recommend it to anyone searching for a new romance/drama. Though it may not be Clannad sad or Nisekoi silly, it has it's perks and you'll definitely find a new connection with this show. 


In the end, I give Golden Time a 9/10 for the job well done in making a dramatic romance anime that was well executed and easy to follow. You'll never find a dull moment watching something so enticing!

"That man is having sexual relations with a bird." -Koko Kaga, Episode 13
This show, this fucking show. Never have I cussed so many times at a show as I have for this one. Ok, let's begin.
This show likes to be different. If you expect something predictable to happen, there's a good chance you'll have guessed wrong. This keeps the story alive, but it comes back to bite you within time (hence the aforementioned cussing).
A lot of the humour is subtle, yet quite delightful.
The final episodes were surprising (well, not so much the last episode). It reminded me of the endings of Scorcese films like "Goodfellas","Casino", and "Wolf Of Wall Street", which is something I wouldn't expect of an anime.\n\n
Now for my honest opinion:\n
I liked how things were going up until ghost Banri showed up and started being a major asshole. Seriously fuck him. I really, really liked this show. Before all of the stressful shit began, I would've given this a 10/10. Unfortunately, nothing is perfect it seems..\n\n
Oh, and as I said in my last review, the art and sound was nice, but what's really the point of watching a show just for that?\n\n
(This is my second review, don't sue me)

Golden Time! A story of how romance can take it's twists and turns of events.
