At first, Golden Time came across as a stereotypical romantic anime. It had everything lined up for it. The wishful boy, the exciting girl, another girl to add conflict or be the true love, and a host of friends that added comedic relief and was a reminder of the single life. But once the ball started rolling, It turned into an anime that is both memorable and heart warming (i cried). 
Really, the worst thing about this anime is the sound and art. Sound wise, it does nothing special. In fact, it's kinda boring. Whenever a scene comes on, you will hear the slight tuneof whatever attitude is portrayed and nothing else. There just doesn't seem to be much effort put into the musical background of the series. Although, I will admit to getting the cheery, high pitched intros stuck in my head. Graphically the show suffers in a similar fashion. It isn't meant to be groundbreaking or necessarily impressive, but is meant to just be the means by which the story is told. The characters were well made and showed a very wide array of emotions, but nothing we haven't seen before. 


The absolute and definitive strengths of the series is in the characters and story. Plot wise, the story follows Tada Banri. He has moved to Tokyo to attend college but has a past that haunts him through his time there. Being struck with amnesia just a year and a half ago, he redefines himself and even grabs a girlfriend (whom i will not name due to spoilers). The rest of the story centers around his development with her and his friends. The key here is that the story doesn't just continue, but all the characters actively grow throughout the series. Each character becomes more refined and unique. They begin to understand one another and eventually become extremely open with each other when it comes to these struggles (even though at times it was hard). This active growth kept me fascinated to see what would happen next. The other great feat that the series possesses is in the active group. All the characters seem average and almost boring in a way in the beginning. They possessed nothing that wouldn't be found elsewhere and yet they blossom into wonderful people. Tada and his girlfriend became a fixed point throughout the series to see this movement. Tada himself struggles internally. He battles with his past and this in turn creates insecurities. It makes him doubt who he really is and yet he always finds comfort in his friends. Each character is given an an episode or so to expand on this development, but most of the time it happens subtly as the conflict deepens and the story takes twists and turns in ways that might give a surprise.  


the series touched me in a very personal way. At times it made me laugh, smile, cry, but more so it felt like i was experiencing life along side these people. The level of immersion and personality far exceeded my expectations. If you're a fan of romantic series, try this one out. Key here is to be patient, let everything be introduced, and see how the whole group develops.

Okay, so this is my 4th time watching this series and I thought of making a review. Please be easy on me, this is my 1st time writing a review.
So lets get started.
Story: This show is about a college dude named Tada Banri. He is new to Tokyo and studies in college as a 1st year student. He met a guy named Yana Mitsuo when heading to college. He met this girl named Kaga Koko who is Yana Mitsuo's childhood friend and fell in love with her at first sight. The stories develop as they both are strangers at first and becomes lovey-dovey when thestory progresses but that is not all there is hardships between their romance and their circle of friends. 9/10


Art: Perfect. Nothing much to say on this cause' its pretty damn good.


Sound: The music will sometimes trigger your emotions depending on the scene. Sometimes if it hits a little close to home, your heart might feel that its going to be ripped apart (I'm just exaggerating) but yeah, you might actually cry towards the end if you are a sucker for romantic comedy. 9/10


Character: Very well rounded characters. Tada Banri is a simple guy with simple needs. While Yana Mitsuo is a guy that is sick and tired of his childhood friend. 2D-kun is an Otaku HAHAHA 😂👌. Oka Chinami is a bit of a complicated character because she is not honest with her feelings but is a good friend as a whole. Linda is someone that likes to keep secrets to herself but is a good friend to Banri and the others. Last but not least Kaga Koko, she is a clingy girl that is romantic and is loyal to her boyfriend, but can be quite overly attached as a girlfriend.


Enjoyment: I loved every single bit of it. Not even joking about this one.


Overall: I give it Kaga Koko/10. And yes I really like this show as a whole. It is one hell of a ride, it has ups and downs and drama with a pinch of feels. ♥♥♥

Well to start with, this is only my second review, so don't get salty with me... Well... let's begin!
Story:
Well lets kick things off with the story. I won't just copy and paste the normal summary, so just check that out for yourself above. The story, though not completely original, was something pretty different and not your usual high school story. This is not a bad thing at all. I like to consider myself pretty well versed in these types of animes (Rom/Drama or Rom Coms, etc) and this anime was definitely something that fit the bill. Amnesia, a big part of the show for ourmain character Tada Banri, can definitely make or break the story, depending on how they play it out, and I say they did a good job, I don't want to say too much without adding in any spoils, so I'll leave it at that. Another thing I noticed was how real this anime seems compared to everything else. What I mean by this, is that it is the most realistic story or one of the most realistic stories I've watched. You'll understand what I mean if you watch it.


Art:

The art was definitely not something that stuck out too much for me, partially due to subtitles lol, but it definitely was not a weakness of the show. If I'd allow myself to be biased, I'd rate the art much higher, since I'm just in love with the style of art. I don't have too much else to say, so I'll just move on.


Sound:

The only negative thing I have to say about this show is that although the OP and and Ending Songs were great as a separate thing, I found myself thinking about how inappropriate they were so happy during the more dramatic scenes, but maybe it's just something I'm thinking about and no one else really minds.


Character: 

One of my favorite things about the show. Some might be saying that some characters are generic, but we are at the point most characters used are generic, but the characters make up a pretty strong cast. Agree or disagree, but I believe that the most of the main cast had actually made a strong development, which is something most shows lack. There characters are very likeable, but thinking back, some people might find some of them annoying.


Enjoyment:

Well even though some of my review was sort of negative, the negatives really were outweighed by the positives. It really hurt me to have to think of all of those, since I truly loved this anime. The anime was actually very different to what I thought I was going into and that wasn't a bad thing, I was under the impression, just due to the description and pictures, that it would just be a Rom Com with a horrible ending, but when I started to watch it, I real realized that it was completely different from that. It started as something I'd maybe watch in the background while I was doing other things, but as the showing progressed, I found myself to become immersed into the drama of the show. One thing that almost made me drop my enjoyment rating was the times they tried adding in comedy to help relieve the serious moment, which I felt were a bit misplaced, but at the same time, I felt like they were great to have for a quick breather, since anything that tries to be serious all the time usually ends up to be garbage.


Overall:

Well if you couldn't tell from my enjoyment, I seriously loved this anime, making it a serious contender to be one of my favorite animes, check out my list if you have the time, and you'll understand how tough it is for me to decide, since most of my anime is in the same categories and such. SO pick up this anime :D

When it comes to anime me and the romance genre don't really get along most of the time. This is mostly due to the fact that most romantic anime's take a cardboard cutout of your stereotypical anime chick and pair her up with some loser so she can either be pure as fucking snow and spend 95% of the show building up to her first kiss with him or whatever or fawns all over him like he is the greatest thing to ever happen to her life. Not the case with Golden Time. 
Everything just feels so natural, the realism of the show and thecharacters is what really sells it to me as being amazing. I've never had a romance show/movie (anime or not) make me relive so many of my past relationships. The human emotion put into each character helps me to connect to the show and keeps me glued to the screen for a good 20 or so episodes. 


The animation and soundtrack are both pretty dope, changing the mood of the show on the drop of a dime while staying consistent in every episode. The story on the other hand seems pretty basic; sure it gives the romance a way to take the foreground but doesn't add anything to the characters relationships it's more or less two collage students falling in love and the dude has amnesia, sure it's not an awful story or anything but I feel like it is the bare minimum requirement for a romance show. 


The only annoying issues I had with Golden Time overall ended up being the slow first few episodes and how forced the ending felt compared to how natural the rest of Golden Time was. Overall Golden Time is simply a great anime that went way beyond any expectations I had set for it.

From my experience watching various slice of life anime, I've noticed a pattern. Usually, the more ambitious shows that try to be more than just a cute story end up falling flat. Rarely can a show successfully retain the universal appeal of a romance while adding more complex undertones, be it supernatural, fantastical, or otherwise. Golden Time manages to be a very appealing story accented with some legitimately interesting psychological intrigue that allows it to stand out from the crowd in a very congested genre. 
The real focal point of this particular anime, however, is its cast of characters. None of the aspects I previouslypraised would work in the slightest if they didn't have a likable and surprisingly fleshed out group of main characters to carry the show. Slice of life is a genre that often falls victim to tired characters with vague motivations and little unique personality aside from previously established tropes, but almost all of the characters here are well thought out and very truly human, making the show as a whole a joy to get invested in. \n\n
There were a few blemishes that prevented it from really becoming one of my absolute favorites (it was a little bloated and some conflicts felt slightly forced), but overall it was a supremely enjoyable experience that I would recommend to almost anyone. The characters were believable and interacted pretty naturally with one another, the story (while a little slow to get moving) was totally captivating once the psychological aspect came more into focus, and it didn't lose the core intrigue of a heartwarming romance with its ambition.

Golden Time, an outstanding series that stood out at so much aspects it shocked me. It is the first anime that I found so questionable in how characters acted. The amount of questionable behavior/reactions are so colossal I'm having a hard time to recall 1 of them.
Story. 6/10
The story of an amnesia boy and his love triangle is meh, not that catchy to me. It could be good but the execution is bad, so it is bad. However the college theme, instead of your usual highschool theme has it own charm.
Art. 10/10
10/10 maybe a bit too much but I really like how diverse the characters'arts are. The number of characters with special art are a lot, unlike others anime where most characters besides the main cast are described with your non important generic NPC art. I also like how main characters, especially main girl Kouko have so much changes of clothes and hairstyle.\n\n
Sound. 8/10\n
Upper average, with a bit catchy OP and ED. nothing more\n\n
Characters. 7/10\n
Completely bland MC, all the cast have questionable actions and characteristics. The only character that is a bit interesting and has consistent characteristic is Nana.\n\n
Enjoyment. 7/10\n
This anime as so so so so so many moments of "comedy" that I had to ask myself Is this where I should laugh? This is definitely an outstanding aspect of Golden Time. For example *spoiler* In ep 16, when Banri was comforting Kouko, her dad walked in. and then the three of them acted like monkeys instead of pulling out usual comedy gag. It is really really questionable and cringeworthy. For an "comedy" anime, the only gag i found funny was the air yakisoba one, and that is not even too funny to boot. \n\n
Overall. 7/10\n
This anime with the college theme has so much potential, but all of them wasted by nonsensical actions/behaviors of the casts. It is both better and worse than most other romcoms, but the worse parts overshadow the better parts.

I got interested on the show due to good critics, principally. It didn't seem the we-all-know-what-will-happen-next shoujo. So my expectations on it were big.
It is true that it is not the typical shoujo. We have characters which are University students, they have different realities, and the accident Banri had made the show interesting from the very beginning.
Maybe I was expecting too much from it, so there were certain things that dissapointed me. Some "resolutions" didn't convinced me at all.
If I list those things I liked, I would say, in first place, Nana-senpai. Yes, that tribute to Nana was one of the things that made mefond of the anime. And I was very surprised she was a recurrent character and important in some point of the story. The animation is pretty good, I liked the characters design very much as well. Koko's outfits were gorgeous... it made me wondered if I would ever be as femenine as her. Overall, it is an entertaining story that anyone who can put up with romances would want to watch it until the end.\n\n
Now, if you are just reading the review and haven't watched the anime yet, I would recommend not to read the following. They are not huge spoilers but it is necessary to highlight certain points of the story to note why some things were not resolved they way I would have liked to. I do not usually spoil. I try to be cautious on that. But I think this time was necessary in order to explain some facts...\n
On the first place, Koko's attitude and changes of love interest. How can it be a woman who has always been in love with one man forgets him in just one day and falls in love with another one, just like that?! I do not say it is not possible. I think that it is a process that should have taken a little bit more time. I haven't gone to the manga, so I don't know if there it is the same. But I don't think that is the way to narrate a love or romance situation. What about those many years of feelings? It must be Koko was being selfish and didn't really love Mitsuo as she said.\n
What I really like and was very good developed was her change of attitude towards people. That was way better shown. How she could open herself and make friends, beside her love interest. Anyways, she didn't stop being too childish...\n
Now about Banri. I didn't like this MC. I mean, I felt sorry for his situation and suffering but his "old side" was absolutely selfish. He was often very rude. I didn't like his love confession to Koko too. It was too sudden as well! When was the time you fell for her? Was that a love confession? I personally believe that was terrible for a romance anime.\n\n
To resume, Golden Time is a good anime. Is a nice show with a refreshing new and original story. I would totally recommend it to someone who wants a different kind of romance (or at least one that changes school for uni). It is not a mature shoujo, as you will find in animes like Nana, but will absolutely catch your attention.\n
It has a background story and it makes the series much more interesting.

The real ending of GOLDEN TIME. (My version.)
It's a real pain to see al those hate comments on this anime. We all know it's "worse" than Toradora. Actually, I don't agree to it. Let me explain:
Golden Time is a very psychological anime. You really have to eatch the full serie a second time for the little details you missed in the beginning.
This anime plays alot on showing the characters not on telling what's really happening. And yes, a con of this anime is that it isn't expressed well enough to understand it in the first run.
And here comes the spoilers. (How can I otherwise explain?..)
Kokoseems a dominant girl, and she expresses it well, but I've seen a lot of anime reviewers saying that her personality is bad developed and to dramatic. Yes at first you'll think that. But if you look deeper, you'll find a Koko that's scared of the future with Banri. She explains it rather poorly in the episode after the car crash, but I guess that was intended to be. 


Also in ep 22, in the end she runs away from Banri saying that she only was there for her first love. Here you would think she only used Banri.

But that's far from true. Because she is struggling with herself, she again, poorly explains what she feels. What she actually feels is that she first was there for her first love. But she met Banri and got in love with him, but, because of his accident, she is unsure of they can stay together and that's why she says it, she didn"t want to hurt Banri, and took distance from him to also protect herself for the pain.


Well, she says again something stupid at the school. (Ep 23 I guess, not sure.) And she ends her relationshio with Banri. But she can't really explain it and that's why it is recieved as if she was again, using Banri.


Further going to the final scènes of ep 24.

Koko shows up in front of Banri, giving him his mirror from back in the first few episodes.

But when Banri realises everything, and runs after Koko, this is where the biggest misconception is.


That moment on the bridge isn't real. It's in Banri's mind. Were the memories of the old Banri collide with the memories of the new Banri.

It happend when Banri was still running towards Koko, because he realised everything, both memories melted into one. Where the personality of the new Banri is remained.


When Linda appears, then we change to Linda's mind. She is finally accepting that she'll never see the old Banri again and that's why she says yes. 'Yes' from: I accepted it, yes you can go.


Then Banri and Koko give each other a hug and the rest is what you'll all know.


This is only my version. It can be diffrent depending on how you think it is.

Going to keep it short and to the point. I heard many good things about this anime from various sources whom I thought I shared the same tastes in anime so I decided to give it a try. I'm not going to sugarcoat the experience at all.
Story - 6. Not much to it. Felt somewhat rushed at certain points but the pace is bearable. Had quite a bit of potential but fell short in the execution.
Art - 6. Nothing special about it and nothing particularly bad. Standard.
Sound - 8. Probably the strongest point in the anime since I didn't pay much attention to it.
Characters -1. Who knew it was possible to dislike a fictional character this much? Tada Banri - King of the Simps. I genuinely liked every other character but the hatred I harbour for Banri overwhelms it entirely. Nothing more to be said on the matter or I might have a stroke.\n\n
Enjoyment - 1. I was looking forward to seeing how the show would play out. Enjoyed the first couple minutes but, again, guess who ruined the fun\n\n
Overall - 5. I don't think it'd be fair to rate the show as a whole so lowly because of one character when it done many things perfectly. The plot, although basic, kept you guessing at times which is quite rare in this genre of anime. However if you dislike simps and 'nice guys', distance your self from Golden Time or you'll end up writing your first ever review, trashing a show unfairly.

This series expresses love in the more mature sense to me. Not the highschooler type of love but that type of love a person experiences after highschool when they have a better understanding of what kind of person they are and more open about their feeling. People tie this series closely to Toradora which was one of my favorite series for a long time (was my #3) but this series replaced it and was better in many ways to me.
Pros- 
realistic and mature characters.
Great plot that covers many love related topics
Has many funny moments
Is emotionally relatable (to a certain age group I'm sure)
Cons-
Fast pace for24 episodes\n\n
The topic of love is what really made me love this series. Since I can't give spoilers I'll have to be vague about which specific topics of love I really enjoyed about this series. The topic of getting over past feelings was mentioned and, from my own experiences, this series got the emotion, reactions, and behavior of that feeling down absolutely perfect (from the perspective of someone who is out of highschool).They also brought up one-sided type of love and this too was portrayed perfectly in many aspects. The topic of getting rejected and dealing with the person mutually was also done very well. Based off of my personal experiences in life and them being very similar (some almost exact) to the characters situations in the story, I can say that the way the characters felt with situations and acted was realistic to the point that I loved this series by the 6th episode and by the end it had topped all expectations and over the fast pace story that I though was an issue.\n\n
Now what makes this story so great and unique is that it portrays love in a more mature sense. The characters are in college and thus act like college students for the most part. What does this mean? Well simply put they're honest with their feeling and don't hesistate like in many characters in high school series do in many cases. Me being a college student myself, I related to each of them on different levels. When you get to a certain age love isnt as hard to talk about or express. The characters in this series show this at what i felt was a very realistic way. They speak how they feel at times but still being young try to cover them up at times too. each character is also unique in their own way. Yes Koko may remind you of an obsessive character (not going to name any) she doesn't go extreme like many in other animes have. She knowns her limits and is well aware of herself which made her a very unique character to me. The other characters too like Tada and Linda are also very well created and thought out to the point they don't fit most molds and are quite realistic.  The characters in this series truly are the strong point that make it so great.\n\n
The plot of the story is also very good. It revolves around Tara Banri and Kaga Kouko along with all their other friends and the topic of love and social interaction in general. I'll admit, the story does move pretty quickly and for even 24 episode it felt like it was going at a very fast pace. While this is true, paying attention to what is happening and how it is affecting the characters you can see that the pace fits them and their situation quite well. One thing that I really loved about the series was how it could transition from a serious topic to every laughing and joking very well without it feeling out of place or akward.\n\n
The art style was very good and it fit the mood of the story very well all the time. The music also was well thought out. In most cases I skip opening and closing but with this series the second opening and closing put me in the right mood to watch.\n\n
Overall, this series became on of my favorites because of the characters. They are very relatable in how they treated their emotions and how they were as people. They changed over the story and in many good ways. That's what I loved about it. So if you're interested in seeing love outside of the highschool type where it's akward, people are embarrassed to admit it and confrontations are very hesitant for both sides, and instead want to watch something that shows slightly more mature love, I would highly recommend this.

The story consists of 6 characters with Tada Banri and Kaga Kouko having the biggest roles.  The story is like any run of the mill romantic comedy, being written by the same person who wrote Toradora.  Golden Time tries to have drama in a way that takes away from the story.  While the drama can put people off, I believe the romance and comedy more than make up for it. The characters do have a good amount of depth that makes you sympathize with them...mostly.  There are times you will find yourself questioning their actions, finding them irrational.  One ofthe big things that makes this show different from most romantic comedies is that all the characters are of college age.  There is also the fact that that this adaptation follows the light novel faithfully and it even ends at the same point as the light novel, giving a definite ending.  While there are better romantic comedies out there, this is one that deserves the three episode rule.

This anime made me cry so hard. I don't always give 10 out of 10 to an anime but this one deserved it. It has an interesting and logical story, it drags you to itself with its story, art and characters. Characters have different personalities too and they are all sincere. The part that makes you cry starts after the 12th episode, but I cried before that too. I hadn't watched any dramatical anime but this at that time, maybe this was the reason why it made me cry. When I finished it, I was confused, I didn't understand the last scene clearly but myperspective to drama animes has changed.

Golden Time. As the title implies, watching it really is golden time. Its just amazing that I can't really describe it with words. Each and every episode will leave you something like "Oh my gosh! What's gonna happen next?" and "I'm gonna watch it cause I can't help it." feel to it(or at least that is what I felt). What I like in this show is how the story goes. Its very interesting that it will make you watch further and further. The characters are also well-developed and the comedic act is well-played. I also liked the soundtrack of this show especially Golden Time whichis sang by Yui Horie(yeah one of my favorite seiyuus). The art is also pretty great. All in all, I'd say its one of the greatest shows that I watched. I highly recommend it especially to persons who are at the peak of their youth. :D

Well, Its a Golden Time to review this anime, soo here is my review on it !
First point that i want to review is the plot. To be honest the plot is not that
good, the ending is good but all other unimportant plot point that lead to that ending is very long and kinda boring. I actually kinda surprise in the first few episodes, the plot really advance very quickly, within 6 episodes the main character already have a girlfriend which usually take about 24 episodes or more to get to that point in your typical romantic comedy anime. But after that point, the plotis just kinda stop there for about 12 episodes before actually advancing again. I get it some of it is kinda important to the character development but there usually nothing going on except all that lovey dovey moment between two lovers. If they make it like maybe 12 episodes, it could be much better anime. For example there is a totally unneeded beach episode and cult episode that really didn't do anything to the main plot except maybe the last 3 minutes in each of that episodes that actually advance the plot in any way. Why would they make 23 minutes of unimportant episodes if what you need is just 3 minutes of that to advance the plot and the character development, i have no idea.


But, although the plot is kinda boring and meh, except the ending maybe. 

The character development is very realistic and progressive. Nearly every 

character that they introduced us have some realistic personality that i 

personally like. The main character for example, Tada Banri. He deal with all his problem in a very human like way. Unlike your typical romantic comedy anime where the main character is a dumb and absolute loser, Tada Banri is brave and smart and that's his main personality. Of course he stressed out and sometimes run away from his problem, but that is just what makes him human, his problem is not small and he deals with it realistically. Other characters is the same too, they all have problem that they have to deal with. Hell, some of them doesn't even solve their problem and just cry and hoping that their problem will go away by itself, just like some of us would do. Soo, the main attraction that makes me like this anime its the very realistic character development that they give me.


The comedy in this anime is not the best out there, but its not the worse either. Like there's a scene where the main character is about to have a romantic intercourse with his lover, and she suddenly want to throw up because she eat too much. Or when Koko is scared by some dude pretending to be a Yakuza member and she just pretends that she is possesed by some ghost and do a funny version scene from exorcism to scare the dude. The comedy gives me a giggle, rarely a full laugh out loud but its nice subtle touch from the comedy aspect, nothing too ecchi or disgusting that turns me off. Just a funny innocent giggle, from the comedy that Golden Time gives me.


Now, the animation !! Nothing to really comment on this because the visual is pretty mediocre, its not bad, but its really far from being good. What i like 

about the animation is that the character in this anime change their clothes alot. Like everyday you seen Kaga Koko or the other characters with a completely different clothes, but thats about it really. They try to make Tada banri hometown beautiful, but to my eyes it's just mediocre.


The conclusion is, Golden Time is not the best anime out there and its certainly aren't the worse either. If you can stand the long and useless episodes that fill half of the total episodes that you will watched, you would find a gorgeous and very lifelike character development that you can easily relate to, plus some jokes to keep you entertained.


9.0/10 Great ! :3

A story can have strong foundations but without the proper pillars to support the actual structure, the story will only be just the foundation.
First off, I would like to say that the synopsis on MAL (as of this writing) for this anime is absolutely not reflective of Golden Time. In fact, it only details what happens in episode 1 and does not hint at the challenges that the main character, Banri, will go through. Also, Golden Time elicited very strong feelings and opinions in me so there may be light spoilers that I may not catch but I'll try to flag as many as Ican.


Golden Time is a highly touted anime that deals with a sensitive issue: mental illness. Banri claims that he is experiencing amnesia but as the audience, it is pretty clear to us that when he has his episodes of mental breakdown, he is switching personality. Although Banri's mental condition is supposed to be central to the story, the drama that occurs around him seems to sweep this issue under the rug. Had it not been for a few annoying characters, Golden Time could have explored this issue in a much more profound and mature fashion.


The story begins with our main character, Banri, arriving for his first day in Law School at a university in Tokyo. He meets a guy named Mitsuo who is a fellow classmate and shortly after, Banri witnesses Mitsuo getting beaten up by his super attractive girlfriend Koko. In a few episodes later, he meets a few other people who will be his good friends, including the VIP Linda. As Banri spends more time with Koko, he realizes that he has feelings for her. The true premise of the story is set when Banri realizes that he has amnesia and lost all his memories of his past self, that is, memories of his high school life. From here on, the story explores how Banri attempts to reconcile with his past while accepting the present. As he goes on this journey, there are many misunderstandings, apologies, and heartbreaks. While I find this story very intriguing, I did not appreciate how the writers sometimes made sharp turns with the story progression. What I mean is that the story jumps from point to point and expects us to follow along rather than guiding us from one point to the next. In a way, however, you can argue that it is reflective of the mental breakdowns that Banri has, especially nearing the end of the anime.

One final aspect that I did not particularly enjoy about Golden Time was that the anime starts off at warp speed but when it reaches the middle of the show, the story seems to have escaped from hyperspace and slows down to a crawl. By the end, the writers realize that they slowed the show too much and take it back into hyperspace until the end. Other than those things, I liked how the anime mixes in some nice and light comedy scenes to alleviate what sometimes may be a very dark and emotional scene. 


Regarding the ending, I felt it provided enough closure (of course, it may depend on which character you're rooting for) that I do not see a need for a second season. I definitely feel that the final few episodes is a highlight of Golden Time because it seemed that the writers finally realized that they had to reign in the childish behaviours of the characters and have the characters grow as adults. It is in these episodes that I felt I could see Golden Time as a mature show.



The cast of Golden Time is a mixed bag. You can either find these characters very complex or very shallow. However, one thing for sure is that Banri is a complex character. Because he has amnesia, we experience his emotional moments where he recalls his past and attempts to struggle with his identity. If not for the awkward pacing of the story, I felt his on-screen moments were the "golden times" of this anime as they were the most mature scenes. As for our other main star, Koko, I felt she can be very annoying. She has an especially possessive personality and cannot seem to understand that her partner needs some breathing room at times. Although she does not readily admit it, she has trouble being in a relationship in general. At times, this is what makes me very infuriated with her character is that she can't seem to recognize the issues that Banri goes through. In other words, she recognizes that Banri has issues but she doesn't know how to deal with them, making her the least suitable partner for Banri. The interactions between Banri and Koko do not convince me that they can be a couple. 

One final aspect of the characters that I am unable to understand is that the romance amongst the characters seem to be more like infatuation. What I mean is that without any story development between the two characters, out of the blue, the writers have the characters confess. Confessions like that do not leave me rooting for the character nor understanding why the character did that.





---POSSIBLE LIGHT SPOILER HERE ----


For example, while we do see eventually character development between Banri and Koko, their confession for each other is very early in the anime and its done with very little story development to help us understand why they feel that way. Similarly, Mitsuo seems to take on a liking to Chinami at the Film Club social for no apparent reason other than to break apart from Koko.


---END LIGHT SPOILER---





To talk about Linda is to talk about the most important character in Golden Time. To put it shortly and spoiler free, I wish that they could have more scenes of Banri with Linda. Since I have strong feelings about Linda, I will leave those feelings at the end of this review.


The artwork of Golden Time is drawn by the same artists who brought you Toradora. If you liked their style, you will definitely find the character designs very appealing. Golden Time runs on a very vibrant color palette but in the more emotional scenes, they tune the colours just right to convey the mood. 


The music was good but not outstanding. The first opening and ending theme songs were very catchy and I absolutely loved it. However, the second opening felt like an entire mess but the second half of the anime is pretty much a mess (though that does not mean the second half was terrible, only that the drama got really messy). 


I'm not sure if I enjoyed the anime. The anime definitely elicited very strong inner emotions, with the results almost having my laptop thrown 2 stories down or the screen broken in two. Probably a reason was because I was heavily invested in one ship and seeing the other ship set sail in relatively calm waters while my ship had to endure endless and unexplained hurricanes really got me hating the show. However, this DOES NOT mean that Golden Time is a terrible show. Only the best stories and the top shows can generate strong emotions. 


My final verdict: you don't need to watch this show immediately. Take your time to get through the shows you really want to watch and then watch Golden Time.


Let me know what you thought of Golden Time! I would love to hear your views on this anime!!



(here begins the Linda spoiler so do not read if you haven't watched the anime yet)





---BEGIN LINDA SPOILER----


Now, I admit that I shipped Linda x Banri as soon as Banri realized what Linda meant to him so I might be pretty biased towards Linda. Nevertheless, I believe Linda is supposed to be the female lead to Golden Time. In fact, she is the most tragic character in the entire cast. Although having developed a relationship with Banri, Linda is capable of putting a straight face when she sees him at the activities fair. This is a scene that shows how much Linda cares for Banri. She is caring enough to realize that Banri needs time to recollect his memory so she puts her feelings second behind his. Even then, when Banri begins to date Koko, she still acts like he's her best friend although as the audience, we know how much she is struggling to deny that he is in love with Koko. If that is not enough, when Banri has his amnesia episodes, it is Linda who first goes to his aid. She does that even though she knows that Banri probably will not see her in the same light as he does for Koko. 


One of the best scenes in the entire anime was when Banri asks Linda to forget about their past for the sake of the selfish Koko and Linda, without hesitation, tears up Banri's only photo of him and her and casts it to the wind. This laptop of mine was about to be flung out the window when I watched that scene. To me, this was a very emotional scene because it shows Linda betraying her own feelings for the sake of seeing Banri live a normal and happy life. This was a great opportunity for her to cling to the past and deny the present, but she wishes to have Banri's happiness to supersede her own. What a beautiful yet tragic scene.


Even until the end, Linda cannot escape her tragedy. At the end, Banri recovers his old memories and recalls how much he loved Linda. When Linda comes home for the holidays, she willingly stays at Banri's side to help him ease into this phase of his condition. Unfortunately, after a visit from Koko, the old Banri regains the new Banri's memories and realizes that he actually loves Koko. As he chases after Koko, Linda throws his running shoes to help him catch up to Koko. It is heartwarming to see Banri reunite with Koko and with Linda enthusiastically cheering him on, but you can't help but feel sad for Linda as she is throwing her own feelings away. Furthermore, the only true moment where Linda expresses her true feelings for Banri is when she jumps into the old Banri's arms on the bridge and tells the old Banri "Yes!" (My hands flew up with excitement during that scene) Even then, she is confessing only to have the old Banri feel some sort of closure. She can never physically love the flesh and bone Banri that she sees everyday because she knows that the new Banri's heart only loves Koko.


Although you can argue that she does these things out of guilt that she is responsible for his condition, you cannot deny that the old Banri planted his feelings inside of her heart and she is trying to nurture those feelings. However, the growth of those emotions are stunted by the presence of the weed killer known as Koko. To me, Koko is a very unlikable character. 


Another factor that resulted in her being a tragic character was that Linda is the most obvious person who understands Banri the most and not Koko. She was his childhood friend and love interest up to the end of high school. She is the one who tends to Banri's emotional episodes where he feels lost in the world. In addition, during high school, Banri tended to Linda's emotions when she was unable to cope with the fact that her brother is being cheated. They have a true relationship because they exchange their feelings. All Koko offers is a one-way relationship as exemplified by her constant (and stalkerish) desire to be around Banri. Koko is a brick wall blocking Banri's vision to his past. Essentially, Koko is telling Banri to throw away his former identity, which is equivalent to having him deny who he is as a complete person. All of this behaviour makes Linda feel like the ideal partner for Banri but he fails to see it. Koko, though admirably, dumps Banri at the end (if only for a couple of episodes) having recognized that she is unable to take care of and appreciate him as a complete person. As I see it, at the end, Banri becomes addicted to the drug named Koko and foolishly casts away half of his identity in order to blissfully live in the present. Of course, Linda is a strong character so she is willing to be forever hidden away in Banri's memory.


On another note about Linda, I vehemently oppose the relationship between Linda and Mitsuo. He just begins liking Linda for no reason (a consistent problem of this anime) and Linda only blushes because he has a good face and body. If there is a second season, this relationship absolutely cannot develop unless if the writers convincingly compose a beautiful romance between them.


---END LINDA SPOILER---

Golden Time's plot is very interesting, and the concept of severe amnesia was the main draw in for me.
Story:7
The story was pretty interesting, though some of it seems rather rushed. Such as character's relationship development, and more particularly the ending of the series. A good point of the story is that they always add twists, and turns. So you won't get into that "happy plotless anime" feeling for to long. I would mention how this takes place in a college setting instead of your average highschool, but that setting wasn't very developed upon, and doesn't have a large play in the actual story.
Art:7
The art workwas pretty good. I liked it nice coloring, character's body didn't appear to be strangle off. Some of the backgrounds could have been done better, but that doesn't mean they were bad. Just some of the setting scenes everything was just one big picture zooming in. \n\n
Sound:7\n
The opening, and closing didn't really stand out to me much. I liked the second opening song, but I don't think it would be good enough to listen to outside of just watching the show. As for the BGM none of it really stood out for me, actually I don't really notice it unless it's a chase, or drama scene. For the one's I did notice they sounded similar to the BGM of Toradora. The story is written by the same writer, and I believe the music was composed be the same person (I could be wrong) so it isn't that big of a deal to me.\n\n
Character:7\n
I found the character's pretty interesting and normally I would give a better rating, but I felt some of the character's either got tossed aside, or I just dislike their personality in general. One character I am particularly found of is Mr. 2D, or 2D-kun. He first comes across as a comic relief type character, but proves himself to be one of the best supporting character's I've ever seen! He cares about his friends, and their bond to point where it could be concidered protaginist worthy! Heck, if they wanted this show to sell they would place him as the protaginist!\n\n
Enjoyment:7\n
I actually really liked this show as a whole, though it wasn't one of those that I would drop everything I was doing to see what happened next, but very few shows are able to do that to me. \n\n
Overall:7\n
Overall I think this show is worth the time to watch for most people. I'm not a big fan of things like love triangles, but this one was pretty good dispite that. For people who don't like romance, or anime's with some kind of unique twist I probably tell them to atleast give it a shot.

To start, the anime here is the perfect romcom with a lot of drama that unfortunately didn't fix itself that much in the end. The story was good in the first few episodes but at around the fifth, everything just flipped. They just switched the mood completely from then on out it was like all happy and normal then they would suddenly do something crazy to create conflict. It was interesting and sad at some points but the writers just sort of pushed things along without much transition. 
The art is basic, very detailed and helps with the mood swings going on in this anime.It changed with different atmospheres like in the  comic relief scenes and over dramatic scenes. 


The sound is good but sometimes a bit too over the top and it stood out too much in gloomy scenes. There was one where the piano was playing and it didn't really match up with the scene, I don't know if that would be a problem for most of you but it just didn't work sometimes. The opening and ending songs were worthy of listening to although the second ending kind of ruins the end of the episode if the episode was surprisingly sad or something(again with the mood changes). Also with the first opening, you can kind of tell what is going to happen already so it didn't surprise me. 


Now, the characters were sort of the bump here. The supporting characters were fine and I actually liked them but the main ones, Koko and Banri were not as strong. I couldn't tell whether I liked Koko or not because she would be really two-faced and sometimes annoying but sometimes reasonable. Banri was just all over the place fighting with himself and I really ended up hating him a lot. Not sure why he was so annoying but sometimes it was just too much.


I enjoyed this anime a lot because it was still funny, interesting and sad in a good way despite the flaws with this anime. It was really confusing to understand what exactly was going on especially in the last episode(seriously what happened on the bridge...) but I guess it worked out okay at the end. The only thing is that they kind of ignored the other relationships that had sprouted and it just didn't feel complete.


Overall, I give this a 7 because there were many flaws and although they were little, they could've been changed to make this anime flow better and make more sense. I recommend it to any romance, comedy and drama lovers because it's still worth the watch.

Romantic comedies ride on a very narrow set of tracks. With limited settings, character archetypes, and plot progressions, it’s easy to see why people often adopt the “if you’ve seen one, you’ve seen them all” mentality when approaching the genre. That being said, every once in a while, buried underneath a mountain of anime that all lookalike, a gem is found. In this case, it seems the anime industry struck something closer to gold.
I’d rather not provide any spoilers here. The series revolves around a group of friends and their experiences in living an independent life. They go through romantic troubles and obstacles with platonicrelationships, introspective issues and material trials, learning about what it is to be human and alive in the present. The story primarily focuses on the life of Tada Banri and his relationship with Kaga Kouka 9 [she's so cuteeeeeeeeee......], his to-be girlfriend, but shifts the focus to other side characters fairly often. Overall, the plot is interesting, but what makes it exceptional is that it’s paced in a way that each episode leaves you wanting to watch the next.


The realism is prominent in each episode. Each episode shows the characters engaged in a constant game of tug-of-war, living life to the fullest only to be brought back to new lows and dealing with the consequences of being alive. Even the romance is painstakingly real, with characters experiencing breakups and finding new love in a manner grounded in reality.


The series is also one of the few to successfully utilize a majorly overused and jaded plot device: AMNESIA. Amnesia is probably as cliche things go, but it’s rare to see it used for anything other than an excuse for starting characters off on a blank slate. Golden Time really milks Tada Banri’s status as an amnesiac, extracting every last aspect of his condition and giving each facet meaningful character interaction. His condition isn’t a simple ailment; it’s a necessary trauma that the whole story revolves around. But most importantly, it’s unintrusive. How enraging is it to be completely engrossed in a series when a character with amnesia most conveniently forgets some crucial piece of information, only realizing he/she forgot at that moment? It’s disruptive and draws the ire of every anime fan, but Golden Time avoids this somehow, all the while crafting the story to revolve around this one single aspect of a character.


Unique character development is nice and all, but it’s an entirely different matter to build on them in a way that creates a more enjoyable character, and this is Golden Time‘s biggest strength. The cast, starts off as the boring standard that most romance anime utilize, but they all develop in ways that positively contribute to the story.


Overall - 10/10 I highly recommend to watch this even if you're not SOL fan at all...atleast give it a try....I know you will enjoy this  :]

Golden Time has an execution problem. And not the one you'd think it has. It isn't ugly or ill-animated (though it can be kind of underwhelming visually). The problem it has is directorial in nature. The show's blessed with strong characters and bristling with dramatic possibilities, but director Chiaki Kon is an impediment every step of the way. She screws up hard and often, making it painfully clear that if Golden Time is to succeed, it's going to have to succeed in spite of her. And, at least here, it does exactly that.
There's nothing particularly promising about Golden Time's setup. It begins with two albatrossesfirmly hung about its neck. One is Tada Banri. He's mild and kind and rather boring—exactly the kind of sweet-natured loser who afflicts shonen romances like some kind of personality-impaired pox. The other is Kaga Koko. While she's strong-willed and unafraid to be unsympathetic, she's also a dispiriting female stereotype: the girl who lives to love a man. The introduction of Tada's amnesia gimmick only adds a third albatross. You can count the number of good amnesia stories on the fingers of a careless chainsaw operator.


The show unfolds pretty much as you expect it to. Tada hangs out with Yanagisawa, which exposes Koko to him and him to Koko. They go to club recruiting meetings and party and hang out together. As Yanagisawa vehemently repels Koko's advances and Koko uses Tada to get close to her beloved, the inevitable begins and the two lonely souls start to connect. Boilerplate rom-com through and through.


Something odd happens along the way though. The cliché characters and their cliché situations start to alchemize, reacting together, pulling each other in interesting directions. Tada's amnesia gives him a compelling reason for his blank(ish) personality. He isn't dull. He's a blank slate in the process of filling itself in. Koko's obsession with getting her man proves progressively less healthy, a romantic psychosis that is clearly eating her away and turning her into someone that she doesn't like. Somewhere along the line you realize that she isn't the lives-for-love cliché girl; she's Golden Time's answer for what happens to that girl when she grows up and the love she's living for doesn't materialize.


In the meantime, Tada's feelings for Koko cause him to re-evaluate his memory loss. He decides to brace his past, but in doing so uncovers some things—specifically about a goodhearted sempai who's befriended him—that start to erode his fledgling happiness. His relationship with Koko turns serious as her relationship with Yanagisawa dies spectacularly, and everything collides messily in a (mid-season) finale that is everything that a romantic climax should be: heart-rending, sweet, and beautifully satisfying.


We realize much of this only in retrospect however. The character evolution, the calibrated arc of the plot, even the emotions along the way—while we're watching, we miss so much of it. Partly because Chiaki Kon screws it up, and partly because we're busy gritting our teeth at her screw-ups. This is the rare series whose directorial issues aren't vague and theoretical, but concrete and often very, very specific.


Take the episode where Tada and Koko get bamboozled into a cult indoctrination session. And yes, that happens. Kon completely misses the surreal hilarity of the situation, trying instead for tension (which, to be fair, is also part of the mix). But more tellingly, when Tada throws himself under the bus to save his fellow cult victims and Koko follows him under for his sake, Kon presents their actions with a kind of affectless flatness. It's left to us to parse what they're feeling and the effect they have on each other, which means the sequence hits us in the head instead of in the heart.


And that's more or less Kon's pattern. Too often she just shows and tells, pushing neither visuals nor actors to pull us into the moment. We observe events when by all rights we should be living them. When in episode four Koko accidentally wounds Tada during an ugly fight with Yanagisawa, her tears shifting poignantly from tears of anger to tears of regret as she realizes her mistake, the moment should have instantly carved our hearts out. But Kon misplaces a single insert shot—a single shot! (specifically of Tada's reaction to Koko's words)—and we're left to figure the sequence out after the fact instead of living through it with the principals.


And that is a serious, serious problem. More serious than the pedestrian animation, which doesn't try nearly hard enough to convey character or feeling through motion. More serious than the clean, but bland background artistry. More serious than Yukari Hashimoto's unremarkably competent score. More serious than the forgettable (non-Koko) character designs. More serious than any technical shortcoming or, for that matter, any failing of the script or the actors. It's a failure to realize the show's potential.


And because it's obvious, at least after the cult episode, we spend more time fretting over lost potential than the potential that persists. Until it bursts into an impossible-to-ignore conflagration. The potency of episode six comes almost as a shock. The pangs we feel, and the wonderful, warm satisfaction afterwards, force a full-on re-evaluation. It's then that you notice how every element of the (mid-season) climax is in place and waiting its turn from episode one. It's then that you realize how much you've come to like and root for Koko and Tada. It's then that you appreciate Koko's strength and complexity, and Tada's secretly wounded kindness. It's then that you forgive the series its every trespass and look forward, hungry to see where Tada and Koko are going next

To enjoy Golden Time you need to look past a few things. First, you need to look past some typical school rom com tropes (although I didn't feel that they were too egregious compared to some school drama anime I've seen). Second, you need to be able to work your way through a couple of dragging plot points in the middle of the series. Third, you need to be more interested in a good story and characters than in the spectacle (particularly art and sound) of the show. If you can look past these things, you will have a hell of a good time withGolden Time.


This show is a roller coaster ride of emotions (in a good way). The plot centers around a college student, Banri, who previously suffered an accident and has amnesia as a result. This affects all of his interactions with his fellow students because there is an intricate web of emotions and memories that Banri has to navigate as he tries to be the best friend (and boyfriend) to the various characters. 


Ultimately, the amnesia becomes a major plot point and really the driving force of the show. To me, the writers actually put quite a lot of thought into how amnesia might affect someone's personal relationships beyond what we tend to immediately think about when we imagine living with amnesia. Sometimes the various characters' actions get frustrating, but ultimately everything is in character and understandable. The amnesia isn't used as a plot device as much as a central topic that is explored through the narrative.


Sadly, the mystical elements of this show force it to play a little fast and loose with the real life medical understanding of amnesia, but I think that the spiritual elements are something that others might find more resonant than myself. If you can look past this and focus on the character relationships and the way they are affected by Banri's amnesia, you'll enjoy the show a lot more.


Overall, this show got an 8/10 from me (Very Good). I hesitate to bump Golden Time's rating up to a 9 because of some of the lackluster art and sound (both musically and VA), the dragging plot at certain points, and the cliches that serve as filler in a variety of places. That said, I didn't just think the show was a 7/10 (Good), I purposefully give this an 8 as I thoroughly enjoyed it and would recommend it to anyone who is even mildly interested in the genre.

Golden Time is an excellent romantic story that has all you could desire from a classic bestselling romantic novel. It begins with a solid story, character relationships grow gradually, the plot is okay-ish in the beginning.
However, in the middle parts and after that -- the story becomes mother of Goku level beautiful. Seriously, there's no other word. As the story nears its end, you would be hard pressed to feel (if you're like me, that is) "Dude, don't give me a romantic tragedy. Had enough of them."
Keeping spoilers out of way there's nothing much I can elaborate on. In fact, other aspects like art andcharacters don't make sense at all in the anime because the story is so beautiful after the middle part. It will just grip you. Needless to say, I watched it in one go and that's what you're going to do.


So, let's get a bit philosophical about it. What actually makes Golden Time an excellent romantic story? Basically, the protagonist's internal struggle. Don't worry, it might feel like you're reading some spoilers but they're not.


Internal struggle between two sides of himself -- pre-accident and post-accident where being conscious of one part means losing the other. It has been, in the very conclusion when you will be crying your eyeballs out (probably, not my thing) -- you'll see the whole point of the anime.


The creators have crafted two separate personalities and in the end, they satisfied both of them. In a way, you can say a conflict of ideas and personalities both managed to get satisfied in the end. This is the most beautiful thing about Golden Time.


Simply put, you'll love it. Best romantic anime I've watched in a while.

Anyways, glad it ended well
Then again, this anime genre isn't my cup of tea so I guess I didn't really understand what the true meaning was. I also love Kouko so yeah.

Golden Time is the most recent anime I have seen as of writing this review. I went into the series hoping to experience the same sense of endeavour that I did with its predecessor Toradora, unfortunately I was disappointed. That being said, this isn't a bad anime series, if we look at it from a stand alone perspective without reference to Toradora this series isn't half bad.
Golden Time follows a boy named Tada Banri who is currently attending college, due to later conceived circumstances we found out that he had recently suffered a case of amnesia that lead him to forget everything after his finalyear of High School. Whilst adjusting to his new life, a girl named Kaga Kouka is introduced who brings with her a plot of drama and romance.


Pros

So yeah I didn't quite enjoy this series as much as I expected to, my main problem lies within a certain portion of the show but I'll get to that later. I'll start of with what I liked about the series, the characters for one, the series does an amazing job with the handling of each character. Every character feels like a genuinely real person, all with their own traits and flaws, if you don't like one character theres gonna be another one that you'll certainly enjoy. *Has 2D flashbacks* Another aspect of the show I enjoyed was the writing (well, at least in the beginning) there are a lot of heart felt moments that can be accredited to the writers of the series, much of the dialogue, especially the lines delivered by Tada Banri, can really tug at the heart strings at times. 


Cons

Alright those were the things I enjoyed about the show, I won't mention the things I didn't mind about the show such as the animation or music because I don't really have an opinion on them, they were just meh. Instead I'll just focus on the pros and cons, as these are the parts of the show that grasped my attention and actually made me give a second thought about. So as I mentioned before I have an underlying problem with this show, and this has the do with the latter half of the series. After episode 6 the series enters a decline as it introduces many other unneeded elements into the story such as evil spirits and love triangles. I would have to say that episode 6 of the series is the best it has to offer, I loved that episode from start to finish and I especially enjoyed how it ended. I honestly believe that if they ended it at the 6th episode I would have been more satisfied. It would have obviously been an incomplete anime but nevertheless I would have enjoyed it more and would be able to come to terms with the ending. The ending of the series is terrible, it is very short sighted and you can tell that the series creators needed to quickly end it before they blew their budget, the show needed more time to further elaborate on the resolve of this series because it kind of just... ends. Another problem I have with this series is its 'humour', I didn't find much of it funny as a lot of it was very forced and kind of interjected into casual scenes. There are some scenes that you may find funny here and there but it's nothing gut wrenching.



Conclusion

So did I like this series?... eh kind of. I certainly enjoyed the first 6 episodes but the rest of it is kind of a let down. Don't get me wrong this isn't a bad anime, it just has a lot of pacing issues but don't let that turn you away from this series, there is plenty of enjoyment to be had out of it.


FINAL SCORE: 5

Overall score: 8 do recommend great series
I started watching this anime cause of allot of people friends and people on the internet said that this is one of the best romance anime's out there as the the overall story was pretty original and it was overall a great story. Also the characters were well made and relateable. Also the ending was a pretty good as well it wrapped things up pretty nicely and it left me satified. Because of that I can say that that statement is not wrong by any means, but the series still has a few flaws. 
Firstly I think that thestory could have been a bit better as I feel as if the progression seemed a bit slow. 


Secondly the characters don't really seem like university/college students as for some episodes the main problem could be solved by simply talking to each other which kinda gave me a high schooler kinda vibe with how immature they seem to be.


Thirdly I think that the could have been more character development for the supporting cast specificity 2D, Oka, as well as Nana. I feel like these characters should have been devolved a bit more.


But the beyond those 3 flaws it didn't really make a difference about how much I enjoyed this series. So overall in my honest opinion this still a great romance anime that I would recommend to others.

***This is a spoiler free review***
Golden Time is an anime that really put me on a rollercoaster ride. There were moments where I legitimately thought it was the best drama I had seen in awhile when other times it had me wanting to drop the show entirely.
Story: 7/10
I will say that the story for Golden Time is fresh, has twists and turns, and had very serious and emotional scenes. I will also say that there are a lot of "cheap" tricks the show uses to make certain events happen for convenient reasons. A quick rundown of the opening is that we follow new college studentTada Banri as he meets new friends Mitsuo, Chinami, Linda, and Kouko. The opening act of the anime had me extremely interested with the possibilities the show could span into. Banri automatically finds someone he likes, he becomes really close friends with Mitsuo, and there was many hints at future foreshadowing events. One thing I would like to point out is that the show did an incredible job at creating "real" feeling scenes that I will remember for the foreseeable future. The friendship between Banri and Mitsuo felt "real" and the events that occur between this cast felt very "real". Also later on in the show when s#!t gets real, I genuinely felt emotionally torn at what I was watching.


Now I cannot comment on what I thought felt "cheap" about the show since it would ruin a major plot point but just know that while the show really pulls some things out of its a$$ in order to make sense of certain events, for the most part it ties the story together well enough in the end.


I do not like rating certain arcs by themselves but the beginning of the show far outshines the ending act.


Animation: 6.9/10


It was....basic but still looked pretty good. The animation studio used some really basic colors and there was a sense of dullness BUT they did an amazing job with facial expressions which really helped out in the emotional scenes. Character models looked pretty good (Kouko was so kawaii :D).


Sound: 7/10


Music=pretty good


Voice actors=amazing level


Voice actors did a really awesome job while the music was good but not great. Openings and endings were not memorable.


Characters: 9.5/10


Extremely tight nit cast that provided so many different scenes. One minute you are laughing at a funny scene while four minutes later you are flipping your chair into the air cursing out Kouko for being Kouko. Every character was important which is very important since a lot of anime try to stick generic stand in's for purpose made situations. Each character had a job and performed that job spectacularly. Now I won't lie and say that I loved each one of them. There were many and MANY moments when I really wanted to jumped into the show and beat the living fu#@ out of some of them but in the end I really did enjoy what each one brought to the table.


Overall: 7.6/10


I really, really, really got involved with this anime. Some of the moments in this anime were the best I had experienced in a long time while others really made me want to leave it for awhile. It will grab your full and undivided attention with its witty cast and believable performances; just be prepared to really get frustrated.


Enjoyment: 8.4/10

While many of the reviews here seem to have a lot of complaints regarding the anime, I personally found the anime itself satisfying. While I do admit that it was far from perfect (in a world such as ours with many groundbreaking animes, it's quite hard to match up to the standard at times), Golden Time still managed to make an impression on me in terms of several aspects.
Unlike others, I'd like to focus on sounds first, which I rated with a high (9). While others may say that the sounds were too cliche in terms of how they were applied throughout the scenes ofthe anime, I think that a lot of them were actually apt for these particular scenes (especially emotional/climactic scenes throughout the anime). This anime, in particular, is filled with some very emotional and striking OSTs (Kurutta Shinario, Konna ni mo Kowareyasuku, Yomigaeru Kako, and Hikan among others), and if you're fond of anime OSTs, you'll realize that the music has the ability (at times) to make up for shortcomings in scene development. In this case, I feel that these OSTs (especially those that I've mentioned) managed to accentuate the "drama" part of the anime which I am supposed to be experiencing, and it really gets me thinking whenever I hear the music.


With regards to the story, I feel that the plot material had a lot of wasted potential. For one, the entire anime was somehow rushed, and a lot of major developments might catch an inattentive viewer off-guard. I also feel that a lot of sub-plots in the anime could have been great material for additional development (I won't spoil but if you watched the anime you'll realize what I'm talking about). Nevertheless, I particularly enjoyed how complex and convoluted the entire emotional situation was, as well its effects on certain individual characters (such as Linda, Mitsuo to a smaller extent, and others). Linda's in particular is a predicament which calls for introspection on the part of the viewer, and as I watched the anime, I can't help but feel a bit pained at the inherent irony and loss which came along with her situation.


Since I'm not really a good judge of art, I guess I'd say that it was pretty good, although other animes have done better. Nevertheless, it doesn't really matter to me since it really didn't have much of a profound effect on the other aspects of the anime. 


I rated character development rather low because I felt that other supporting characters (Chinami, 2d-kun, even Mitsuo) could have benefited from a bit more development. I get that the amnesia overarching theme is quite big, and that it already involves at the very least three important characters (Linda, Banri, and Koko), but it would have been nice to see how the sentiments of other characters (Chinami and Mitsuo in particular) would have played out in the scheme of things.


As I have a particular weakness for emotional music and sob scenes, I really enjoyed this anime in particular. I am also a fan of humor, and so I enjoyed how there were plenty of humorous scenes to counteract the sad vibes which were pretty much prevalent in this anime.


I guess that overall, I wasn't expecting so much, which is why I wasn't disappointed (unlike what others have said). However, this anime gave me a pretty good story, likeable characters, great music, and a satisfying anime. If anything, I would say that this anime is sort of like my guilty pleasure, since I know that objectively speaking, there are better animes out there. Despite this, I consider Golden Time my favorite anime, and that's because it was able to resonate with me.
