*Disclaimer - This is my first review on MAL.
I feel as if this is the most realistic romantic comedy/drama anime I've seen. I'm not sure about how realistically the amnesia is handled, but it felt real enough to fool a person like me who knows little to nothing about it. The best thing I can take away from this anime is that you can have realistic emotions and characters portrayed in a story without it being overly dramatic or boring.
Characters - 
They are brash, impulsive, stupid and most importantly flawed. They feel like real life people. Imperfect real people who know exactly what to doat times and have no clue how to handle things at times. Sometimes those actions pay off and sometimes they don't just like in real life.


Relationships -

The relationships between friends and lovers is handled realistically as well. There are no forced situations between them and they handle situations in a mature manner and sometimes in a not so mature manner, again just like in real life. Also, it's refreshing to see characters act their age.


Story -

The story is well written and the screenplay is great, but there are times when you feel like nothing is happening and they could've easily done away with it, but I feel that it added to the feeling of the character's life being mundane at times. The pacing seemed fine although I feel that there was a lot of repetitive dialogue between the characters where they discussed exactly the same thing they did a few episodes ago. Again, I feel it added to the realness of the relationship and characters where in real life we too often discuss the same things over and over again.


Animation and music -

Animation is top notch and so is the voice acting. I didn't care much for the music though, but I think the background score was good enough.


Enjoyment -

I thoroughly enjoyed the journey of Tada Banri and the people around him. What I got sick of was him saying his name over and over and over again.


Final thoughts -

To me the story and characters felt real unlike in most anime where you know that this situation would never take place or a character would never do anything like that. That doesn't mean that it was boring and/or devoid of joy, it was anything but that.

Golden Time seemed like a very promising series that changed the settings from the conventional slice-of-life, school anime series to a much more mature themes like the first steps to the adult life; college life, paying bills and debts, dealing with responsibilities and making some free time for friends, trying to survive by your own self.
The characters seemed to be very likeable, both in their design and personality, that makes them, somehow, very human, leading to some relatable situations (I may believe  when you watch this, some of you might say "I remember this" or "I've been through this"...) filled with comedy, drama orsome incredibly, but memorable, awkward moments.


If there's something that I have to complain it's about the "paranormal trope" around Banri Tada (the main character). I didn't find it so necessary to fill the plot with a "metaphor" about his terrible experience. Also, at some point of the series, some characters apparently"disappeared" from the events and their fates remain unknown.


About the storyline, I found it entertaining, but "unbalanced", because there is some parts of the story that went so fast or gave them too short time on screen, these "details" are worthy to explore it further to understand some situations that could've made it more interesting or compelling than before.


For me, this anime series had a lot of potential, because it had the chance to show how the characters deal with a more adult's world exploring what is love, friendship, the college and the work life and their own personal issues. But it becomes a disappointing, unfulfilling promise that throws away any possibility to rescue it from its own terrible mistakes.

Have some rather mixed thoughts on this one. Golden Time is a romantic dramedy focused around our male lead Banri entering a law school to get caught up in some antics involving another student named Mitsuo and his rather aggressive childhood friend Kouko, who has an requited love interest in him. Banri winds up becoming acquainted with Kouko throughout the series and their relationship gradually develops into a romantic one.
I guess I'll get into what I liked about this baby first. Kouko made for a rather fun character to see thanks to her varying moods throughout the series and was shown to undergo a gradualamount of development with her character as she came to realize the challenges she faced in the relationships she developed with other characters. The series rather believably explores the development of Banri and Kouko's gradual relationship as they start dating and both come to learn the ins and outs of being a couple such as developing trust and commitment toward one another. I was actually enjoying this aspect to the series rather well up to its second half and many of the show's comedy scenes delivered well for the most part, particularly those with "Nana-sempai" who is an obvious expy of the punk rocker character from josei series Nana.


Unfortunately, there is one major aspect of the show's plot that deters its quality to a good extent and this comes from an aspect of Banri's character in that he has amnesia. Amnesia has been a rather convenient plot device milked in live-action and animated dramas with varying levels of quality and emotional connection since aspects of the medical condition are often not portrayed believably. This story element does have its potential at first as Banri struggles with old feelings he has for Karen, a classmate he knew from high school and attending the same law school as him and who occasionally has him experience relapses of recalling times with her before his accident.


However, the way that amnesia works in Golden Time is a bit on the absurd side with a ghost-like manifestation of Banri seen throughout the series representing the memories he lost in his accident whom tries sabotaging the life of his current persona in a way similar to the ghostly old flame from Natsuyuki Rendezvous, only way more angsty compared to the present persona portrayed by Banri. This has the unfortunate side effect of causing the quality of Golden Time's second half to tank quite a bit as the plot becomes more fixated on the absurd direction that Banri's amnesia is taking him and putting strains in the relationships he establishes with Kouko and his law school friends throughout the course of the series, becoming a rather intrusive and unnecessary form of drama due to how poorly believable it is. The way things get wrapped up at the end of the series with the amnesia storyline is lazy and way too convenient with how things get resolved.


So pretty much, I'm kind of mixed in my reception toward Golden Time. The romance and comedy deliver well for the most part as I enjoyed the believable development of Banri and Kouko's relationship. Unfortunately, the drama delivered through Banri's amnesia borders on absurd and I was dumbfounded that the creators of the series incorporated the story element in the way they did. I'm rather disappointed in that element of the series as it otherwise was a good rom-com with what it offered up beyond the amnesia gimmick.

A romance anime that starts off with a whack in the face with thornless roses. It's a situation where the physical impact doesn't hurt, but it can't cover up the fact that it strikes at my heart.
That's how I feel about the ending of this anime as well, when the anime gets off scotch free from the mistakes they made with it and runs away with the princess in their arms. I'm going to say this straight away, the ending is loose, it is rushed, plot holes just very conveniently happen and I don't like it.
But this doesn't mean you should skip out on thisanime. The ending doesn't make up the entire thing, and I'm glad that it does not do that at all. The plot is generic, but the characters are truly the bones that hold up the sagging failures it has. These are some of the most well thought out characters that aren't like the typical tsundere or perverted straight man that blows an artery when he sees the slightest bit of skin. No no, they are normal people for the most part and more importantly, they are relatable to you an me. They may at times choose to run away from their problems, but they eventually learn to confront it and face it head on, even if it hurts. When there is a discrepancy-instead of fighting, abandoning or hiding these problems-Banri(Main character) and Koko talk it out. Especially when they meet up after the night club; that has got to be one of the best conversations that sensible, smart people can have when faced with a situation like that. 


It's what normal people would do, and it's odd that it does so many slice of life moments better than animes that claim to follow that genre. Yet this is a supernatural anime. Yeah, I know that Ghost B really messed things up with his appearance. It did confuse me too at first, but if you choose to think about it as a mental debate. If that part was done better; instead of it being a ghost, this anime would certainly have gotten a 9 or higher. 


Story: The story is not particularly special, except for the ghost part. What it serves is to move things along and allow characters to develop. It's okay, but simply is not special.


Art: It's good, it serves its purpose, but doesn't stand out either. Sometimes the characters do look a little funky, but I got used to it. 


Sound: Now this was something that this anime excelled at. I really enjoyed the 2nd opening in particular because it always gave me those chills that you get after reading a good book. When the arguments start raining down, the instruments pick up the mood and play along with them. 


Enjoyment: For the majority of this anime, I did enjoy it. However the ending ruined it for me. But even as I was reading the reviews that blasted that over and over at me, I still chose to push on because I simply had so much fun listening to the characters talk, laugh, joke and move on with their lives. Don't be reluctant to pick up this show simply because the ending was poorly written, because it is worth it. 


Thanks for reading my review and if you got any questions, want to debate, or want to give some criticism, I'm up for it!

It took me a long time to complete this anime. Mostly because I started getting bored of it in the middle and left it for other romcom anime. Anyway, Golden Time is your typical romance drama anime with a few love interests, major drama, some handicap and a happy ending. I'm gonna write a really short review because I honestly don't feel like writing one, since there's nothing special about this anime.
Story 8/10:
Just read the synopsis, it pretty much sums things up. Tada falls in love with Kouko, they go out. Problems arise, they break up, get together again. Add in between that stuff, apast lover, a friend who also has romantic problems and some other troubles and that's it.


Art 8/10:

Good animation and graphics.


Character 7/10:

The protagonist is your everyday college boy. No delinquency, no bookworm. Just an amnesia problem that made him forget his past. As for the girl, she's the rich lady type. Add a caring friend, an average high school girl, and some other guys, that's pretty much it.


Enjoyment 7/10:

Sometimes, it is enjoyable. The first half of the anime goes pretty well but the second half was difficult to watch continuously for me. It becomes predictable and I found myself watching other romance anime instead of this. Now I'm not saying this is a bad anime. For a romance drama, this is as good as you can get and if you want a pure romance drama anime, Golden Time is the perfect choice.


Overall, for romance drama lovers, this is an awesome anime. Enough said.

I dont generaly write reviews, mainly because I dont think I´m well enough versed in nuances of anime world, but when I saw this anime and lack of acknowledgement it got here I simply felt it was neccessary to do something.
Story: Although I am sure many will disagree, I think story is one of stron point of this anime. I start as ordinary school life story and develope into multilayered one. As series progress you learn more and more about protagonist and hios hardships. Story contains one element which is little more fantasy natured but given narative of story I accepted it fully without anymajor hiccup. Ending was little bit predictable and maybe even rushed - I think another ten or twenty minutes would be better, but it definitely didn´t ruined story for me.


Art: I dont know what to say about art. It felt appropriate for story, it felt realistic, not simplistic in any way. It wasn´t artistic orgasm but I think that wasn´t called for in the story.


Sound: As above not my expertise so nothing stand out in bad or good way. Felt good but not memorably so, not that I am complaining.


Characters: This is tied to story which should indicate I was pleased. Characters are deep enough, they have backstories, their characters or rather their behaviour is consistent throughout story. Some felt little bit melodramatic but not in unbelievable way.


Enjoyment and overall: In the end what is most important for viewer is enjoyment. if story struck note, or viewer can empathize with characters. And this story did exactly that. Somewere in the half of series I couldn´t stop watching, I needed to know what will happen next and then and so on till story was finished. I was bit surprised how much I enjoyed this series given I started watching it by accident, I was looking for a differnt anime and this one popped during my search. I say this to ilustarte how good it was, I started watching simply beacause of synopsis and was hooked since 1st episode. And when it ended I felt sadness you feel when old friend leaves.


So everyone who wants to be surprised, definitely give this one try.

Ok here I go, I may have scored this a little high but I actually was a big fan of this show.
 There are a lot of low reviews saying the characters are stupid and annoying or uninteresting. I find it refreshing to have characters that aren't so over the top and set in their personalities that is makes no realistic sense. Nobody is so clear cut that they act the same way throughout the whole show no matter what is happening around them. I think that is what makes this anime so good.
There will be characters you like one second and then they dosomething so unexpectedly infuriating that you just pause the show and say "nope you are dead to me" but then they come back and admit they were being a jackass and seek forgiveness. Just like the real world.


Golden Time takes real college student personalities and adds a truly terrifying identity crisis. When you don't know who you were and what is expected of you do you move on and leave that behind you? Basically killing the person everyone knew. Or do you attempt to rebuild old relationships and become the person that was lost. If you do that what happens to the current version of yourself?


I don't think this show was designed to appeal to everyone. But if you do like it, I can see it jumping into your top 10 like it did mine.


Miyazaki has said that Anime as a whole is on the decline due to the industry being filled with otaku that don't actually know/interact with real people. Golden Time is, in my opinion, proof that there is still hope.

I was not up for watching the series at first, but it was a good thing I did. I completed all the episodes in one go without getting bored.
Story:
The beginning was not so great. But soon enough, the story got good. It is predictable but interesting. The pacing was almost perfect. The ending is quite predictable but there are many other going on that will keep your interest.

Enjoyment:\n
It is a enjoyable series. Most of the people who watch romance will take a liking to this. It has some humor which adds to the enjoyment. I usually binge watch, so I cannot really say watching it slow would be enjoyable or not. The series is may not be a great one, but definitely not boring.

I was really enjoying the series. All of a sudden, right about halfway through the series. I felt like it was drifting off of the topic. I thought it was pretty obvious who he was going to choose. The ending felt rushed to me and they didn't even focus that much on the main characters at all. One of the main characters felt more like a side character towards the end. The ending was the worst ending that I've seen so far. It made no sense. People who have seen it will understand what I mean. I really thought it had potential. There so muchthat went wrong with this series. I was hoping that it was at least going to end with an amazing plot twist. The author was probably more lost than me, as to how to make this series with a good ending. I wouldn't recommend this series to anyone. \n\n
The main problem I had with this series was how his "original self" was more like a supernatural character. It would've been better if his memories had started to come back while still being the person that he was while he was in college. That would've been the most obvious way to go, realistically speaking. Then it would've been a dramatic ending by having him choose with who to stay with in the end.

I just want to make a quick review on this show because I thought that it was average and there were a bunch of flaws that mainly had to do with the second half of the anime. I'm just going to point the obvious.
Story:Story was interesting in the first few episodes but then we get a love triangle with amnesia in the mix. Other things to mention is that it paces from comedy to drama every so often. The biggest gripe I have is the second half since the drama bits start to feel like a spanish soap opera and not much payoff in theend of it either.


Characters: Too many character archetypes used but nevertheless they were enjoyable. They were all fun to watch when the anime went into comedy mode but not so when it went into drama mode. Koko's character starts off as eccentric but later matures which I find really boring. The only interesting thing about Tada Banri was his amnesia and Linda's character was just there to fill up the role of his amnesia love triangle, although her backstory was pretty darn good. The other supporting cast were mostly there to fill up the role of comedy relief and sometimes they would participate in the drama bits.


Art: Art was nothing special IMO. They didnt even tried to mix in other animation in there, just basic anime drawings.


I did enjoy this anime a lot right until Koko stopped being eccentric and mature into the "perfect" girlfriend (I swear in the ending they had these shots for guys to pretend they were banri when they were kissing and making up). Even in the second half it was still fun watching it for the comedy portion of this comedy romance since the jokes were well done some times.

Mr/Mrs Character Developer is the writer who loves to play out human emotions to their logical extreme. Mr/Mrs Character Developer loves to set up archetypes or stereotypes and slowly break down their mythical carapace into believable bits of human fodder. Mr/Mrs Character Developer probably stares at all his/her friends with the kind of aesthetic distancing that may be voyeuristic and alienating but said alienation/voyeurism only serves to allow for a clear and refined look into the human interior, so as to allow for the perfect 1-1 ratio of psychological profundity. The extreme end of Mr/Mrs Character Developer is Dostoyevsky, who starts off with, as opposedto archetypes, ideological viewpoints, and slowly brings them down to Earth through an accumulation of acquired psychic detail. Mr/Mrs Character Developer is generally unaesthetic, prefers calm detail rather than stylish beauty, and, on the surface, seems like a kind of bore of a writer. Nothing stands out for Mr/Mrs Character Developer on first glance.


Mrs Character Developer A, Yuyuko Takemiya, has certain elements that seem like great flaws in creation. She loves, too much, exorbitant airy humor, slapstick, and the type of lowbrow that seems to stick in your stomach rather than rattle your brain. MCDA loves heartfelt hot-blooded nostalgic scenarios that overplay school romcomdrama cliches and enticingly banal slice of life moments, including beach episodes. MCDA loves irritatingly strange plot elements including sudden split personality amnesias, random scientologist-like cultists, Awa dances, and Nana-lookalikes playing heavy metal. One wonders whether MCDA is conniving, in that she managed to pull of the old Key trick of stringing up romcom banter after romcom banter with slowly gathering drama elements before pulling out the big guns, and thus managed to make essentially one of the best school romcomdramas of all time.


When viewing MCDA's new work adapted into animation form, one may perhaps notice as said above strange plot elements, a seemingly greater tendency towards lowbrow humor, very strange characters, and a very very unpolished animation style. Thus one wonders where did all that beautiful polished Toradora animation and vibrant archetypical-but-subverted characters all disappear too? Now we're left with a guy who apparently falls in love faster than a fingersnap, and a heroine who is, and proudly admits it herself, a bitch. Passions seem to tornado out of nowhere along with weird plot twists, while all sanity is lost by episode 3.


But wouldst thy lowly anime-fan doubt the psychological prowess of MCDA? In this case, apparently from all the reviews abound, yes, resoundingly. Characters were deemed 'unlikeable' and humor was deemed 'nonsensical' and all that sort of thing. Little did they know this was the very sign that MCDA was settling for something greater, a rawness of style that only befits the select few who intend to reach the peaks of MCD-greatness by acquiring the sacred 1-1 character to human profundity ratio.


Now when one looks back, it seems fitting that such a raw loose bad animation style (possibly unintended due to a bad studio) would be attached to Takemiya's greatly flawed but greatly interesting work. One of the things that seems to piss people off about the show are the character's obscure motivations. For example Tada Banri's unexplainable sudden love, and Kaga Koko's bipolarness which seems to skirt between emotional extremes ridiculously. Further strange obscure motivations includes Linda's very wavering very confusing heart, as well as Chinami's sudden outbursts and her own very very confusing heart. The split personality thing only serves to add more confusion to the mix, with pre-Banri and post-Banri, and the ending is really really weird, to say the least.


But if you think about it this frustrated confusion is the logical end result of the themes that were explored in Toradora. The very complex chain of interactions and passions which drive us to lead very double-faced lives and never be honest with ourselves, or never even really know ourselves. In Toradora there was a double-bind between two friends who didn't want to hurt each other but sort of knew about each others feelings for that one guy, and the underlying tension expanded until it exploded in the finale. Now in Golden Time you have essentially about multiple double binds built up between Banri-Kaga, Kaga-Mitsuo, Chinami-Mitsuo, Linda-Mitsuo, Linda-Banri. Not to mention between pre and post Banri, which takes the double-faced life concept in Toradora to a crazy insane extreme. The result is countless frequent explosions which seem to make no sense if you aren't exactly clear of the complex ways which the characters are meshing with one another while simultaneously trying to smooth out the various feelings and passions that are developing within them. The fickleness of the heart, another Toradora theme, especially considering how everyone never seems to get together with the one they claim to love, is taken to obscure heights here. Golden Time seems to bring everything up a notch even in its other departments. Idle schooltime jokes in Toradora are raised to the crazy gags in Golden Time's University life. It even has a subverted Beach Episode, which ends up leading to one of the most heart-poundingly realistic shit-could-happen moments of the show.


Another strange thing Golden Time loves to do is to have a comedic counterpoint to its really dramatic moments at times. But if you think about it it makes complete sense in a world where the naive romanticism of young school life gives way to the more complicated social interplay that happens at university level, where people don't take their emotions as sincerely or as romantically anymore, and have to balance greater their own social life and their own fervent passions. In fact one of the major emotional breakups in the series arises from a possibly idle misunderstanding played for laughs very early on in the series.


But for all its flaws and insanity Golden Time is just completely real. Its real because it captures the very raw and flawed landscape that exists in the countless permutations of interactions between human characters. Kaga Koko eventually becomes a very complex self-aware heroine who manages to rise out of her own self-loathing and emotional swings to become a great  self-determined character. And like Life itself, the loose ends are never really tied (except for that ending, which makes no sense to me), but never really cut off either. I would expect nothing less from MCDA.


Well she's still a far way off Dost, but she's on her way there.

While looking through the list of my anime and the few that I've remembered well enough to rate, I wondered why I gave Golden Time such a low score.
After I revisited the page I remembered why this series fell short. The plot device was too forced. Banri's Amnesia really didn't make him likable, more than a few times I had to sit there and just think "wtf is going on here."
As others have pointed out, a fair amount of drama occurs, things break down, and at that point I'm just thinking to myself "God damn it." It didn't make the anime more enjoyable or giveit any more depth.


I will say that I did really like Koko, I enjoy animes that have ladies. The bouquet scene was definitely funny, and throughout the anime she stayed beautiful and enjoyable.


At the end of the day, I feel like the forced plot and everything that comes with it just made the anime irredeemable. At the end, I just couldn't feel satisfied, I was just asking "Why?". That's why it's a 4, because there's just not a good aftertaste of it.


I will say that if you're able to overlook the forced plot the Amnesia creates (the biggest part), and the drama doesn't hurt you, then I can totally see this Anime getting an 8 or 9, which probably explains why it seems there's a gap of 3/4s vs 8/9s on the show.

I'll preface this review by saying that I've watched anime for close to 30 years now and that I only write reviews for anime that truly deserve it (good and bad).
When I started watching Golden Time I expected the same old cliches that are part of most romantic comedies, the same characters with the cookie cutter traits, and for the story to start boring me around 1/2 way through the series.  I've dropped a number of series due to this.
What I did not expect was to see was how each of those traits, that we take for granted now, in characters can be sowell played in a story that had a few weak spots, and really strengthen the series so that it turns into something truly outstanding!


Again, after close to 30 years of watching anime, this series truly made an impact on me and not sits comfortably in my Top 10 of all Romantic Comedies.  It may even rank in the top 15 of all Anime's I've ever seen.


I know that to some my words might be pushing the envelope.  There was a couple of flaws in the series (where is there a perfect series?) but at the end I couldn't stop watching and waiting to see what the end would bring.


This series held my attention, made me feel for the characters, and at the end put a couple of tears in my eyes.  For those that have truly experienced life - there's a little reminder of the hardships, trials, and love that's been lost and found again.


In the end - I give this series a Solid 10 rating.

Golden Time provides that normal rom-com anime we have but rather in a unique way - college setting, female lead is not your typical -dere (i.e. Toradora!), and others. But rather, from my own opinions, it has its own flaws, such as how you would be dissapointed if you see the last episode.
STORY - 3
The reason why the story was just that low was the anime left many questions unanswered. And, they put attention to Banri's tragedy instead of the comic part of the anime. Some events were too shallow, that you would feel that almost every episode is just a filler. The anime broughtup an outstanding and unique flow, but the progression of the story feels like only from the first few episodes and the last three episodes. In my opinion, you would really end up disappointed with how the story will end.


ART - 10

The graphics were astounding if you can say. Brightly colored and quite a match for other anime released in that year.


SOUND - 9

Music (all OP/ED) were sung by Horie Yui. I actually liked the sounds but what I only add in my music collection were the first OP and ED. The second OP and ED were fine too yet I got too overboard with them. Too lively for me to handle.


CHARACTER - 5

As with the story progression, characters were pretty "not in character." Development was too shallow too. The only characters I liked were 2D-kun and Nana (they were very cool but I was disappointed with 2D-kun as his role was never too significant for the rest of the anime).


ENJOYMENT - 8

Some rom-com anime fans will also like it in the beginning but if you were to expect a great ending, I wouldn't spoil the moment. 


Overall, I give it a 6. The anime could be pretty dull and not as tragic like Clannad or Angel Beats but if you are a fan of or like tragic anime, rom-com, unique settings, childhood friends cliche or any other anime that were produced by J.C. Staff, you can always try to watch Golden Time.

As my user name implies, I am a fan of the shoujo genera. In hopes of finding a slice of life romance anime, I decided to try Golden Time. As expected, the average romance anime followed through with a boy that somehow made it out of the friend zone, but I did not expect the plot twist of super natural activity. As much as I would like to spoil what super natural activity occurs, I will simply state that the romance anime that some would consider boring became heart pounding with cliff hangers and tragedies. I couldn't root for one character over another, when allmy grief and regrets were calmed with a superb ending. I would recommend this to this who take interest in: Romance, plot twists, love triangles/ jealousy, and an obsessive main character.

I really want a Season 2 of this anime. Although, i dont know what's going to happen. I still want to see koko and Banri more. 
I dont care if some people didn't want a Season 2 for Golden time, but I,m hoping ... for the sake of some people like me that love to see this once again, please make it for us.
I really love the way that  the story goes. I love its plot. I love Koko and I love to see a season 2 for them.

For the longest time I couldn't figure out why I had started watching this series only to get in a few episodes and then just stop. I had started watching it when it originally aired and got to around the 5th of 6th episode before stopping and only when I picked it up again over the last month did I remember why. 
The story is trite, and the characters are either poorly developed, unlikeable, unsympathetic or all three. I generally tend to find these types of anime an easy watch, but I honestly had to stop myself from stopping this series again in the hopesthat it would redeem itself. My hopes were sadly misplaced.  


Not only does it use the hackneyed plot point of convenient cinema amnesia as a premise for most of the external conflict for the show, but it manages to somehow make most of the main cast terribly shallow and unlikeable save for a few minor characters. 


Banri is pretty much a generic anime male lead who is made to look like a good guy until he selfishly manipulates Koko into a relationship with him by first forcing her to befriend him, open up to him, and then threaten to not even be friends once she rejects his first advances.


Koko is an emotionally unbalanced and manipulative stalker who has very clear co-dependency and trust issues. Despite being obsessed by one of their shared friends, she appears to very rapidly 'fall in love' with Banri, only after he threatens to not talk to her anymore. 


I held hopes that the show would address the unhealthiness of the relationship that was on show, and allow the characters to grow and develop through the course of their relationship, but unfortunately this doesn't eventuate and the series finishes in an achingly saccharine cliched way.


If relationships built on lack of trust, obsession and co-dependency don't bother you, then there may be something in this anime that you might find enjoyable, but if these things don't sound like your idea of a great main couple then it may be best to pass this one by.

This is by far one of the best anime romance series I've watched so far... Even though I'm newish (kinda?) to anime this is by far one of the best I've seen to this point along with Toradora and Chivalry of a failed knight. Let's get into my opinions and thoughts of this series..
Story 10/10: It's not a typical romance and the story is an amazing way to show you why... It's not a typical child hood friend, first sight love, saved your life kinda of love story it's a whole new way to it I've seen so far (If that makes sense)... I lovea good backstory and this definitely gave me what I was looking for as well. The way to pieced to the stories together about him losing memory along with finding his childhood friend in a college was amazing and the way the placed Banri and Koko together was amazing... They started off by not knowing each other at all and even though the relationship seemed kinda rushed.. It still worked out good, clingy girl falls in love with a first love guy? Typical right? As said I love a good backstory and loved everyone's characters from the get go.


Art 9/10: I love this style of art and really enjoyed the animations 


Sound 9/10: Not that big on sound for anime's as long as it sounds good I don't really care..


Character 10/10: The characters for this anime were almost perfect.. Rich girls loves a guy who doesn't love her and falls in love with someone who does. The backstories for the characters were amazing and it fitted so well bring every character together. Although I did some characters annoying and had no reason to be there I still understand why they were made into a secondary type character.


Enjoyment 10/10: Really enjoyed this and would recommend it to anyone whose looking for a way to be tossed into a romance/school type anime.


Overall 10/10: This anime is perfect for the typical Romantic type kind where you'll get all soppy over things and love a good backstory! The backstories for this is one of the best I've seen in a while and would love to see more of it.. I'm really annoyed that was no dubbed version for this because it would of made it 10 times better instead of having to read anything I could of sat back and relaxed instead of having to read everything.. BUT I still enjoyed myself watching this.

lets start with the story I thought the story was good it was different from other romantic anime I have watched the story follows a main character named Banri Tada who had a bad accident and now has amnesia wanting to start a new life so he decided to attend law school in Tokyo and trys to start a new life. thats what story is with out giving to much away. now the characters the characters for me were a mixed bag there were some I enjoyed and there were some I really did not care about. the one thing I really like about thisanime was the main female lead was not trying to get with the main character at first. which I really liked because it was different and not the same as other romantic anime. I really like the art and sound no problems here now lets talk about what I did not like.  the first thing were some of the characters that I felt really did not need to be in the anime lacked relevance to the story. next the major thing I did not like with this anime was at some points I felt as they were trying to force conflict and drama into the story it just felt forced. other thing I like and this comes down to personal preference is there is love triangle in this anime. Overall I really enjoyed this anime but the problems were apparent noticeably trying to force some conflict and drama and some of the characters were not relevant to the story.

There are times when I'm watching an anime and want two characters to be together, and then they don't get together. But this time around, I really don't want the characters to be together, and they get together. The world is a backwards, cruel place.
Golden Time! The anime about love, loss, and well, memory loss. The story is mainly about Banri who get's hit by a moped and ends up falling off a bridge and surviving, but in turn loses his memories. He then goes to the hospital and months later gets sent out to college in Tokyo where he finds a new life andthen some. While in tokyo he meets many new friends and even gets a girlfriend, but what he doesn't know is that soon he will be having a war within himself to find truth. It's a very compelling story with detailed characters, but if only the characters were good.


For the characters I really just feel like saying, I love them, but I also hate them. See, the characters here are very well written, but what they do and how they might act with one another, just doesn't feel right. Specially if we're talking about Banri. I won't go too much more in-depth because this anime relies heavy on it's characters, but I'd say it's a bitter-sweet mix of good and bad overall.


The first OP was, alright. I didn't really get sucked into it all that much, but the second OP was kinda...bad. For me, it just wasn't catchy, but the visuals worked. As for the visuals, I liked them, but they weren't overly done, just right for this show.


Overall I'd say this anime left a bitter-sweet feeling in me. I wasn't too happy with the ending, but it ended up working out for everyone. I will only recommend you watch this if you like a good romance anime and a great story.

I do not know exactly where to start with this anime. From beginning to end i really loved everything about it. This was my first romance anime that i have watched and boy was I lucky. Seeing a 7.92 rating may scare off some people, but this anime is truly one of a kind. I would like to keep this review short and to the point for those eager to watch this show.
Story: 9/10
The story was very unique and well written. I went into this anime with no insight, and really wanted it to just grab me and hook me in. From the very beginningI felt as if i was feeling exactly what Tada Banri was feeling. I could kind of relate with the character since i am in college myself. Between Tada Banri trying to keep real to himself, The comedic relief, and the really well written drama scenes, i found myself loving this show more and more every episode.


Art: 9/10

The art was high quality and well drawn. Not many lazy moments found here


Sound: 7/10

The music was average, but i loved the all the intros and outros of the show. On top of that the voice acting is what makes up for the average sound throughout the show. I heard genuine laughs along with passionate discussions about the relationships.


Characters: 9/10

Banri Tada and Koko Kaga were both good protagonists. I loved their relationship and how they actually tried to workout difficulties like an actual couple instead of being mad at each other one day, then in the next episode be fine with each other without and real communication.


Enjoyment: 10/10

Overall this will go down as one of my favorite anime i have watched. I felt genuine happiness watching this anime through. I felt the characters emotions play through the screen and was really moved to click on the next episode. Hopefully when you begin to watch this show you will feel the same way.


Overall: 10/10

Soooo... Their are 2 sides of people 1) They will love this anime and will make them cry cuz of the feels. 2) Will think it's just meh.
So the anime itself is about a boy named Tada Banri who lost all of his memories by getting into a accident. The story itself tells about his life in college. The PLOT in my perception was almost fluent. I am not a type who watches a lot of romance anime, but I wanted to give it a go. And wasn't disappointed. So In conclusion I'm thinking that I still suck on reviews, but I'll try to improve... But anyhow you're a student? Have nothing to do? Have troubles with gf/bf? Give it a go you might see something that will help you.

This is going to be my first review so I hope you will find it helpful. This review is going to be on the anime “Golden Time” I will also keep it spoiler free for the people who haven’t yet watched it.
Story-9
The story is based around a student named Tada Barni and his experience in university. He meets many interesting characters on the way. He crosses his paths with a girl named Kaga Koko and starts to develop feelings towards her. (I won’t talk about that too much as it will spoil the story). The story is very enjoyable and has many plot twists, itis heavily based around friendships and love. The MC (Tada Barni) Is suffering from amnesia due to an accident that happened beforehand. He then moves into Tokyo (where the story is set) to continue his life without any memory of the past. This is were he meets Linda Senpai his crush from high school (before the accident) not knowing it is her. Later on he discovers their relationship due to photos from high school. Now he is facing a difficult decision on wether to stay with his present girlfriend or go back to the feelings he had years ago. 


Art-8

The art suits the characters well and the animation is great. Although there are places to improve as certain facial expressions and as obvious as they should be, it is quality, the attention to detail is very good faces are well designed; the small nose really suits. In my opinion the art isn’t the most important factor of a good anime but it’s nice to have - this anime did the job well. The environment is detailed and overall image is crisp. One thing that could have been better is the looks of the characters as if you removed the hair the characters (mainly females) would be pretty similar. Little to no CGI and I am very grateful for that.


Sound-7

The sound of the voice suits the personality of the characters (Furukawa, makoto voicing Tada Barni and Horie, Yui voicing Kaga Koko). Both the beginning and the ending have a nice and memorable melody. Although I think that they could have improved on that and made it even more enjoyable. The sounds of the environment are accurate and not once have I realised any delay between the animation and the sound. Background music is ok although it could have been a lot better. In some scenes, such as the ones where the two mc’s were close to each other, the music could have been louder and stand out more. Overall the sound was good but music and certain sound effects could have been a lot better (although everything was enjoyable).


Character-10

Each character (especially the MC’s) have a very in-depth explanation of their background. I’ve been drawn closely to the characters, especially Tada Barni. I feel as if theres a literal bond between me and the mc, I’ve cried when he did and laughed when he did. Every character has a strong side and a weak one wether it is a emotional or psychical one. Each character is different and lovable. This is a very strong aspect of this anime as this is the reason that it’s a must watch in my opinion.


Enjoyment-10

I’ve cried my eyes out in the ending. It is a emotional roller coaster, this anime was just great I watched it in one sitting I just had to know what will happen next. I was glued to the screen. I’m planing to rewatch it, it’s a gem, a must-watch. I enjoyed every second of it and just had to write a review in it or I would never forgive myself.


Overall-9

I’m giving it a 9 because although the story is great I was kind of disappointed with the songs within. I love it ad you have to watch it I guarantee you will love it just as much as I so - if not more. While watching it have a “Golden Time”.



As this is my first review I would appreciate if you would mark it as helpfull or made any comments about what you think.

Thank you for reading!

So, the only times i actually scream at my TV are when I’m watching my favorite teams and they’re being stupid. I’ve never actually gotten mad at a show before. I got mad at this show a couple times, mostly at Banri. Now everyone has their own obstacles and trials that they have to get through in their life and Banri had his. I sort of felt like maybe I needed a little more explanation as to why Banri was so afraid of being forgotten. When I’m saying that, I’m talking about that incident in high school before his accident that I’m not supposed totalk about because this is a review. But what I’m trying to say is, this anime really got to me. It really is a show that, if you’re younger, or if you’re just inexperienced in love, you’re not going to get it on the level that they’re trying to show you. Accept it, you won’t. But don’t let that stop you from watching.


It was really fun to watch this because it’s not your typical high school romantic comedy anime that you always see, and to be honest, we need more of these. I felt like the story flowed really well, the animation itself was really well put together; And it was very engaging. So engagin in fact, that I seriously considered dropping it a few times. Remember me saying I screamed at the TV? Well, that’s because I found the characters so natural and realistic to my own experiences in my life that it almost felt Ike it could be something you’d actually see on the street between two people and not just something in an anime that makes you go, “well that would never happen in real life.” Don’t take me saying that I almost dropped it as a negative score against the anime because it most certainly isn’t.


Also, I found the inconvenience and utter frustration of Banri’s lapses in his memory utterly perfect. It’s so very real. It shows how terribly frustrating a traumatic brain injury can be for not just people around the person experiencing episodes like that, but how terrifying and upsetting it is for the person experiiencing them. It pissed me off, and nagged me even more.


The anime’s biggest asset is showing how vital it is for people who are in love to never, ever give up on each other. No matter how painful, agonizing, heart-wrenching; infuriating the situation or circumstance, you love and accept the person for who they are and always stay by their side. Y’all know who I’m talking about if you’ve watched it. The anime’s second biggest asset is showing just how powerful it is when people grow as individuals out of love because of another person. It shows how being selfish and having an ego really doesn’t matter. When you acrifice for someone in any capacity, you grow and become a better person yourself. 


Golden Time is now one of my favorites. I hope that it will become one of yours too and that you’ll understand the messages that it’s trying to teach you. This one, to me, is a real masterpiece.

DEAR LORD IN HEAVEN, WHAT TO SAY ABOUT THIS GIFT FROM GOD THAT IS GOLDEN TIME!!! (this is my 1st review so bear with me, and i hope youll take the time to read all of it)
story - 9. well this is a very romantic anime to say the least. theres so many twists you could never imagine and sometimes you just want to strangle the characters but i guess thats part of what makes it so great!! A very enjoyable show with a unique story is how i would summarize Golden Time. I felt drawn into the story and i really enjoyed the MC Tada Banri. It was a wonderful anime with sweet, warm, and even bitter moments that all meshed together to create something special. The ending didn't really live up to the rest of the anime, but it didnt stop me from enjoying the show altogether. With a better ending i feel like this anime could have been alot better, but i feel its still worth a watch

Golden Time somehow managed to make me feel all the things the characters felt.  Most romantic comedies are somewhat ridiculous in nature.  While some aspects of this show were indeed a bit unbelievable, I never felt that the characters themselves were.  I know a girl just like Kaga Koko, I've felt the emotions that all the characters felt in this show.  From avoiding an obsessive girl, to the hurt of rejection, the holding back feelings for the sake of others, the pain that secrets cause, the pain of seeing someone you love with someone else, finding someone you can be yourselfwith, and so many more.  I could completely relate to everything this show was about.  The characters are very strongly written, and even though the storyline was something that would probably never happen in real life it always seemed like there was a chance something similar could happen.   I completely loved the entire show, and the only thing I thought could have been done better was the ending.  It isn't a completely failed ending it just adds a few things in that are a bit too far out there to be easily looked past and accepted.\n\n
This is a wonderful show however and I hope everyone takes the time to give it a try!

I honestly had my doubts about any success of this series, and I certainly found the first four episodes slow-moving. But not that the series has ended, I'm sad and satisfied at the same time!
Besides the brilliant animation, Golden Time stands out for it's laugh-out-loud comedy, in-depth character development, and inspiring story of true love. It's very rare to find a romantic comedy anime that stays this good until the heart-warming and tear-making ending, so enjoy every second of it!
What's truly enjoyable about this anime that few rom-com's fail to achieve is character development. The characters change a lot over-time, most of the time forthe better. This helps keep the show fresh and much more enjoyable to watch. 


The only down-side to this anime is how slow it is for the first four episodes. It's very easy to despise the lead characters in the first four episodes, especially Koko. You also get turned off when you find out that Banri has amnesia, which rarely works out in anime's. 


But once Banri slowly regains his memories and when other characters start to get involved in his personal life, it truly becomes an anime you don't want to stop watching.


Even if you can't handle watching the first four episodes, I would still recommend skimming over the plot and then going to episode four. That's when the series becomes it's best. 


The next twenty episodes in the series are where relationships change, characters develop, you get hit in the head with the "metaphorical baseball bat of feels" numerous times, and you realize that the story is more that what you thought it was going to be in the beginning. 


In conclusion, I'm not giving this anime a 5-star for no reason. It truly is one of the best anime's out there that has everything you're looking for and stays true to itself to the end. 


THE VERDICT:

+ Brilliant Animation

+ Heart-Warming Story

+ No Cliche's Except For Love Triangle and Pink Hair

+ Excellent Character Development

- Slow and Painful Beginnings


SCORE: 9/10

I heard Golden Time was written by the same person who wrote Toradora, this information had me very excited as I very much loved Toradora. I started watching Golden Time while it was airing, say when it was at about 6 episodes in. I liked it, I loved it. Koko quickly won me over, the amnesia story was interesting but then as I continued to watch the show kept going in different direction, it was somewhat of a rollercoaster of excitement and poorly done drama. Knowing the truth about Banri and Linda, the way their personified his amnesia and all sorts of other little thingsgradual made me grow tired of this anime. I like the characters, I want to like them more -- but, I feel as though Koko and Banri's emotions are very unrealistic. I very much focus on character development, and as characters I feel Koko and Banri fail, big time. Linda is a tad dissappointing in the end, too. I don't want to spoil anything, but I feel as though this anime was poorly done and lacked a sense of realism, not to mention the drama and whatnot is cheesy and makes little sense. I liked it very much at first, but in the end I realized it didn't live up to Toradora and tried a little hard to copy it's success (maybe).

Golden Time. To get it out of the way and make it very clear, I love this show. I could very well put it in my favorite anime list with ease. It has some of the best characters, character interaction and honest to god one of the best portrayals of a romantic relationship I have ever seen, in anime or otherwise.
Does it have flaws? Of course it does. You could say that (not spoilers, but heads up) the final episode is a bit stuffed with content, that the scene at the bridge doesn't make sense (I personally interpreted in a way that I think makestotal sense, but that's just me) and that (maybe spoilers) ghost Banri is kind of out of place. These are for the most part, valid complaints. Hell if you hate amnesia story lines you may dislike the show altogether.


But even the best things have faults, but they are still the best because everything else they do makes the faults not be there. I mentioned the romantic portrayal and I wasn't exaggerating. Banri and Kouko's relationship, from the minute they meet till the last scene of the show is incredible to watch. A lot has to do with the writing and the characters. Some of the scenes that these two share are so, to not have any other word to really express it, human. When they talk casually, when they kiss, when they fight, every moment is in a way so realistic and honest and makes the relationship such and incredible experience to behold. One of the greatest things about it, is that we don't just see the classic "they got together, happiness", no, this show goes deep into a relationship between young adults and the challenges that people go through. 


Other than that (which honestly, if an amazing romance doesn't make you want to watch a romance anime, I honestly don't know what to tell you) the other characters are also very likable and again, very human. They go through situations that I have gone through or seen other people go through and it still keeps the drama engaging. That is a really hard balance to find, but the writers do a great job with it. 


The art style is very beautiful and well animated, as to expect from JC Staff. It's not perfect (JC Staff doesn't have the budget of Kyoto Animation), but 

I recommend anybody who read the description of the show and found a minimal amount of interest to see this, you owe it to yourself.

Golden Time
The story revolves around Tada Banri; recently graduated from high school, he was injured in an unfortunate accident, causing all of his memories to be forgotten. When we meet him, he's in Tokyo attending a private Law School.
With Tada Banri, we have the beautiful, intoxicatingly clingy, absolutely amazing Kaga Kouko. It's pretty easy for me to say that I love her. The clingy attribute is something I absolutely like and a girl like Kaga, just amazing really! For the rest of the cast we have Yanagisawa Mitsuo, Linda, Oka Chinami and 2D Kun. Except for 2D Kun, everyone goes through troubles and issues oftheir own, sometimes involving Tada Banri, other times involving other members of the gang.


I enjoyed the way the story went. Although if the last episode didn't happen like it did, I would have been absolutely infuriated with this anime; it'd be the first anime that I have serious issues with.


The seiyu in Golden Time did a fantastic job. Aside from when Tada Banri has to scream, the seiyu do a good job. I enjoyed listening to them all and the way that they all handle certain scenes, really moving performances at times. Their ability to change expressions in their voice, really lends to the talent involved for sure, so again, amazing performance.


Unfortunately, I don't feel the same about the animation. It's the first anime I've seen where I feel like, "you know, this really isn't all that amazing". It's not bad, but I can't say it's incredible. With the animation is the art style used too, and it was okay as well. Colors used were nice, mostly vibrant with popping colors, it's very pleasing to watch. Sometimes the way scenes were animated, it made Golden Time look older than the year it was really aired in, I found that interesting.


The music in Golden Time is pretty good though. Both Endings and both Openings used are phenomenal pieces of music and I listened to them over and over and over again. The ambient sounds in Golden Time were nice, but like most anime, I was either caught up in the experience, or in this case, losing my mind over the last 4 episodes and the arc about Tada Banri that I didn't really listen to the music. Even though that may be true, I still feel like what I did hear and what was used, was very good indeed. Big props to the OP and ED though, freaking amazing.


I really enjoyed the Tea Club scenes in Golden Time, every time the Tea Club was involved, I couldn't help but just laugh out loud in hysterical fashion, they're truly funny and I'm glad they were apart some good moments. Even though I feel like the animation was lacking, there were great reaction faces and other moments in which hysterical moments were created. A lot of funny and plain out fun can be experienced watching Golden Time, so that's always a plus!


Overall, Golden Time is a good anime, though if you plan to watch it, please don't go to bed if you're reaching episode 20. Unless you like the way that type of story goes, finish the entire thing, because what they (Producers/Writers) tried to pull was awful and not needed at all. It did end the way I wanted it to and because of that (very selfish reason I know), I give this anime a huge thumbs up. All the stories told, the arcs that we go through, I feel like they're really well done.


Kaga Kouko

When I bought this one I did not expect to find what I did, I read no reviews, and I think I bought it for the girl on the cover, she looked kinda cute. So I took a chance... 
This has got to be one of the more powerful anime I've watched. And its one of the few where I simply cannot agree with anything in the lower rated reviews. 
Normally I go for the really wacky characters, this one doesn't really have those to the extent of some of my other favorites of this genre like Toradora or Chunibyo or Pet Girl of SakuraHall. instead it focuses on a deeper more dramatic storyline. Much more adult, less childlike, and I don't mean that in terms of Hentai. 


But really the backstory and the ghost self, and all the little but meaningful details in between are so intensive. Perhaps its because... I have had a girlfriend like Koko, and girls from the past like Linda. They did them very well. 


This one left me haunted and thinking about it much longer than when the anime ended. I think the only other anime that did that to me was Kanon and it was for the same reasons. Leaving them behind and then coming back years later and realizing the enormous impact you'd had in their lives for good or bad. 


The art was excellent, as was the story and the character development, 


I don't know if I can watch this one again... but not because it sucks or anything like that... but because it may just be too painful... again much like Kanon was for me.

What can I say this is probably as close you'll get to perfect from a romance anime. Everything was done to perfection or pretty near so. It is an true emotional experience that most will enjoy. I am not too keen on romance anime  but I gave this one a try and became hooked. 
 One of the most intriguing stories of a romance anime that I have ever seen. It is filled with twists including a bit of weird amnesia. While starting off light hearted it starts taking darker more serious turns after a few episodes. It shows how arelationship isn't always perfect, that their are issues that can complicate it. The comedy while not perfect was pretty good. There was a great variation with the types of episodes they made. It did not fall into the common tropes of the genre frequently. The anime also made you wonder "will the couple stay together?" or "what happens next?". The tension rises high near the end especially the last few episodes which had me on the edge of my seat. But the end needed to be fleshed out more because it felt a bit crammed together.


 The characters highlight the experience as they are are some of the most relatable and likable characters as well, they all have personal struggles and most create conflicts among the group. Their interactions are dramatic but fit and seem like those of real college students. Pretty much all the characters have decent back stories and unique personalities. When they show an emotion you can feel the weight of their sadness or happiness. There are a few minor characters that were enjoyable but other than that the side characters were lack luster.


  The art is great, using many bright colors that give off a happy vibe. I never felt like the artists got lazy or missed details. I was however not left with a feeling of aw besides the openings. The music was not great but they looked gorgeous.


  So if you enjoy emotional yet comedic romanctic anime with bright colors give Golden Time a try

This review's more for personal use but feel free to read it and criticize what I liked/didn't like about this anime. SPOILERS**
I liked the idea of this anime, the idea that when you lose you're memories you become a completely different person. The idea is great because it forces the generation of character development, it adds the chance for things from before memory loss to come into play adding drama and furthering development and the way it was used really worked in some parts of this show.
The reason this show isn't 10/10 is basically because the explanation for ghost Banri/the memories of Banri's previous lifeis really bad, the show kinda drops it in there and you might not notice that ghost Banri is really doing anything other than being a sort of narrator. Later on in the show when Banri starts getting his memories back and the 2 personalities are battling for control of Banri's body you realise what's actually going on and the show gets a lot better because you can understand the drama and emotions a lot more clearly.


The shows romance is actually quite well done although i thought Banri kinda jumped the gun a bit when he first confessing to Koko because they don't really know each other that well but i guess it set the pace for the rest of the show, there were a lot of twist's and turns in the show and it made for some good drama however i do feel it was a bit compressed compared to other anime but this was actually a relief because instead of longing out the part where Koko liked Kana but obviously nothing was going to happen which could be the basis for a whole show they wrapped it up quite quickly and moved on instead of having 4 episodes where the characters are just fussing about in a hot spring or something.


Another random thing i liked about this show was that it was actually mature, the people in a relationship actually kissed and didn't hold hands for the entire show and then having 1 kiss in the penultimate scene.


All in all a great show with some messy execution but lots of drama and good deep characters. Probably good to re-watch as you understand the most confusing bit already.

8.5/10

This is my second favorite anime ( behind SAO ), and for a very good reason. It is the only anime that has made me cry like a little girl. I'm not saying that I didn't tear up during some moments is SAO or Clannad, or many othera, but this one made me really cry. I watched all episodes in one afternoon, and they managed to keep me hoked all the way. I did not feel that a single episode was dull. I could really feel the pain and joy of the characters, evidenced by my gleeful bawling during the final scenes. The relationship buildingwas stellar, the fact that the main couple gets together fairly early on makes for a nice change of pace, and created something i desperately craved for, a relationship romance, not the tipical high school "romance" anime, in wich the couple only becomes a couple on the last few episodes.\n\n
TL;DR Nice change of pace, awesome story and characters, messes with your feelings quite a bit, second best anime couple.💏

Let me start off by saying that Golden Time is not a bad anime. It's a decent romcom and coming-of-age-and-finding-your-true-self story if nothing else. The thing with it is, it's not all what it could be. It has a lot of potential in it the authors failed to realize, and it constantly falls short of the expectations it sets itself for the viewer and therefore can be watching it is extremely frustrating at times, yet it definitely has its moments and a lot of good points. The reason I gave it a 5 is not because it's really mediocre; while it's definitely nothing too specialeither, the main reason is that for every great point of Golden Time there's a bad point too. Good and bad in this anime kind of cancel each other out, making it a 5 not in terms of medicority, but in terms of being very mixed. 


If you like psychological anime dealing heavily with characters' psyche and emotional growth, this might be something for you. The controversial storyline revolves around the main character Tada Banri and his medical condition that I personally feel is rather used as a metaphor or a device to explore such topics as dwelling on the past and learning to let go of it, early adulthood and the associated problems of still being a child at mind and heart but having to grow up and conform to society's norms, carving out a place for yourself in this world, identity troubles, acceping life, the people around you and yourself for what it all is and many more quite profound questions. Mind you, it only touches upon these topics and does not discuss them at length, but at its best the show delivers on making the viewer consider some important questions, offer an interesting perspective on them through characters' words and actions and entertain with light-hearted slice-of-life sketches peppered with light humour and nostalgia that are quite heartwarming. 


The worst thing about the show, in my opinion, is that it can't decide what it wants to be and ends up being nothing, or, rather, tries to be everything at once and ends up falling short on a lot of fronts and becomes a poorly sewn together patchwork of episodes further ruined by uneven pacing. There's tangible tension between the introspective character-study side of Golden Time trying to be serious and profound, and the romcom part of it. The authors have completely failed to properly combine these two parts of it, and one ends up competing with, and ultimately ruining the other. The mood constantly switches between quite heavy drama and light-hearted silliness, which makes it very difficult to make either of them believable and enjoyable. In the end, both parts look abrupt and forced, although at some fine moments you get honestly moved or can laugh with characters as they show their softer, dorky sides. The build-up to development of both sides suffers from lack of proper exposition and explanation and extreme abruptness, which makes both profoundly underwhelming, In a way, Golden Time is bipolar, violently swinging between its two extremes, with the end result of feeling sloppy and rushed.


24 episodes seem to be too much. In some episodes, the strain to fill out the 20 minutes is evident through unnecessary exposition about irrelevant stuff that could easily be left out in favor of developing the characters and their relationships, for ultimately this kind of anime stands or falls depending on whether this is done properly. In Golden Time, sometimes it is, but most of the times there's either too much or too little of something. The dialogues often feel bland and underwhelming. For a show that deals a lot with the theme of past, the flashbacks feel forced, too short and lacking the proper exposition to understand the characters' motivation and personalities.


The primary genre of Golden Time being romantic comedy, it disappoints quite a lot. Romantic comedies are meant to explore a budding romance in a thrilling way, often using love triangles as a device to ramp up the tension and excitement. While I do appreciate that authors discarded the overused "will they or won't they" cliche that plagues the genre by the making the main characters a couple less than one third into the story, they did so at the expense of a thorough build-up towards the relationship which ends up barely believable. The love story of the main characters will not make your heart beat faster, and the love life of the support cast is even less developed and is only outlined very generally, appearing only when the author seems to have some spare time from exploring the main couple's relationship, making the timing, pacing and spread of the support cast terrible. The worst thing is, is that authours end up relying on the "love triangle" device at the heart of the series to spice it up, however, it has got to be the most pathetically botched attempt at using it in the history of anime romcoms. That is, the OP erases all and any doubts one could have about how the love triangle will be resolved: as OP is annoyingly centered on the female main character and the only other character to appear there is the male lead, and they do nothing but express their love for each other in the opening animation, well... I mean, they could have thrown other characters in there too just to make it less obvious. If the main couple stubbornly appears acting all lovey-dovey every time in the beginning, there can be no tension whatsoever regarding the love triangle. It just spoils it big time and all attempts at creating suspense about who ends up with whom just seem really pathetic after this.


To me personally, the characters were both what made Golden Time very enjoyable and very annoying to watch. At times, they are incredibly sincere and very human, and their antics set against the backdrop of uneventful everyday university life make them very lovable and relatable. Through the main plot device, the main character's medical condition, this title goes to show just how precious even the most ordinary and unremarkable everyday life can be. No one in the show is perfect, no one has superpowers, but they all have their quirks and care for each other in their own special ways, and the beauty of Golden Time is that through this it expresses the happiness that can be found in small things very believably. For this, and for all the funny moments where authors let the characters' personalities shine and interact in hilarious ways, I loved this anime. However, I really hate it when this happens, but sometimes some characters are just not my cup of tea and it just ruins it for me. This was the case here. Again, from the very beginning, i.e. since I first saw the OP and the poster, I knew it was all going to revolve around the female lead, who is going to take up most of the time. That is indeed the case, and I just can't bring myself to like her. The writers obviously did their best to develop her character, but all their best efforts couldn't save her for me. At best, there are times when she's less annoying than usual, and it's cute when she's upset about doing something wrong, because you do realize she's not a bad person and that she cares and feels too and is by no means a cardboard cliche character, but... They tried to porrtray her as a very lonely character who needs love and understanding and people who can see past her very bitchy and arrogant exterior and reach out for her, they made hints that she may have some problems at home, but they never actually explore it. I never saw why she should feel lonely and never understood why the writers decided she deserves any sympathy. From the story, it is very obvious that she is the root of her own problems, and she never learns from her mistakes. She is clingy, annoying, downright parasitic and pretty much good-for-nothing dumb bimbo\spoiled princess. She is supposed to also be very caring and loving, but the way she expresses her love is always cringeworthy: she just smothers the one she loves and as a viewer you are supposed to somehow admire and praise her for being overbearing. Sorry guys, I just don't buy it. I don't see any reason why it all should revolve around her. The rest of the cast I loved, the main character is finely analyzed and well fleshed-out, his battle with his insecurities believable and touching. Linda, Yana-san, 2D-kun, Nana-sempai - everyone from the supporting cast was fresh, cute, very human, but really underused. I am convinced that too much screen time was wasted on the female lead that had nothing interesting to say. She was good as a comic relief, but the rest of the gang had more to offer.


The final episode was a disaster. You can see the end coming from a hundred miles away and it's the most disappointing cliched let-down you could imagine. It is supposed to tie up all lose ends and provide a happy ending for evertone, but it is just unnatural and feels very forced and just wrong. I might have given Golden Time a higher rating if the last episode, especially the later half of it didn't exist. It is boring, all kinds of stupid and does not serve to bring home the point of the anime at all. 


All in all, it is a nice anime that has a lot of undeveloped potential. People who like tsundere characters, slice-of-life genre, coming-of-age stories and are nostalgic about college life will probably enjoy it immensely. It gives food for thought. However, the many shortcomings will also probably frustrate you, so beware!

So, this was an interesting anime. 
There's essentially two things about this anime that make it stand out:
One, the character romance is really bad, and even cringe-worthy.
And two, the comedy, when it tries to be funny, is actually really funny!
Golden time is supposed to be a romantic comedy. When it tries to be funny, it succeeds fairly well on the comedy side, and can actually be quite hilarious! There are some instances in this show that are really, really funny, and just totally had me shrieking with laughter. 
On the other hand, on the romance side of things, that's where this anime really fails. Alot of people have pointed out that, "well at least the main characters pursue the same relationship for the whole story..." Well yeah, but it's a really bad, terrible forced relationship.


Simply put, Golden Time is kind of a love triangle. You have Guy A and Girl A and Girl B. 


Guy A and Girl A have genuine chemistry together, and a history together. However, Girl A is a bit of a tsundere (someone who's initially cold, while gradually showing their warm side) and is kind of in denial about how much she really cares about (and loves) Guy A. 


But the problem comes in, when Girl A takes so long to be honest about her feelings for Guy A, and so Guy A ends up dating (settling for) Girl B. 


And this is where the romance just kind of goes south. Guy A and Girl B basically have no chemistry at all, and he spends his entire time thinking about Girl A whom he really loves, and pretty much just kind of humors Girl B. Meanwhile, Girl B is kind of crazy and obsessive and after spending so much time with Guy A it becomes apparent that she's been with him so long that he feels really guilty about leaving her, and so they just kind of keep going, even though they have no chemistry at all. 


He's clearly not into her, but they just keep going with the relationship. Meanwhile, Guy A has serious health problems due to a past accident, and whenever he needs real help and support the first person he turns to is Girl A. 


Really, as a romance, this anime is a tragedy. The entire time you want Guy A and Girl A to be together, and it just never happens, and so the relationship between Guy A and Girl B just seems really forced, awkward, unnatural, and just sad really. 


You feel like they're just settling for less and choosing to be sad rather than really listening to their heart and being with the person who really makes them happy. 


And that's really the fatality of this anime, the sadness that underlines it when it becomes clear that the main characters really *aren't* going to do the right thing and be with the person they *really* care about... It just puts a damper on the comedy which is otherwise the real highlight of the show. 


It leaves you feeling disappointed, and kind of sad, rather than satisfied. 


And despite some strong humor, the disappointment in the characters pulls the anime down a lot from the build up the that humor makes. 


Overall, it was somewhat enjoyable to watch, but it was more like a 6. It really could have been a lot better and it wasn't.


The whole thing just kind of has this overlay of sadness. Like: "We'd really like to be together, but alas... we cannot. For... no apparent reason really."
