This is my 1st review so here goes. Hopefully it isn't too long....
   I read all of the reviews for this before watching it. I started watching it accidentally because I was testing out  my soundbar for my 4k HDTV which has been having connection issues. I just randomly clicked on a title without reading the name & picked the 1st episode for testing. I only watched the part when they were handing out the roses. Since it wasn't on my plan to watch list I didn't know the name of it or anything else. When I finally got my soundbar workingright again about halfway through epi #1 I got curious & read the reviews. I took a chance on watching it after some of the negative reviews & I hafta say I'm soooo glad I did. 


STORY 9:  I really liked the plot of this. I could especially relate to Banri because I was in a really bad fire where I almost lost my life & I once had really short term amnesia. I liked all the subtle nuances of having to mentally piece yourself back together especially when: 



   1. You really have no clues to how you should feel & react to life in general.

   2. You don't know who you are now. 

   3. You don't know who you were before the accident even though there is 

       evidence & people trying to give you clues.

   4. You can't trust yourself or anything you currently feel or experience as being your "real life".

   5. You are extremely confused, frustrated, fearful, anxious, & at times very angry or depressed. 



   Due to all the above reasons the reactions of those who knew you before might frighten you so naturally you want to run & hide from yourself. Here's the problem where do you run to to escape from your own mind & life???!!! Well obviously they can't have the main character try to commit suicide cause that would make this Romantic/Comedy too deep to early on I guess. SO instead they turn his past self into a ghost version & it silently watches his current self without being able to interact at all for almost the entire show. I saw this "ghost" as his subconscious mind trying to regain his memories & sense of self. It was also good as flashback points which showed who he was before he fell off the bridge.


   I was actually happy that Banri was as strong mentally as he was because he could've been a complete basket case instead of just freaking out occasionally.  Speaking of basket cases we get the other lead his girlfriend, Kouko. Wow what can I say she starts the show off by hitting Mitsuo several times in the face with a bouquet of red roses right in front of Banri which is how they kinda meet btw. Not only that but we quickly find out she is basically stalking Mitsuo by attending the same college & oh it just gets worse as we go along. At 1st I thought OMG she's completely nuts how can anyone want to date her but by a bit past midway through I started to see that her idiocy, possessiveness, jealousy, & general insecure self gives Banri a sense of worth because Kouko so "desperately" LOVES him & NEEDS him that she does crazy stuff because of it.  It allows Banri to NOT hafta think about who he is right now. He just has to get carried along in Kouko's intense feelings & it overshadows & fills in this huge hole he has inside because of his amnesia. The old saying it takes one to know one comes to mind here because in a way Banri is just as crazy as Kouko is. I also really like all the supporting characters in this show & how they affected Banri's & Kouko's behavior throughout the series. Even the next door neighbor, Nana, had a interesting role to play as she rescues him mentally & takes him to the hospital once as well. 


   Also the the strange plot elements like the whole cult thing & the cursing yourself when you are a ghost thing was really interesting as it played out & so terribly that it scared me quite a bit. I mean who hasn't gotten very angry at someone & said, "I'm going to haunt you when I die!", just to spite them. I know I have at least once or twice. It was parts like these that gave this short run series a really unique plot which can be hard to find these days. I really wish that they had continued for at least another season to show how Banri & everyone else was adjusting to his getting all his memories back at the end. I mean do you go back to your old life & quit college if that wasn't in your past or do you cut off all the ties you made while you had no past memories. How would you react to all this. What would you do in this exact situation at that exact moment given what little you have to go on. How do you trust your decisions & those around you. Do you trust people to understand what you are going through or do you fear their reactions to you?! It is all very complicated stuff...



ART  7:   What can I say the animation was good, backgrounds were appropriate but nothing particularly stood out except I really like Woodstock Cafe where Chinami works for some reason maybe cause the front door was all artsy far-sty & just seemed like really nice & fun place to hang out. Other than that I never really gave it much thought. Probably cause I was too caught up in what was happening & the dialogue that I didn't get bored at all (which is when I usually find myself mindless staring at the artwork) like I can in a lot of the repetitive series. 



SOUND 7:   Well this is the 1 area I tend to ignore cause I usually marathon shows till the end of at least the 1st 2 seasons. I normally skip the OP & ED songs to save time but this time I listened to them both a few times. Although I hafta say I really hated the high pitched child-like voice in the OP song until I realized that was just how Kuoko acted most of the time. I thought the lyrics were good & fit the series well. The voice acting was really good & I always watch my anime subbed. I really liked Mitsuo voiced by Ishikawa, Kaito.



CHARACTERS 9:    What can I say I wish that I had several of the supporting cast as my actual friends irl. Especially Nana, Mitsuo, & Takaya AKA 2D. Nana with her angry punk/goth appearance reminded me a bit of my younger self before I learned how to love myself. Personally I would never date anyone like Kouko or Chinami as I hate overly girly characters. I also don't do crazy, jealous, or possessive types because I'm very independent. I was happy to see the main girl, Kouko wasn't the atypical weak willed & completely forgettable anime female lead.  As far as Banri is concerned he was very interesting. I found myself crying more than I wanted to surprisingly especially as this is labeled a comedy. I felt it had a lot of Tragedy moments to it as well. I guess this is where the Seinen label comes from as I was constantly thinking & reevaluating my own life based on things that Banri was learning about himself. Mostly I related very well to how he resolved & reacted to things. I would have totally ran after Kouko after she broke up with me though. I'm not sure if I could go out with someone with amnesia considering my past. It might just be too painful. I would definitely date Mitsuo as he is just my type besides the rich thing which I could care less about. I really enjoyed how Mitsuo kept making a mess out of trying to find a girlfriend. That awkwardness really works for me.  2D was pretty nice as well especially how he cared so deeply about keeping their group together. I could also relate to how he saw the "3D world" as I sometimes feel like that myself. Other than that even some of the minor characters were very nice like the president of the Festival club & those 2 crazy chics from the tea club were a total riot not to mention creepy as hell! Please don't let me ever hafta go through what poor Banri & 2D did... 



ENJOYMENT & OVERALL 8:    Like I have already mentioned unique plot, lots, & lots to think about even after you finish the series, high relatability to characters & plot. Scary moments, happy moments, angry moments, confusion the list of emotions goes on & on. For a Seinen it definitely lived up to its label. For a Romance it did a pretty good job. It was alright in the Comedy sense but I'm not partial to Comedies anyways so I'm most likely biased about them. Overall I highly suggest you think about watching this as it might just teach you a few things about your own life & how tragedies & Romance mixed together can change everything you know about yourself & life in general. For those of you who have had to deal with any mental issues that greatly affect or affected your decisions & life I think you will get a lot out of watching this unique gem of a series. Even if you haven't had mental problems you may still learn a few things about yourself. I think I will go see if the manga continues on past the show. I really hope it does...

GOLDEN TIME 
Golden time is truly a masterpiece to me. I know many disagree with myself but for those that disliked it, you probably were watching with a critic mind. I myself had no bias going into this as it was my first romantic anime, now after watching essentially all the good ones I've come back to review this.
PROS
Golden time just does so much right. It has just the right amount of comedy, enough that it'll take some weight off during the intense moments. The romance is unparalleled, it hits you in all the right places and has so much to offer. It's underlying mentalillness themes are beautifully incorporated. For an anime to have all of this is truly taken for granted, I don't know one other anime that has done all of this as well as golden time has, 'Orange' had great underlying themes however its love story wasn't nearly as strong. 'You lie in April' another masterpiece, had perfect emotions and its underlying themes were just as strong however it's comedy lacked effect as I never laughed as hard as I did with Golden time.\n\n
CONS \n
The only true con I can give Golden Time is that at times it does get a little repetitive however I feel that it's all a part of the character development necessary in the end.\n\n
SHOULD YOU WATCH?\n
Yes, absolutely. Go in with a open mind and relax, don't take things like a critic just enjoy whats there!

Golden Time is one of those rare anime romance shows that are not based in a Japanese high school. Instead, this romance plays out in their college. This setting is something anime viewers rarely get to see and for me at the time of this shows airing that was an enticing prospect.  The college setting isinteresting but does not add or detract to the romance in any way. 


A disclaimer I have to add is that I dropped this around episode 12 when it was airing I seem to remember something happening with a production issue, or I got bored then. Regardless even when I was revisiting this recently, I frequently had to take month-long hiatus between episodes because it didn't particularly hook me.


I should mention I do also like that the parents are involved somewhat too anther rarity in these kinds of shows. The supporting cast is not all that bad either. I liked Yana, 2d kun, and miss ultrasonic just fine.


I think the romance between the main couple Tada Banri and Kaga Kouko could have been much better. Banri has amnesia and can not remember anything before starting college. Amnesia in itself is a pretty tricky plot device to handle well, and this show does not do so. I found losing interest anytime it came into play, often I had to force myself through them because they were not compelling at all.  It, unfortunately, leaves their relationship feeling forced.  


The chemistry between a couple is essential. Otherwise, I am not going to be invested.  It's been an interesting year for me romance anime wise. I have gotten a better idea of what to expect for me to enjoy a romance anime.  Shows like Bunny Girl and MMO Junkie are great examples of good couple chemistry whereas Wotekoi, Tada, and this show end up feeling just Meh.

Golden Time is certainly different. It brings with it beautiful story and character arcs, an amazing OST and is generally amazing. Of course, it has its flaws, but Golden Time is generally what I would consider good anime.
How should I put this... Golden Time was... Different... I'll go on with my general consensus first, the story and character arcs were a-fucking-mazing, no I'm serious, if you ever get bored of rom-com animes then you come *here*. Like, I seriously cannot emphasize the FEELS that ooze from this anime, and be warned, this anime is hazardous if you can't watch it in a short amount oftime because the suspense will literally emotionally paralyze you, no matter which episode you're on until the last. Like, to emphasize how much of just PLOT there is in Golden Time, like, you'd have to create an entire new language. Ploot. That's what I've resorted to calling it. Ploot. (I'll get on to why I gave Story and Character 9s only later)\n
Moving on, the art is nothing special, I mean like take any average 2013-14-ish anime and bam, you've got yourself Golden Time art, but the sound, omg the sound. I'll go in order of ascension. Any and all sound effects or background noises were clearly taken into consideration no matter how trivial. They really nailed the VAs on this one. I think that the voices used for each and every character clearly and well represents their personalities and current emotions at any given dialogue.\n
Now the Audial Masterpiece of Golden Time (yes, so much so that it deserves it's own paragraph). Let me get one thing straight. I hate end songs and opening songs. In general. Openings waste my time and effort to speedscrub and estimate to where the song ends and Endings make it hard for me to concentrate on finding the next ep. But Golden Time's Ending song certainly makes itself an exception. The beautiful Piano solo prelude accompanied by the ensuing contemporary percussion is quick to captivate anyone with anyone who can hear. I won't go much into this one song but I'll say this, it certainly arouses suspense and emotion in the audience (part of the reason why I recommend you finish this anime quickly). The reason Sound only gets a 9 is because the opening song is nothing special. Honestly, if animes can't come up up with good openings and endings they may as well just cut'em out.\n
Now, the flaws. In general, Golden Time's greatest flaw lies in episode 24. The ending. This won't really make sense to those who have yet to watch the anime, but the producers really went easy on us. In episode 24, the producers could've very easily made Golden Time a straight up 10, masterpiece (in the process of doing so emotionally obliterating anyone that watched it). But no, they gave mercy. Think of the ending of "Stranger Than Fiction"... something like that.\n
One thing special about Golden Time is its episode management. I'm pretty sure the producers had a few long sit-down about this. Watching the anime , I realized that the episodes were meticulously scheduled in order. Each episode inadvertently contributed to the ploot somehow. There were no "filler" episodes, and less ploot-significant episodes only served to build suspense for oncoming mass-ploot events. I divide Golden Time into three segments, the Intro, the Progression, and the Drop (sure I guess you can say climax, but its less dramatic). The transitions between each segment are beautifully done, however, so subtle that its unnoticeable except in hindsight.\n
All in all, Golden Time is a flawed, beautiful piece of art anime that really gets you to start thinking about what to do with your time. Especially since it teaches you that time, is golden.

Golden Time was a great work, it could have been a masterpiece.
THIS REVIEW WILL CONTAIN SPOILERS
I think it's pointless to talk about the synopsis since it's already written, let's skip this and let's talk about what I liked and what not about this anime. The story was good, really good, even though amnesia is the cliché I hate the most in anime, I'd say that here it wasn't a problem at all, instead I over-enjoyed it, for the first time in my life I thought it was a good thing to start from.
I'd also say that the whole story was about to be able toaccept your whole self, your past self, your actual self and even your future self. You have to accept your flaws, your mistakes in order to be able to love yourself, because if you don't accept yourself you will never be able to love anyone else. You just can't love anyone if you don't love the way you are because you will always think you are not good enough for them, that's what Banri, the main protagonist, understood at the end of the anime. I think this whole concept was really really well done, I appreciated how it was handled but I couldn't stand just one thing : Ghost Banri, that we will Call "G!Banri" from now on, was like a whole other esistence from Banri. I understand that G!Banri was someone else, because we can see through the serie that the post-incident-Barni, that we will only call Banri, is totally a different person. The way he acts and thinks it's completly different from Past/G!Banri and the one we see from the memories we get from him or Linda. Despite that, G!Banri was like a bad spirit, as he said himself at some points, that tried to stop Banri from being happy and could even interact with reality. I know it's "anime logic" but I'm someone who looks for reality in anime, especially works as Golden Time, you can't tell me it's just "anime logic". I also tried to think that maybe G!Banri was just a manifestation of Banri's regret and fear so Banri himself was trying to stop himself from being happy because he didn't feel like he deserved it (Evangelion ending, anyone?) but yet I can't accept the fact that he interacted with reality, as when he gave to Banri his ring  that fell in the river! He didn't lose it, it fell in the river, how could he find it? Or when he made all Banri's plans get cancelled and almost killed himself and the others??? I can't stand this kind of things, but yet I have to admit that I liked G!Banri much more than 'our' Banri. There were also a lot of plot-holes that I couldn't accept, like how easily Koko forgot about Matsuo (like one episode after??? I mean really? After a whole life in which you said that you were in love with someone you can just forget about them? ) or how easily Banri and Koko fell in love, I didn't get exactly why Oka-chan didn't confess to Matsuo? Or why Matsuo fell in love with Linda? Did he fall in love with her because she was pretty? That's all? I don't know. I don't get it but let's say again "anime logic?" or "light-novel logic" but yeah, I didn't read the LN so I won't talk about it. I think that is everything about the plot itself, because I've already said that I liked it so let's talk about the characters. (I'll talk just about the REAL main characters tho, Banri, Linda and Koko)


My favorite character was Linda, I guess it's nothing new I read that a lot of people liked her, she was not only the best character in the serie - she was also the most generous, real and consistent of the whole anime. Let's start talking about her, shall we? 


- Linda is a character that has matured a lot after the incident, it is not said, no one notices that, but it's true. Linda was a friendly and cheerful girl, as we can see from the accident with her brother she is also very rational, and she is determined to do all she can to make others happy. But she matured, even though she was quite insecure previously to the incident, she looks somehow more confident after it. Even when she does not know what exactly is "the best" for the other part, though, she works hard. And this is clearly visible after the accident, Linda doesn't try to regain Banri, it wouldn't take a lot to get him again, Banri is confused, he doesn't know anything about his past, how do you think he would have reacted if she told him that he had a crush on her? I think that he would run away from her at the beginning but with a little of time he would come back to her and slowly they could also ended up together. But Linda does not do this, she says that she realized how Banri was running away from her and from their past, Banri was afraid and she did not want to make things difficult. Again, as with her brother, Linda put others before herself. I love that about Linda, she doesn't meddle in Koko and Banri's relationship, despite knowing her feelings, despite everything, she just wants the best for him. She tried always to stay positive, she wants to help everyone, she doesn't give up, she is kind to everyone, even when Oka-chan attcks her, she worried about the girl first. That's Linda! Linda respects people's space remiding them that she's there. She said from the first moment to Banri that she didn't want him back. Deep down she did, of course she wanted that time back, but she pretended to not listen when G!Banri said that he wanted to go back during the time it was just to two of them and it was because she knew that the "Actual" Banri wouldn't be happy about it. She did it for him, even though it would make her suffer. She was never selfish, not once, even though she could have took so many chances to get Banri back she didn't because she knew it wasn't right for him. That's why Linda is my favorite character. She is a nice person who tried her best, with her flaws and her mistakes, she does her best to make others happy.

She was a support during the whole serie, even in the end when she gives Banri his shoes, she is there, always as his shadow.


I'll leave Banri as last character for a few of reasons so let's talk about Koko.


- My relationship with Koko is hard. I like and can't stand her at the same time. Koko is a strange girl? Sometimes, or often, she has exaggerated reactions. She's irrational, selfish and sometimes even a bit stupid. Despite that she is admirable for the effort that she makes to stay close to the people she loves, the way she gives all of herself without restrictions, the immense patience that she has towards others and in her own way she cares about the people she loves (as with Mitsuo after falling out in love with him or with Oka-chan). And despite the fact that I really loved Linda, as I've already said, I think she's the best for the post-incident-Banri. Banri needs someone as Koko because she's pushy, she's always there ready to remind him that she loves him, even with her strange ways to show him love. She's there and she won't go away. Linda was good for before-incident-Banri but not for 'our' Banri. He knows that, they know that, I know that. But even though I understand that I can't stand the way she reacts, she thinks only about herself, sometimes she over-reacts about every little thing and she acts like she possesses Banri, she wants to manipulate their time together, she lies sometimes, she hides things from him, and she does everything she can to make the both of them happy. I don't like people as Koko but I know she does all of it for good, I can't hate her, even though she has all I hate in people I dislike, she's just a human being and she doesn't know to react, she can just be herself, right? so, yeah, she's a good character deep deep deep inside, and she was definitely the best pick for Banri.


Now, Banri.

- I've already said that I love Ghost Banri much more than Banri. I love the way he is still there, the way he doesn't to give up, I love the desperation he portrays. If you think about it, Ghost Banri lost his life and he was replaced by another Banri. Sometimes, your past self replaces you, but deep inside you stay yourself. Ghost Banri, instead, lost his place. He was just put away and forgotten. I think that if Banri from the first day after the incident faced his friends, his family, his feelings and everything, Ghost Banri wouldn't have been so sad, but yet, how would anyone of us react if one day they just woke up without knowing anything? We are who we are because of our memories. We don't exist without them. No one of you is "you" if you don't have memories, the memory of your beloved ones, the memory of the people you hate, the people you lost, the mistakes you made, the things you wish to forget, to forgive, the things you want to move on from, the things you want to keep, the people you want to never give up on. Everything loses its meaning if there is no memory. That's why memory has such a beautiful and strong power, and that's why I feel so sad for Ghost Banri. He lost his chance to live and now he's succubus of someone who isn't "himself" but yet I understand that we couldn't get Ghost Banri back, because post-incident-Banri now is here and it's right for him to be here, he should just accept Ghost Banri right? About the things I didn't like about G!Banri, I've said them in the part in which I was talking of the plot so. 

- About 'our' Banri, there are so many things I'd like to say, he might look like your passive character who just stays still waiting for things to happen and it's true he's like that but in his own way he acts. He's scared so he runs away but there is Koko reminding him that he's not alone so he tries to move own but he never really faces the problem, you know? When you have a problem and you run from it but try to live as nothing happen it doesn't make the problem go away, it stays there and it's always ready to haunt you. That's what happens with Banri. He is not the old himself, he's another person and he doesn't want to disappear. That's why he doesn't face his past self, what if he disappears? What if Old Banri takes his place? That's an inner war that he doesn't want to face and so he runs. He runs even when Koko tells him that she doesn't want to be with him anymore, he doesn't try to get her back. He waits for her to be back. Because, again, he doesn't think he deserves it (we can see it when he remembers about her and says that even though he might be broken, he is here and that's what matters) But despite from that Banri is a nice person, he worries about others and tries his best even though he doesn't know what to do. He always needs others help but so what? After he gets it he acts, not all people can be strong as Koko some need others but doesn't mean they are not good enough. He was a plain character, true, but real. More real than others plain characters, I appreciated him, true I'd loved to see more from him but I'm glad the same. In the last part, at least we can see how much he accepted himself. 



I'm not commenting other characters because even though I liked them, except from Oka-san, which for me was a pointless character, except for her Okamera, I don't think the story would have changed without them. It might be jut my own idea but that is it. 


Once again, Golden Time had many flaws but yet it was a really pretty good work, I recommend it to everyone, really. 


Sorry for any mistake, English is not my native language.

(This review does contain a spoiler but its marked very obviously so you can skip it by just not looking at it).
This was definitely a pure romance anime that gave a sense of reality in the end. So many romance stories now days are either very tragic, or have an obvious happy ending. This was one of those stories that will give you a satisfying ending, but then again, it has it's unsatisfying parts, but you learn to accept it. It's almost neutral because it just give you a very large sense of reality.
This is my review on Golden Time, a real romance story thatactually did okay.


Story: I honestly thought it was very unique. On the actual main plot line itself, they made it feel real and the conflicts they had together felt very believable. The cult however, that seemed a bit strange, and an excuse to get Koko and Banri together somehow. They could've probably thought of something better, but it was better than nothing.


I will say, it's drama isn't so tragic but it did have me feeling sad inside at times. It made some very good conflicts and helped build the relationships between each character.


The romance was a little fast. I liked how Koko and Banri were friends at first, but around the sixth episode, they started going out saying "I love you." I guess they wanted to move the story forward but it was too quick, since they barely just met, and it caught me off guard.


Now for the lesson at the end, you actually can learn from this story. What I'm going to do, is give you a vague explanation for people who haven't seen it yet, and then I'll let you know when a spoiler it about to hit using the characters because I feel like I have to refute a couple of things.


For people who haven't seen this anime, as I said in the beginning, this is satisfactory but then again, it may not be. It's almost like a mild tragedy but ends up okay in the end. Why is this ending so weird? Because it makes you think as it did me. It presents you with reality. Lets say, you grew up with someone of the opposite sex in high school and then comes college time with your friend. You have a really good friend that's sticking with you for a long time so it might be obvious that you'll develop romantic feelings. Well...sometimes, it isn't obvious. Sometimes, friends is the last level you can reach. It's hard when someone doesn't love you back, especially when you were friends for so long, but its just reality. With this said, I'm presenting the story with a 9/10.


______________


Now...SPOILER TIME; (Read after the second line if you don't want to see the spoiler)


I know some many people loved Linda. I did too. At times I was rooting for them to get together but other times I didn't. I think Linda did have feelings for him even when she said no, there probably was something there but either wasn't ready or didn't feel like it would be good for him. This was never explained why, which sucks, but reality is, some people just can't think of their best friends romantically. This is why Koko and Banri ended up together because after with what they been through, they figure they really do love each other. Instead of Linda giving a vague answer going back in fourth with her feelings, Linda thought it was better for him anyway so she chose not to interfere with Koko and Banri.

I'm not doing art and sound because it was all good and this normally isn't always what makes a story good unless it's absolutely terrible. Little typos that go unnoticed shouldn't be a big problem. I didn't see anything. 10/10 for both.


Character: It took me a while to get use to Koko. Koko is one of those crazy stalker girls that deal with anxiety towards their boyfriend and obsesses over them. It makes her weird and kind of awkward but she knows all of this. What's admirable about her, is that she tries to change. With her still being the same Koko, she was a little annoying from time to time, but I guess that's just part of her charm. Her character development was only good. What she really needed, was more backstory and more time spent on her, more than Linda. That, I was disappointed on. I mean, she's the main character on the covers of everything.


With that said on Koko, all the relationships between the characters were very real. Linda and Banri were perfect main characters with a personality and everything. As the main male lead, Banri, he probably had the most development considering his amnesia. For this, I'll give a good 8/10.


Enjoyment: For anyone who likes a true romance focusing on relationships, and ready to learn a symbolistic lesson at the end, this is where to go. I'm giving a final 8/10. Very good. Give it a watch as it will entertain you.

In all honesty I did enjoy Golden Time from the beginning to the end, but there were a few things that steered my attention away at times. A lot being from the characters Kaga Koko and Tada Barni. For the most part I enjoyed the story. There were a small number of filler episodes aandmd there were a lot of set ups  for big plot moments. Lets start off with the story. For the most part I was really interested in the concept and plot, it was a great way to throw the emotion in there and build the characters. So thats why myscore for that is so positive. The art was top notch, I dont think therewas anything about it that disappointed me. Only one moment where Koko is wearing leggings on with her skirt and is crossing the street with Barni and all of a sudden it disappearsher legs are bare. That was weird but we all make mistakes. Other than that I loved the art. Characters were very interesting but Barni was very weak. Im not sure if his character ever got strongerr but he overcame obstacles. Kaga Koko was hilarious but she got annoying at times, But her true intentions were actually quite warming. Nevertheless, she is the "main chick" but she does get tiresome at times. I would definitely say she is an enjoyable character though and made the series something special. Yana was definitely that cynical "why am I here?" Character and he shows it. It wasn't that I disliked him, it was more of "what will happen with him?". He definitely has some funny moments though, and his combative demeanor towards Koko is undeniably hilarious. Oka Chinami was my favorite for two reasons, she was strong and she had a deep concern for her friends over herself. She was very refreshing to say the least. Linda  as s confusing. I couldn't really figure out her intentions from the start and I wasnt exactly sure what to think about her but I did enjoy her as a character. She brought a warm vibe. 2-D kun was not very interesting to me. I guess the only thing I liked about him was his concern for the group. The rest of the characters were bland but I understood their purpose. Beside everything else I really enjoyed Golden Time. Others would argue it was full of holes but I'd say it was touching. Not like other things ive seen but definitely moving. So check it out, it would be a nice little experience. \n\n
-ZRR

Golden Time is very unique due to its differences from other romantic comedies, what makes this one better is its ability to deliver a actual decent story for being a Rom Com. What made me really like it is how it's set in college/university which is really rare. Anyone who is coming into age of college or university will very much enjoy this one!!
Another thing i really love about Golden Time is its maturity, you don't see romantic comedies often that's mature and somewhat serious and still have jokes in them that can still make you laugh so hard that you snort XD. It's sortalike clannad except it has wayyy more comedy.


The art and sound are bright and vibrant, the opening is one of my favourites with its soundtrack, honestly I could hum the opening song for the longest time its weird :P.


The characters are very develop,you get to see what each character are, and how they would react to situations. You turn to like each character even thought they might have there differences. You just can't hate these characters because of how they were developed and they're role in the story. 


Overall this anime made me feel and I think people who wants to watch a relaxing,chill, and somewhat emotional anime this one is a must watch especially if you're into the romance genre. This is how all romantic comedy animes should be!!

Honestly.. it's just one of those anime you should watch.
I laughed, cried (a little) and was even angry a few times.
All in all, it was a very refreshing and enjoyable show. It had its quirks but I won't take marks off for that. Every show does. I honestly can't say I've felt this satisfied with an ending, thus far. I'll keep my eyes peeled, though.
Admittedly, there were a few times it got frustrating. Mainly when the plot gets a little too unnecessarily convoluted and tries too hard to be complicated. This show was little too straight forward for that kind of thing.
I will say, however,that it was full of depth and meaning. You'll find yourself really thinking about how you would react in that type of situation if you had gone through the same experience.\n\n
Perhaps I'm a little biased, though. I can be a huge sap and a truly hopeless romantic. This show was made purely for those types, in my eyes. It tugged at all the right heart strings and really moved me at times.\n\n
Just watch it.. if you like romance and a little drama (or a lot, in this case) this is the anime for you.\n

When I first heard about this show, I honestly didn't know what to expect. I figured it would be just like any other romance anime with a pathetic main character and useless, annoying main heroine. But not only did I absolutely adore  ALL the characters, including the main heroine, it also surprised me with it's incredibly enticing story that completely changes your view on amnesia stories. In a way, they completely flipped the whole outline of your average amnesia based story. (In order to avoid spoilers I ask that you watch the show to see what I mean). It constantly had me at theedge of my seat with all of the drama and conflicts and even after all those crazy dramatic conflicts they still manage to give you a resolution and is not only satisfying but also leave a little warm feeling in your chest.


The characters were what truly surprised me the most. All of the characters were just very well made in my opinion and each and everyone of them assists in progressing the plot which is rare to see in most shows these days. I even enjoyed the main heroine, which is pretty rare for me honestly. It's true that she has her moments where she seems overbearing and she might make you cringe at times but all of those moments, believe it or not, only help improve her personality and make you realize just how deserving she truly is. In fact almost all the characters have their moments of failure that might just piss you off at bit but those moments only build their personalities and help you better understand just what they're going through. In a way, all of the characters have their redeeming moments and that's one of many reasons I truly enjoyed this show.


Overall, this is a fantastic watch for those looking for something better than your average romance anime which is mostly comprised of high school kids bitching and whining over a few trivial things. Which is why I'm glad it took place in college instead of high school. As for the overall enjoyment of this anime, I truly think you'll be satisfied. This show will give you chills, make you cringe, and make you want to scream at some of the characters but in the end they always give you a very satisfying and very fitting resolution to all of the conflicts and challenges that the characters face, so I thoroughly believe that you shall receive a lot of enjoyment and satisfaction from this tear jerking love story.

Oh yeah the first to write a review at the end of this series. Oh yeah and my first one...
If you're looking for a (kinda) short review, try reading this one!
At first I wasn't really expecting much from this anime. I thought it was your typical dramatic love comedy... which it was at first. But not cliched in anyway, like a harem. 
You're introduced to the two protagonists, Koko and Banri who are.... not into each other? I mean yeah, that's how it always starts out, but then you see that Koko is totally stuck and clingy on some other guy and you ask yourself,"How do these characters get together (clearly shown in the opening btw) when you've got this going on?"


Of course, events happen. (If you've seen Toradora, you'll see the similarities of... interesting conflicts between the two anime and it wasn't until I realized that these anime were created by the same people. That was a pleasant surprise.) 


Then you realize that it turns out awfully tragic. Which also gives a  supernatural element to it which, I think, it's executed well. I won't tell you exactly what it is, but if I were to split up the anime into two parts: the first part about Koko (and the two getting together) and the second part about Banri. 



I've seen people give more detail on their ratings, but I like keeping things (kinda) short. 


So here's why I liked it, I actually don't like all the characters in this anime. Ha ha, I have beef with all of them for different reasons, but that's because they handled or reacted to different situations ways that reminds us that we're human. I may not like them individually, but collectively they remind us of how we can act so selfish, how we do things that we think is best for everyone else, how we hide our true feelings to protect ourselves - all the "ugly" things that make us diverse and dynamic characters in our lives. 

So maybe saying "not liking" is the right words for how I see these characters, but more like I appreciate them for.. I guess sharing their lives with us. 



I can see people not feeling the same way for this anime, so after reading this, keep in mind that this anime may not be for you ^_^


I feel that anime in general have that duality since I haven't found an anime where there was no one who didn't like it. I'm not here to persuade everyone to watch or like Golden Time although I do highly recommend it for people who want to see something different from your high school love story (and watch a college love story) :p



Thanks for reading! :D

The main reason I enjoyed Golden Time so much had to do with its honest representation of university/college romance. It showed the ups and downs of being in a serious relationship while growing up into an adult. A lot of the feelings that characters had in this show were reminiscent of my own, and I enjoyed how I could relate to what was happening on screen. Whether you’ve been in a serious relationship as a young adult or not, a lot of the mixed emotions that happen throughout the show are relatable to all walks of life. Even adjusting to university/college life is properly representedhere, and like a good drama it shows you the good and the bad. I really loved how honest it was as that’s not a common thing in anime. More akin to a drama from the West, I really enjoyed the storytelling in Golden Time.


Also, this show really knew how to write a cliffhanger. It had me coming back every week to see what was going to happen next. Even when things were going well for the characters, a wrench was thrown into their plans to stir everything up. Although the second season wasn’t as strong as the first, it still did a great job at keeping me interested. You became invested in the characters early on and stuck with them until the end. Few animes can do drama well, and Golden Time is one example of how to keep you hanging on for that next episode.


Golden Time is one series I highly recommend, even if you have trouble with the second season lull see it through to the end! It’s worth the patience.

I'll try to be brief:
This show goes places a lot within the same genre in anime do not.  The college setting is a great change I'd love to see more of.  The characters get into real relationships, express themselves, and attempt to deal with their issues.  Things most of us have experienced in real life in real ways, even if (this being entertainment) the setting and/or personalities are a bit more extreme.
If you want a lot of detail, there are plenty of other reviews that cover the show more thoroughly and better than I could.  I just want to say thatI would recommend this show to anyone looking for a show that takes relationships more seriously and dives into how complex they can sometimes be.

What to expect: A romance/slice of life show apart from the typical highschool setting with mature characters that actually develops a serious relationship
Story and Setting: ( 7/10) 
The weakest point of the show, while the premise can be seen as clicheed in romance related mediums, it still is more important  how well the plot can develop. And it doesnt do a bad job at first but then makes the mistake of dwelling too much into an unnecessary subplot, that especially in the later episodes becomes more significant and can take  you out from the shows otherwise well built relationships and romance. The settingon the other hand is promising for everyone who is sick of high school and wants more maturity. 


Characters: (10/10)


The strongest and  also the selling point of the show are the characters. While not all side characters are fleshed out or get diverse development, the main ones satisfied me. Especially the relationship between Kaga and Banri was to my liking and was  the highlight of the show. It is on one hand very relatable and believable and on the other hand adds a magical feeling that lets you forget your sorrows to it. The characters are all at a more or less mature age and thus have more mature problems. There is some comedic relief character action, but it doesnt go overboard and entertains.



Art and Sound: ( 10/10)


The overall fanatastical romantic feeling of the show is underlined by a great and fitting soundtrack, that perfectly captures each scene and event.

The  art is likeable, animations are average and do the show justice.


Enjoyment: ( 10/10)


This show had a few shorcomings but still managed to be my favourite romance anime, mainly because of its uniqueness and relatability.
